module.description: This PrepTest contains three scored LSAT sections  plus an additional section to simulate the unscored section in a real LSAT administration. Practice as if taking an actual test by following the test-taking instructions and timing yourself.

sections.directions: Directions: Each set of questions in this section is based on a single passage or a pair of passages. The questions are to be answered on the basis of what is stated or implied in the passage or pair of passages. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText:
The late 1950s and early 1960s were a time of profound growth for the civil rights movement in the United States. Although racial segregation in the public schools had been outlawed in 1954, the ruling applied only to this one category of discriminatory practice in U.S. society. But it furthered within the African-American community the anticipation of broader changes. It was in this climate that the student sit-in demonstrations of the early 1960s were born. The technique of the sit-in was simple—African Americans occupying "whites only" seats in racially segregated establishments—but this new type of student activism galvanized established civil rights organizations, brought about the creation of new ones, and generated support for the civil rights movement among many new segments of the populace.

Initiated by four students of the North Carolina Agricultural and Technical College, the first sit-in occurred at a lunch counter in February 1960. Sit-ins then spread rapidly through the southern U.S., involving over 70,000 participants by August 1961. The sit-ins provided an important model for nonviolent protest and showed students that they could affect the political process. The influence of these demonstrations on the determination of the student activists was particularly visible in two events: the formation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, and the birth of a second form of sit-ins called Freedom Rides.

The formation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee followed the first sit-in by just a few months and not only solidified student involvement in the civil rights movement but also placed students in leadership roles for the first time. It operated independently of other civil rights organizations and relied on strong local leadership, helping to transform student involvement from participation in small-scale protests into a sustained effort to challenge discrimination throughout the U.S. But the development that marked the clearest turning point for the civil rights movement was the Freedom Rides. The goal of the rides, which were organized in 1961 by the already well-established Congress of Racial Equality, was to challenge segregation through the occupation of "whites only" seats on interstate buses and in facilities at the various terminals at which the buses stopped. Because the rides inspired violent reprisals in some regions, the U.S. government began using force to protect the safety of the Freedom Riders; this was the first government action taken explicitly in support of the cause of desegregation outside the public schools. The Freedom Rides thus helped take the civil rights movement to a new level by underscoring to the U.S. government, and to U.S. society generally, the harsh realities of the segregation system, and by providing, for students and their elders alike, examples of the methods they might use to achieve a more equal society.
items.stemText: The primary purpose of the passage is to

options.optionContent: describe how the successful use in the early 1960s of a new tactic to combat discriminatory social practices led to the transformation of the U.S. civil rights movement
chronicle the activities of the U.S. civil rights movement during the late 1950s and early 1960s that led to the first use by student activists of sit-in demonstrations
contrast various techniques and tactics used by U.S. civil rights organizations in the early 1960s to expose the injustice of racial segregation and achieve a more equal society
argue that confrontational sit-in tactics were necessary in order for the U.S. civil rights movement to make inroads against racial discrimination in the late 1950s and early 1960s
provide information on the extent to which the activities of the U.S. civil rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s were rooted in the earlier successes of the movement

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This matches our anticipated primary purpose: “show why a movement of civil rights protests and organizations that started with sit-ins was historically significant.” We anticipated that this movement “started with sit-ins,” so it's accurate to say a “new tactic” eventually “led to the transformation of the U.S. civil rights movement.” This answer choice also correctly identifies that sit-in demonstrations and ensuing movements were intended to “combat discriminatory social practices.” The only part of this answer choice we may need to check is its claim that sit-ins were successfully used in the early 1960s, but the first paragraph corroborates that claim (P1, S4-S5). Once we verify this matter, we can select (A) and advance directly to the next question.

This doesn't match our anticipated primary purpose: “show why a movement of civil rights protests and organizations that started with sit-ins was historically significant.” While our anticipated main point discusses the movements that “started with sit-ins,” this answer choice focuses on the civil rights movement before sit-in demonstrations. The passage only discusses the climate before set-in demonstrations in the first three sentences. The rest of the passage discusses the sit-ins and their aftermath.

This doesn't quite match our anticipated primary purpose: “show why a movement of civil rights protests and organizations that started with sit-ins was historically significant.” The author isn't concerned with “contrast[ing]” various civil rights tactics. The author discusses tactics that were inspired by the sit-in demonstration, but the author doesn't point out these tactics' differences.

This doesn't quite match our anticipated primary purpose: “show why a movement of civil rights protests and organizations that started with sit-ins was historically significant.” The author, whose tone toward sit-in demonstrations is entirely approving, would probably not use a loaded term like “confrontational” to describe sit-ins. Moreover, the author never argues that sit-ins were “necessary” for the civil-rights movement. The author argues that sit-ins inspired other civil rights protests and organizations, but the author doesn't claim that these protests and organizations could not have grown without sit-ins.

So close! However, this answer choice messes up the dates. The passage discusses how the sit-in demonstrations of the early 1960s inspired new tactics and protests like the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and Freedom Rides. So, it's probably fair to say that the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and Freedom Rides were “rooted in the earlier successes of the movement,” but it would be ahistorical to say they were from the 1950s. Moreover, this answer choice goes a little too far when it says the passage's “primary purpose” is to show “the extent to which” activities like the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and Freedom Rides were rooted in earlier civil rights successes. The author really just asserts that both were influenced by sit-in demonstrations and doesn't elaborate (P3, S4).

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stimulusText:
The late 1950s and early 1960s were a time of profound growth for the civil rights movement in the United States. Although racial segregation in the public schools had been outlawed in 1954, the ruling applied only to this one category of discriminatory practice in U.S. society. But it furthered within the African-American community the anticipation of broader changes. It was in this climate that the student sit-in demonstrations of the early 1960s were born. The technique of the sit-in was simple—African Americans occupying "whites only" seats in racially segregated establishments—but this new type of student activism galvanized established civil rights organizations, brought about the creation of new ones, and generated support for the civil rights movement among many new segments of the populace.

Initiated by four students of the North Carolina Agricultural and Technical College, the first sit-in occurred at a lunch counter in February 1960. Sit-ins then spread rapidly through the southern U.S., involving over 70,000 participants by August 1961. The sit-ins provided an important model for nonviolent protest and showed students that they could affect the political process. The influence of these demonstrations on the determination of the student activists was particularly visible in two events: the formation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, and the birth of a second form of sit-ins called Freedom Rides.

The formation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee followed the first sit-in by just a few months and not only solidified student involvement in the civil rights movement but also placed students in leadership roles for the first time. It operated independently of other civil rights organizations and relied on strong local leadership, helping to transform student involvement from participation in small-scale protests into a sustained effort to challenge discrimination throughout the U.S. But the development that marked the clearest turning point for the civil rights movement was the Freedom Rides. The goal of the rides, which were organized in 1961 by the already well-established Congress of Racial Equality, was to challenge segregation through the occupation of "whites only" seats on interstate buses and in facilities at the various terminals at which the buses stopped. Because the rides inspired violent reprisals in some regions, the U.S. government began using force to protect the safety of the Freedom Riders; this was the first government action taken explicitly in support of the cause of desegregation outside the public schools. The Freedom Rides thus helped take the civil rights movement to a new level by underscoring to the U.S. government, and to U.S. society generally, the harsh realities of the segregation system, and by providing, for students and their elders alike, examples of the methods they might use to achieve a more equal society.
items.stemText: According to the passage, the outlawing of segregation in the U.S. public schools in 1954 had which one of the following consequences?

options.optionContent: It led directly to the formation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.
It served to encourage African Americans to expect similar changes in other parts of society.
It provided a useful example of a method students might use to achieve a more equal society.
It dramatically concluded a period of profound growth in the U.S. civil rights movement.
It galvanized established U.S. civil rights organizations and led immediately to the creation of new ones.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this refer to one of three consequences we found in the first paragraph (not making segregation illegal elsewhere, leading the African-American community to anticipate broader changes, inspiring sit-in demonstrations)? Nope. For this reason, we can cross off (A). In fact, the passage makes it seem like the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee was directly inspired by the sit-in demonstrations (P2, S4; P3, S1), not the outlawing of segregation in public schools.

Does this refer to one of three consequences we found in the first paragraph (not making segregation illegal elsewhere, leading the African-American community to anticipate broader changes, inspiring sit-in demonstrations)? Yes! This refers to the second consequence we identified. The passage claims that the outlawing of segregation also led the African-American community to anticipate “broader changes” (P1, S3). “Broader changes” in that context means changes beyond just making segregation illegal in public schools. So, it's accurate to say that the outlawing of segregation in schools encouraged “African Americans to expect similar changes in other parts of society.” Because this answer choice conforms to our anticipation, we can select it.

Does this refer to one of three consequences we found in the first paragraph (not making segregation illegal elsewhere, leading the African-American community to anticipate broader changes, inspiring sit-in demonstrations)? Not quite. While this decision eventually inspired sit-in demonstrations, it would be a stretch to say that the decision “provided a useful example of a method students” could use to fight discrimination. The case didn't directly provide an example—it's not as if Chief Justice Warren and Thurgood Marshall showed students how to occupy segregated areas in Brown v. Board of Education. It's more accurate to say that the outlawing of segregated schools inspired African Americans to expect more changes and fight for those changes with techniques like the sit-in. So, we can eliminate this answer choice. If we check the passage, we'll see that the author says that the Freedom Rides, not the outlawing of segregated schools, provided a useful example of a method students might use “to achieve a more equal society.”

Does this refer to one of three consequences we found in the first paragraph (not making segregation illegal elsewhere, leading the African-American community to anticipate broader changes, inspiring sit-in demonstrations)? Not at all. This passage's main point says that outlawing segregation in public schools led to sit-ins, which inspired a new movement of civil rights activism through the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and Freedom Rides. It didn't conclude the “period of profound growth” at all!

Does this refer to one of three consequences we found in the first paragraph (not making segregation illegal elsewhere, leading the African-American community to anticipate broader changes, inspiring sit-in demonstrations)? Not quite. The author implies that outlawing segregation in public schools eventually, indirectly led to sit-in demonstrations. It would be a stretch to say that outlawing segregation in public schools immediately “galvanized established U.S. civil rights organizations” or led to “the creation of new ones.” So, we can eliminate this answer choice. If we checked the passage, we'd see that the author says that the sit-ins, not the outlawing of segregated schools, “galvanized established civil rights organizations” and “brought about the creation of new ones” (P1, S5).

The late 1950s and early 1960s were a time of profound growth for the civil rights movement in the United States. The Freedom Rides thus helped take the civil rights movement to a new level by underscoring to the U.S. government, and to U.S. society generally, the harsh realities of the segregation system, and by providing, for students and their elders alike, examples of the methods they might use to achieve a more equal society.
items.stemText: Based on the passage, which one of the following can be most reasonably inferred about the Freedom Rides?

options.optionContent: They were primarily a spontaneous phenomenon.
They were directed against the U.S. government.
They were less important to the U.S. civil rights movement than were the original sit-in demonstrations.
They were based on a different philosophy than the original sit-in demonstrations.
They were modeled on the original sit-in demonstrations.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with the facts we reviewed in our note on the Freedom Rides or in the third paragraph? Nope. This isn't reflected in our notes on the Freedom Rides, so we can justifiably eliminate—or at least table—(A) and move on to the next answer choice. Besides, if we reviewed the third paragraph, we'd already know that these were not “spontaneous” affairs. They were “organized in 1961 by the already well-established Congress of Racial Equality” with deliberate objectives (P3, S4). So, (A) is a false statement.

Is this consistent with the facts we reviewed in our note on the Freedom Rides or in the third paragraph? No. This isn't reflected in our notes on the Freedom Rides, so we can justifiably eliminate—or at least table—(B) and move on to the next answer choice. Besides, if we reviewed the third paragraph, we'd already know that the Freedom Rides were not necessarily directed against the U.S. government. Ostensibly, they were directed at “interstate buses” and the “facilities at the various terminals” (P3, S4). We don't know if the U.S. government operated these in the early 1960s. Moreover, the author only mentions the U.S. government in the third paragraph to say that the U.S. government began using force to protect the safety of the Freedom Riders and later became more aware of the harsh realities of segregation (P3, S5-S6). So, while the Freedom Rides may have changed the U.S. government, they weren't necessarily directed against the government.

Is this consistent with the facts we reviewed in our note on the Freedom Rides or in the third paragraph? Negative. This isn't reflected in our notes on the Freedom Rides, so we can justifiably eliminate—or at least table—(C) and move on to the next answer choice. Besides, if we reviewed the third paragraph, we'd already know that the author calls the Freedom Rides “the clearest turning point for the civil rights movement” (P3, S3). The author thinks the Freedom Rides were very important, perhaps even more important than the original sit-in demonstrations.

Is this consistent with the facts we reviewed in our note on the Freedom Rides or in the third paragraph? Again, no. This isn't reflected in our notes on the Freedom Rides. Moreover, our anticipated main point suggests that the sit-in demonstrations inspired the Freedom Rides. So, we can justifiably eliminate (D) and move on to the next answer choice. Besides, if we reviewed the third paragraph, we'd already know that the Freedom Rides seem very similar to the original sit-in demonstrations. After all, like the sit-ins, the Freedom Rides involved occupying “'whites only' seats” in segregated spaces to protest this discrimination (P3, S4). The similarity of these two approaches further suggests that (D) is false.

Is this consistent with the facts we reviewed in our note on the Freedom Rides or in the third paragraph? Yep. While this isn't reflected in our notes on the Freedom Rides, our anticipated main point suggests that the sit-in demonstrations inspired the Freedom Rides. This strongly suggests that the Freedom Rides were modeled on the original sit-in demonstrations. Moreover, if we reviewed the third paragraph, we'd already know that the Freedom Rides seem very similar to the original sit-in demonstrations. Like the sit-ins, the Freedom Rides involved occupying “'whites only' seats” in segregated spaces to protest this discrimination (P3, S4). Since these two tactics are so similar, we can combine that with the main point to validly infer that the Freedom Rides were modeled on the original sit-in demonstrations. Additionally, the second paragraph refers to the Freedom Rides as a “second form of sit-ins” (P2, S4). All of these facts suggest that (E) is supported.

items.stemText: The discussion of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in the third paragraph is intended primarily to

options.optionContent: argue for the preeminence of a particular U.S. civil rights organization
serve as a contrast to discussion of the efforts of student sit-in demonstrators
summarize the historical background against which the Freedom Rides flourished
describe an important outgrowth of the student sit-in demonstrations
explain why local sit-in demonstrations require nationally coordinated efforts

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this say the author discusses the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show a civil rights movement that was inspired by the sit-in demonstrations? Nope. We can quickly cross off (A). Besides, the author doesn't argue that any particular type of civil rights organization is “preeminent” or superior to others.

Does this say the author discusses the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show a civil rights movement that was inspired by the sit-in demonstrations? No. The author doesn't think the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the sit-in demonstrations are contrasting efforts. The author argues that the sit-in demonstrations inspired the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee by showing students that they can affect change in the civil rights movement.

Does this say the author discusses the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show a civil rights movement that was inspired by the sit-in demonstrations? Negative. For that reason, we can immediately eliminate (C). Besides, the author doesn't introduce the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee as a background detail in the story of the Freedom Rides. The author says that the sit-in demonstrations influenced two important events: the formation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the Freedom Rides. The author brings up the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show how it and the Freedom Rides were inspired by the sit-ins. The author doesn't mention the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show how it inspired the Freedom Rides.

Does this say the author discusses the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show a civil rights movement that was inspired by the sit-in demonstrations? Yes, it does! Based on our review of our notes and the third paragraph, we can validly conclude that the author brings up the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show an “important outgrowth” of the sit-in demonstrations. We can select (D) and advance straight to the next question.

Does this say the author discusses the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to show a civil rights movement that was inspired by the sit-in demonstrations? No. So we can cross off (E). Besides, the author never claims that sit-in demonstrations require nationally coordinated efforts.

items.stemText: Which one of the following statements most accurately expresses the author's view in the passage regarding the Freedom Rides?

options.optionContent: By exposing the harsh realities of the segregation system, the Freedom Rides induced the U.S. government to address segregation.
The Freedom Rides were the final contribution of student activists in their effort to defeat the segregation system.
The Freedom Rides introduced an entirely new technique into the U.S. civil rights movement that served as a model for later protest.
Because the Freedom Rides provoked violent reprisals against demonstrators, they reversed earlier progress in the cause of desegregation.
The Freedom Rides transformed a series of uncoordinated local student protests into a movement with national scope.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with our note for the third paragraph or what we can recall from the third question in this set? Yes! Our note for the third paragraph says that the Freedom Rides “led to government protection” and “showed segregation's harsh realities.” This answer choice says exactly that! Therefore, we can review the third paragraph to confirm that the author would agree with this. Upon reviewing the third paragraph, we'll see that the author says, “Because the rides inspired violent reprisals in some regions, the U.S. government began using force to protect the safety of the Freedom Riders; this was the first government action taken explicitly in support of the cause of desegregation outside the public schools” (P3, S5). The author also claims that the “Freedom Rides thus helped take the civil rights movement to a new level by underscoring to the U.S. government, and to U.S. society generally, the harsh realities of the segregation system” (P3, S6). So, these details confirm that the Freedom Rides exposed the harsh realities of the segregation system and induced the U.S. government to address segregation. We can select (A) and wrap up this passage.

Is this consistent with our note for the third paragraph or what we can recall from the third question in this set? Nope. Our note doesn't suggest that the Freedom Rides were the last contribution from students. Moreover, the phrase “the final” is a strong, hard-to-support phrase that we don't like to see in Author Agree answer choices. Therefore, we can cross this off without checking the passage. Besides, if we had to check the passage, we'd see that the author claims that the “Freedom Rides thus helped take the civil rights movement to a new level” and provided, “for students and their elders alike, examples of the methods they might use to achieve a more equal society” (P3, S6). So, far from being the end of student involvement with civil rights, the Freedom Rides marked the beginning of a new era of student involvement.

Is this consistent with our note for the third paragraph or what we can recall from the third question in this set? Nope. Our note doesn't suggest that the Freedom Rides were an “entirely new technique.” Moreover, the word “entirely” is a strong, hard-to-support word that we don't like to see in an Author's Agree answer choice. So, we can cross off (C) without reviewing the passage. Besides, if we had to check the passage, we'd see that the Freedom Rides were very similar to the original sit-in demonstrations. After all, like the sit-ins, the Freedom Rides involved occupying “'whites only'” seats in segregated spaces to protest this discrimination (P3, S4). The similarity of these two approaches further suggests that the author would disagree with (C). In fact, the author claims in the second paragraph that the freedom rides were “a second form of sit-ins” (P2, S4).

Is this consistent with our note for the third paragraph or what we can recall from the third question in this set? No. Our note for the third paragraph says the Freedom Rides led to violent reactions, but that the violence “led to government protection” of the demonstrators. So, far from “revers[ing] earlier progress,” the Freedom Rides led to greater protection against discrimination. We can cross off (D) without reviewing the passage. Indeed, if we checked the passage, we'd also see that the author says that “Freedom Rides thus helped take the civil rights movement to a new level” (P3, S6), which shows that the author disagrees with (D).

Is this consistent with our note for the third paragraph or what we can recall from the third question in this set? Negative. Our note doesn't suggest that the Freedom Rides started out as uncoordinated. Therefore, we can eliminate—or at least table—(E) without checking the passage. Besides, if we had to check the passage, we wouldn't find any evidence that the Freedom Rides started off as a series of uncoordinated student protests. On the contrary, the author says the Freedom Rides were “organized in 1961 by the already well-established Congress of Racial Equality” and had deliberate objectives (P3, S4). This suggests that the author would disagree with (E).

items.stimulusText:
Grammarians of the prescriptive school take it as part of their task to distinguish correct from incorrect usage in language and thereby to encourage the former. They believe that in so doing they play an essential role in preventing a constantly changing language from falling into disarray. In contrast, descriptive grammarians are so called because they are content to describe the way language is actually used by members of a community. In their eyes, those who seek to preserve some forms of usage while preventing others from gaining a foothold are being unscientific and are, moreover, doomed to almost certain failure. Descriptivists point to numerous examples of usage that were once judged by prescriptivists to be incorrect but that over time and through continual use have come to be almost universally accepted. One example is the use of "data" as a singular noun in English: prescriptivists have typically regarded the phrase "the data is incomplete" as ungrammatical, on the grounds that "data" is the plural of the Latin noun "datum" and should continue to be treated as a plural in English out of respect for the word's origins. Descriptivists argue that "data," in addition to its use as a plural, has acquired a widespread use as a singular mass term, like "water." It would be pointless, they say, to try to reverse this trend.

This example illustrates the two main objections of descriptivists to prescriptivism. The first is the scientific objection: the transformation of language is governed by laws not unlike the laws of nature, and those trying to hold back linguistic change might as well attempt to defy the law of gravity. The second is the egalitarian objection: the prescriptivists are simply trying to impose their own linguistic practices, which are usually those of an educated and affluent elite, upon other members of society. The suggestion is that the attempted imposition is somehow immoral.

With regard to the scientific objection, it should be noted that while many attempts to regulate language have failed, some have succeeded. Descriptivists may respond that in the latter cases the usages favored by prescriptivists were in accordance with the laws governing linguistic change and would have prevailed without their assistance. But this is in large measure an article of faith. In the end it must be acknowledged that the laws governing the transformation of language are not like the laws of physics. Language usage depends on choices made by individuals, who are subject to persuasion. In response to the egalitarian objection, prescriptivists point to the importance of standard language usage for the free exchange of ideas. Those to whom preservation of the standard is entrusted inevitably possess some of the attributes of an elite, but their aim is one of inclusion rather than exclusion.
items.stemText: The passage says that the aim of descriptivist grammarians is to

options.optionContent: criticize the habits of language users
observe how language is actually used
facilitate communication among language users
slow the pace of linguistic change
influence laws that govern language usage

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this match our anticipation that the aim of the descriptivists is to “describe language as it's used”? Nope. This sounds more like those fuddy-duddy prescriptivists, although “criticize” might be too harsh of a word for them. Regardless, we can cross off (A).

Does this match our anticipation that the aim of the descriptivists is to “describe language as it's used”? This is pretty close! We don't love the word “observe”—the word “describe,” which is used in the passage and our notes, suggests the descriptivists take a more active role in their approach. Still, this is otherwise such a close match to our anticipation that we can mark it as a strong contender and quickly evaluate the remaining choices. If all the remaining choices are further from our anticipation, we'll select (B) confidently.

Does this match our anticipation that the aim of the descriptivists is to “describe language as it's used”? No. Neither the notes nor the part of the passage we reviewed suggests that the descriptivists want to help people communicate with each other. That's enough reason to eliminate (C). Besides, if you have a good memory of the last paragraph, you may recall that the author says one of the prescriptivists' aims is to promote “the free exchange of ideas” (P3, S6). So, like (A), this answer choice describes the prescriptivists.

Does this match our anticipation that the aim of the descriptivists is to “describe language as it's used”? Nope. Like (A) and (C), this describes the prescriptivists. They want to slow linguistic change before language falls into disrepair (P1, S2). We can eliminate (D).

Does this match our anticipation that the aim of the descriptivists is to “describe language as it's used”? Not quite. Once again, this answer choice describes the prescriptivists. They're the ones who want to influence whatever laws govern language by imposing their standards (P1, S2). We can eliminate (E).

items.stimulusText:
Grammarians of the prescriptive school take it as part of their task to distinguish correct from incorrect usage in language and thereby to encourage the former. They believe that in so doing they play an essential role in preventing a constantly changing language from falling into disarray. In contrast, descriptive grammarians are so called because they are content to describe the way language is actually used by members of a community. In their eyes, those who seek to preserve some forms of usage while preventing others from gaining a foothold are being unscientific and are, moreover, doomed to almost certain failure. Descriptivists point to numerous examples of usage that were once judged by prescriptivists to be incorrect but that over time and through continual use have come to be almost universally accepted. One example is the use of "data" as a singular noun in English: prescriptivists have typically regarded the phrase "the data is incomplete" as ungrammatical, on the grounds that "data" is the plural of the Latin noun "datum" and should continue to be treated as a plural in English out of respect for the word's origins. Descriptivists argue that "data," in addition to its use as a plural, has acquired a widespread use as a singular mass term, like "water." It would be pointless, they say, to try to reverse this trend.

This example illustrates the two main objections of descriptivists to prescriptivism. The first is the scientific objection: the transformation of language is governed by laws not unlike the laws of nature, and those trying to hold back linguistic change might as well attempt to defy the law of gravity. The second is the egalitarian objection: the prescriptivists are simply trying to impose their own linguistic practices, which are usually those of an educated and affluent elite, upon other members of society. The suggestion is that the attempted imposition is somehow immoral.

With regard to the scientific objection, it should be noted that while many attempts to regulate language have failed, some have succeeded. Descriptivists may respond that in the latter cases the usages favored by prescriptivists were in accordance with the laws governing linguistic change and would have prevailed without their assistance. But this is in large measure an article of faith. In the end it must be acknowledged that the laws governing the transformation of language are not like the laws of physics. Language usage depends on choices made by individuals, who are subject to persuasion. In response to the egalitarian objection, prescriptivists point to the importance of standard language usage for the free exchange of ideas. Those to whom preservation of the standard is entrusted inevitably possess some of the attributes of an elite, but their aim is one of inclusion rather than exclusion.
items.stemText: The author's defense of the prescriptivist approach in the fourth and fifth sentences of the final paragraph would be most strengthened if which one of the following were true?

options.optionContent: A study showed that communities left to formulate their own rules of grammar typically develop rules very similar to those of other communities.
A study found a strong correlation between emphasis on grammar instruction in primary schools and lifelong adherence to the rules of usage taught there.
A cross-cultural study found that nations with extensive formal education systems and those with minimal education systems demonstrate a similar range of variation in language use.
A study showed that groups of students left to formulate their own rules of grammar usage were more likely to reach agreement if they had little prior instruction in correct usage.
A report demonstrated that within certain communities linguistic practices were quite uniform despite large differences between communities.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this strengthen the argument that language change does not follow certain observable, unchangeable laws because people are persuadable? No. In fact, this makes language seem more law-like. If two separate communities—presumably with people who are persuadable in all sorts of different ways—end up developing very similar grammar rules, it seems like language resembles a scientific law. If people were so unique and persuadable, as this author contends, we'd expect the grammatical rules created by different people to vary. Instead, these languages are all subject to the same rules, much like the groups would be subject to the same scientific laws. Therefore, (A) weakens the author's argument.

Does this strengthen the argument that language change does not follow certain observable, unchangeable laws because people are persuadable? Yes! This answer choice shows that people can be persuaded enough to overcome any observable, immutable laws. If people adhere to the grammar rules taught in their early schooling, that shows that people are highly influenceable. If there were strong laws that governed linguistic change, we'd expect these people's linguistic behavior to change according to those rules at some point. However, since these people's linguistic behavior doesn't change much after early grade school, it supports the author's argument that language is not very law-like. While most test-takers wouldn't feel comfortable selecting the first answer choice that appears to strengthen the argument, we can at least mark (B) as a strong contender and take a quick look at the remaining choices. After eliminating (C) through (E), we can select (B) with confidence.

Does this strengthen the argument that language change does not follow certain observable, unchangeable laws because people are persuadable? Nope. Like (A), this makes language seem more law-like. If two nations with different education systems produce “a similar range of variation in language use,” that doesn't make it seem like education systems are very good at changing the way people speak. If even an “extensive formal education system” can't influence people to speak more “correctly,” that might suggest that language use is governed by something akin to scientific laws. (We're hedging with “might” because we don't know the extent to which these education systems address grammar or usage.) At the very least, we can confidently say that this doesn't strengthen the author's contention that language change doesn't follow law-like rules.

Does this strengthen the argument that language change does not follow certain observable, unchangeable laws because people are persuadable? No. This answer choice doesn't make people seem very persuadable at all! If students are less likely to agree with each other on grammar usage after they've been given prior instruction in correct usage, it seems like students have trouble learning grammatical rules. The students are better off developing their own system, not trying to follow the “correct” rules the prescriptivists recommend. So, this definitely doesn't strengthen the author's pro-prescriptivist argument.

Does this strengthen the argument that language change does not follow certain observable, unchangeable laws because people are persuadable? Nope. Like (A) and (C), this answer choice makes language seem very law-like. If two separate, very distinct communities follow similar linguistic practices, it seems like language follows some sort of scientific law. If people were so unique and persuadable, as this author contends, we'd expect the languages created by communities of different people to operate quite differently from each other. Instead, these communities are subject to the same linguistic practices, like how the communities are subject to the same scientific laws. Therefore, (E) weakens the author's argument.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stemText: The passage most strongly suggests that the author would agree with which one of the following statements?

options.optionContent: The conflict between prescriptivists and descriptivists reveals the need for a new approach synthesizing the ideas of the existing schools.
Although the prescriptivist call for a free exchange of ideas should be supported, the etymologies of words should not influence current usage.
Moral considerations should ultimately have no bearing on recommendations regarding correct language usage.
Scientific methods can contribute nothing to the study of grammar because language is not subject to natural laws like those of physics.
The successful attempts by prescriptivists to regulate language are evidence that individuals will sometimes make linguistic choices in response to persuasion.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with the author's main point or reflected in our notes on the author's attitude? Nope. The author doesn't recommend “synthesizing” the prescriptivist and descriptivist approaches in their main point. The author takes sides with the descriptivist approach! So, we can infer from just the main point that the author would disagree with this claim.

Is this consistent with the author's main point or reflected in our notes on the author's attitude? No. Neither the main point nor our notes mention the “etymologies of words,” so we have no idea if the author would agree with this claim. Moreover, this answer choice expresses slight disagreement with the “prescriptivist call,” and we have no reason to believe that the author disagrees with the prescriptivists on any issue. Finally, this answer choice makes a strong, SCOTUS-y “should” statement, which we don't like in Author Agree answer choices. For these reasons, we can eliminate—or at least table—(B) without checking the passage and move on to the next answer choice. Besides, if we checked the passage, we would find that the only time the author brings up this topic is to suggest that prescriptivists think that the original Latin form of “data” should inform how we use that word in English (P1, S6). This would suggest that the prescriptivists believe that words' evolutions should influence their current usage. The pro-prescriptivist author might agree with that belief!

Is this consistent with the author's main point or reflected in our notes on the author's attitude? Nope. Neither the main point nor our notes mention the “moral considerations,” so we don't know whether the author would agree with this claim. Moreover, this answer choice makes a strong, SCOTUS-y “should” statement, which we don't like in Author Agree answer choices. For these reasons, we can eliminate—or at least table—(C) without checking the passage and move on to the next answer choice. Besides, if we checked the passage, the only reference to anything like “moral considerations” occurs when the author says that descriptivists suggest that the prescriptivist approach is “somehow immoral” (P2, S4). While the author disagrees with the descriptivists on this issue, that doesn't necessarily mean that the author doesn't want morality to play any function in how language is used. The author might think that prescriptivist approaches involve moral considerations, such as whether recommended terms are truthful or offensive.

Is this consistent with the author's main point or reflected in our notes on the author's attitude? Well, the author doesn't think that language is subject to natural laws. If we don't remember that excerpt from the previous question, it says so in our third paragraph notes (“language is not law-like). But this answer choice uses the strong, SCOTUS-y language (“can contribute nothing”) that we don't like in Author Agree answer choices. So, it's probably best to resist any temptation to check the passage, table (D), and check whether (E) presents a more easily supportable statement. However, if we did check the passage to see whether the author would agree with (D), we wouldn't find support for its strong, over-the-top language. The author says that “it must be acknowledged that the laws governing the transformation of language are not like the laws of physics” (P3, S4). But does that mean science can't play any role in proper usage? Even if language doesn't follow science-like laws, the author could still think that language can benefit from some scientific principles. Therefore, we can't definitively say that the author would agree with (D).

Is this consistent with the author's main point or reflected in our notes on the author's attitude? Yes! Our note for the third paragraph shows that the author would probably agree with this claim. Our note for the third paragraph says that “regulating language is possible.” This supports (E)'s contention that there have been “successful attempts by prescriptivists to regulate language.” If we don't remember this quotation from the previous question, we can check the third paragraph to confirm that the author also agrees with the claim that individuals will sometimes make linguistic choices in response to persuasion (P3, S4). Structurally, the author uses the claim that some attempts at regulating language have been successful to support the claim that “[l]anguage usage depends on choices made by individuals, who are subject to persuasion (P3, S1, S4). So, the author would also agree that the successful attempts to regulate language “are evidence that individuals will sometimes make linguistic choices in response to persuasion.” Therefore, we can definitively conclude that the author would agree with (E). Let's select it and move on.

items.stemText: The author most likely uses the phrase "article of faith" (third sentence of the final paragraph) to mean that descriptivists

options.optionContent: demonstrate a greater measure of intellectual commitment than prescriptivists do
rely on theory rather than observation in describing language usage
hold to their views on language usage despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary
have no proof to bolster their claim that prescriptivists' efforts have no effect on the evolution of language
have based their claims on empirical evidence that other researchers have discredited

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this say the author uses the phrase to mean that the descriptivists “cannot prove their claim” or “have no evidence to support their claim” about perscriptivism? Nope. The author uses this phrase to criticize the descriptivists, not to praise them for having more “intellectual commitment than the prescriptivists. We can immediately cross off (A).”

Does this say the author uses the phrase to mean that the descriptivists “cannot prove their claim” or “have no evidence to support their claim” about perscriptivism? No, so we can eliminate (B) without thinking about it too deeply. Besides, “relying on theory rather than observation” doesn't sound like descriptivists. They want to observe and record how people actually use language (P1, S3).

Does this say the author uses the phrase to mean that the descriptivists “cannot prove their claim” or “have no evidence to support their claim” about perscriptivism? Not quite. The author means that the descriptivists don't have evidence to prove their claim. That doesn't mean that there's “overwhelming evidence” that they're wrong, though. In fact, it would be hard to present evidence for either side of the issue discussed—whether successful language regulations were consistent with the laws governing linguistic change and would have occurred even without the prescriptivists' recommendations. We can't produce evidence for a hypothetical like that, so (C) is incorrect.

Does this say the author uses the phrase to mean that the descriptivists “cannot prove their claim” or “have no evidence to support their claim” about perscriptivism? Yes, it does! The author uses the phrase to show that descriptivists have no proof for the claim that successful language regulations would have occurred even without the prescriptivists' recommendations. In other words, the author says that descriptivists cannot bolster their claim that prescriptivists' efforts have “no effect on the evolution of language.” Because this conforms to our anticipation, we can select (D) and advance immediately to the following question.

Does this say the author uses the phrase to mean that the descriptivists “cannot prove their claim” or “have no evidence to support their claim” about perscriptivism? Nope. The author means that the descriptivists don't have evidence to prove their claim. That doesn't mean that they once produced evidence that has since been discredited. In fact, it would be hard to present evidence for the descriptivists' argument—that successful language regulations would have occurred even without the prescriptivists' recommendations. We can't produce evidence for a hypothetical like that. This makes (E) incorrect.

items.stemText: The passage indicates that which one of the following views is held by prescriptivists?

options.optionContent: The constant change that language undergoes should be regarded as healthy for the language.
The study of language is not a scientific undertaking.
A word's origins should inform its current usage.
Laws do not govern the transformation of language.
Morality is not at issue in the study of language usage.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with what we reviewed in the first paragraph? No. This doesn't sound like the prescriptivists we read about. They want to keep language from changing too much to ensure it doesn't fall into disarray (P1, S2). We can eliminate (A).

Is this consistent with what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Nope. Nothing we reviewed in the first paragraph would support this assertion. Still, this is a tempting answer choice for many test-takers. While the author eventually argues that linguistic change is not governed by science-like laws (P3, S4), that view is the author's—we don't know whether it's held by prescriptivists generally. And even if prescriptivists don't think linguistic change is governed by science-like laws, they still might think that the study of language is somewhat scientific.

Is this consistent with what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Yes! This is supported by the “data” example from the first paragraph. The author says that the prescriptivists think “data” is plural in English because it's plural in its original Latin and thus “should continue to be treated as a plural in English out of respect for the word's origins” (P1, S6). So, the prescriptivists definitely think that a word's origins should inform its current usage. We can confidently select (C) and advance to the following question.

Is this consistent with what we reviewed in the first paragraph? No. We didn't review anything in the first paragraph that would support this claim. Still, like (B), this is a tempting answer choice for some test-takers. Although the author eventually argues that linguistic change is not governed by science-like laws (P3, S4), that's the author's belief. We don't know whether the prescriptivists agree with it. Even if the prescriptivists agree with the claim that linguistic change is not governed by science-like laws, they still might think that some laws govern changes to language.

Is this consistent with what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Negative. We didn't review anything in the first paragraph that would support this claim. We can safely discard (E). Besides, if we checked the passage, the only reference to anything like “morality” occurs when the author says that descriptivists suggest that the prescriptivist approach is “somehow immoral” (P2, S4). The author disagrees with the descriptivists on this issue. Moreover, this charge doesn't imply that the prescriptivists don't think morality plays any role in the study of language. The prescriptivists might consider their approach a moral duty to keep language in good shape and facilitate interpersonal communication.

items.stemText: The passage provides the most support for inferring which one of the following?

options.optionContent: The rate at which linguistic change takes place has increased as descriptivism has gained more widespread acceptance.
Descriptivists endorse some attempts to prescribe correct language usage, but only in cases in which the prescription takes word origins into account.
Descriptivists do not acknowledge that some uses of language are unavoidably ambiguous.
Prescriptivists and descriptivists both recognize that the English language is constantly changing.
Prescriptivists generally do not consider their attempts to regulate language as successful until descriptivists' investigations show that the regulation is being followed.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with the main point or reflected in our notes? Nope. Neither the main point nor our notes discuss whether language is changing more rapidly or whether “descriptivism has gained more widespread acceptance.” For this reason, we can eliminate—or at least table—(A) and move on to the next answer choice without checking the passage. Besides, we wouldn't find any support for this claim if we re-read the entire passage. The passage doesn't state or imply that linguistic change is happening at a more rapid pace or whether descriptivism has become more widely accepted.

Is this consistent with the main point or reflected in our notes? No. Neither the main point nor our notes discuss whether descriptivists endorse some attempts to recommend “correct language usage.” For this reason, we can eliminate—or at least table—(B) and move on to the next answer choice without checking the passage. Besides, if we re-read the passage, we'd see that the only time the passage discusses a word's origins—the “data” example—the descriptivists argue against the prescription that “data” be treated as a plural noun (P1, S6-S7). Although it's possible that the descriptivists might sometimes recommend the prescriptivist approach, the passage does not furnish any evidence for that.

Is this consistent with the main point or reflected in our notes? Nope. Neither the main point nor our notes discuss “ambiguous langauge.” So, we can eliminate—or at least table—(C) and move on to the next answer choice without checking the passage. Besides, we wouldn't find any support for this claim if we re-read the entire passage. The passage doesn't state or imply that language is sometimes unavoidably ambiguous or that the descriptivists overlook that fact.

Is this consistent with the main point or reflected in our notes? Well, yes. Our notes suggest that both prescriptivists and descriptivists recognize that language is changing. Our note for the first paragraph suggests that prescriptivists want to correct a changing language, and our note for the second paragraph shows that descriptivists believe that language change is governed by science-like laws. Therefore, we can dive into the passage to confirm that (D) is supported. In the first paragraph, the author says that prescriptivists believe that “they play an essential role in preventing a constantly changing language from falling into disarray” (P1, S2). In the second paragraph, the author explains that descriptivists believe that the laws governing linguistic change are like scientific laws, so trying to counter this change is like defying gravity (P2, S2). If these descriptivists believe this change is like the law of gravity, they must believe this change is constantly present. So, we can find textual support that shows that (D) is almost certainly true. We can select it and advance to the following question.

Is this consistent with the main point or reflected in our notes? Nope. Neither the main point nor our notes discuss whether prescriptivists need descriptivists to confirm that the prescriptivists' attempts to regulate language are successful. So, we can eliminate—or at least table—(E) and return to any answer choice we haven't already eliminated. Besides, we wouldn't find any support for this claim if we re-read the entire passage. The only time the author mentions successful regulations, the author doesn't claim who confirmed that the regulation is being followed (P3, S1).

items.stimulusText:
Grammarians of the prescriptive school take it as part of their task to distinguish correct from incorrect usage in language and thereby to encourage the former. They believe that in so doing they play an essential role in preventing a constantly changing language from falling into disarray. In contrast, descriptive grammarians are so called because they are content to describe the way language is actually used by members of a community. In their eyes, those who seek to preserve some forms of usage while preventing others from gaining a foothold are being unscientific and are, moreover, doomed to almost certain failure. Descriptivists point to numerous examples of usage that were once judged by prescriptivists to be incorrect but that over time and through continual use have come to be almost universally accepted. One example is the use of "data" as a singular noun in English: prescriptivists have typically regarded the phrase "the data is incomplete" as ungrammatical, on the grounds that "data" is the plural of the Latin noun "datum" and should continue to be treated as a plural in English out of respect for the word's origins. Descriptivists argue that "data," in addition to its use as a plural, has acquired a widespread use as a singular mass term, like "water." It would be pointless, they say, to try to reverse this trend.

This example illustrates the two main objections of descriptivists to prescriptivism. The first is the scientific objection: the transformation of language is governed by laws not unlike the laws of nature, and those trying to hold back linguistic change might as well attempt to defy the law of gravity. The second is the egalitarian objection: the prescriptivists are simply trying to impose their own linguistic practices, which are usually those of an educated and affluent elite, upon other members of society. The suggestion is that the attempted imposition is somehow immoral.

With regard to the scientific objection, it should be noted that while many attempts to regulate language have failed, some have succeeded. Descriptivists may respond that in the latter cases the usages favored by prescriptivists were in accordance with the laws governing linguistic change and would have prevailed without their assistance. But this is in large measure an article of faith. In the end it must be acknowledged that the laws governing the transformation of language are not like the laws of physics. Language usage depends on choices made by individuals, who are subject to persuasion. In response to the egalitarian objection, prescriptivists point to the importance of standard language usage for the free exchange of ideas. Those to whom preservation of the standard is entrusted inevitably possess some of the attributes of an elite, but their aim is one of inclusion rather than exclusion.
items.stemText: The passage most strongly suggests that prescriptivists hold which one of the following views of descriptivists?

options.optionContent: Descriptivists are motivated more by animosity toward prescriptivism than by a desire to study language objectively.
Descriptivists adhere to the scientific method less rigorously than prescriptivists do, despite their claims to the contrary.
Descriptivists fail to recognize the ways in which their own approach may undermine egalitarian ideals.
Descriptivists are generally unaware of the etymologies of words that carry different meanings today than they originally did.
Descriptivists fail to acknowledge that their empirical observations generally support prescriptivist views.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with the main point or what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Is it reflected in our notes? No and no. None of these resources discuss whether the prescriptivists think descriptivists are motivated by “animosity toward prescriptivism.” Our notes suggest that the descriptivists think that prescriptivists are elitists—which is a derogatory term—but that doesn't mean the prescriptivists think descriptivists are motivated by a dislike of the prescriptive approach. So, we can eliminate—or at least table—(A) and move on to the next answer choice without checking the passage. Besides, we wouldn't find any support for this claim if we re-read the entire passage. The passage doesn't state or imply that prescriptivists hold this belief.

Is this consistent with the main point or what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Is it reflected in our notes? No and no. None of these resources discuss whether the prescriptivists think descriptivists don't follow “the scientific method.” Our notes bring up whether linguistic change follows science-like laws, but that doesn't imply that the prescriptivists or the descriptivists follow the scientific method. For this reason, we can eliminate—or at least table—(B) and move on to the next answer choice without checking the passage. Besides, we wouldn't find any support for this claim if we re-read the entire passage. The passage doesn't discuss the scientific method at all.

Is this consistent with the main point or what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Is it reflected in our notes? Well, our main point and notes mention that the author doesn't think prescriptivism is “elitist,” despite the descriptivists' claim to the contrary. This at least touches on the topic of “egalitarian ideals.” That doesn't exactly imply that the prescriptivists believe descriptivists undermine their own egalitarian ideals, but it's not so far off. Moreover, this answer choice at least uses the weak, easy-to-support language (“may”) we like in Must Be True answer choices. We should probably table (C) without checking the passage, looking to see if any other answer choices are better reflected in our notes. But if we get to the end of the line and haven't found anything, we can review this one first. Upon review, we'll see that the author claims that “prescriptivists point to the importance of standard language usage for the free exchange of ideas,” which the author characterizes as a motive toward “inclusion rather than exclusion” (P3, S6-S7). So, the prescriptivists must view the “free exchange of ideas” as an inclusive, egalitarian ideal. The author also says that prescriptivists think that allowing language to deteriorate without rules—the descriptivist approach—will leave language in “disarray” (P1, S2). If the descriptivist approach leaves language in disarray, it would be harder for people to freely exchange their ideas—which, again, the prescriptivists view as an egalitarian ideal. That would mean that prescriptivists would probably agree that the descriptivists overlook how their approach can undermine their egalitarian ideals. So, (C) is supported, and we can select it.

Is this consistent with the main point or what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Is it reflected in our notes? No and no. None of these resources discuss whether prescriptivists think that the descriptivists overlook word's etymologies. Therefore, we can eliminate—or at least table—(D) and move on to the next answer choice without checking the passage. Many test-takers will recall the discussion of “data” in the first paragraph, which has been referenced in a couple of questions already. In that part of the passage, the author says that descriptivists know that “data” was originally just a plural noun but also argue that it, “in addition to its use as a plural, has acquired a widespread use as a singular mass term” (P1, S7). So, the one time the passage brings up a word's etymology, it's for a word in which the descriptivists are apparently aware that the word used to have a different meaning.

Is this consistent with the main point or what we reviewed in the first paragraph? Is it reflected in our notes? No and no. In fact, this answer choice doesn't even make sense. The prescriptivists want to correct people's language to keep language from deteriorating (P1, S1-S2). Prescriptivists imagine a better future with more correct language. How could empirical observations support the prescriptivists' view? What ... ahem ... data could we gather that would suggest that the prescriptivist view is correct?

items.stimulusText:
Passage A is from a newspaper article. Passage B is from UNESCO's 1999 Draft Convention on the Protection of Underwater Cultural Heritage.

Passage A

A North American company that found what is believed to be the HMS Sussex during expeditions in the Mediterranean from 1998 to 2001 has signed an agreement with the British government, which owns the Sussex, to raise what may be history's richest sunken treasure and to split the proceeds. The agreement is a legal breakthrough that could allow the recovery of perhaps US$4 billion in gold coins lost with the Sussex in a storm in 1694.

As robots, sonar, and other technologically advanced gear have opened the deepest oceans to exploration and recovery, governments have begun asserting ownership over their sunken vessels. But governments often lack the money and skills to retrieve cultural riches and, until now, there had been no legal precedent for a private company to join with a government to salvage the government's treasure. This agreement could end the days of freelance treasure hunting and allow nations to oversee the recovery of their lost fleets.

The company, which is funding the venture, agrees with British historians that the ship carried coins, most likely gold, worth £1 million in 1694. The US$4 billion figure is the coins' theoretical value if sold to collectors. The agreement calls for archaeological integrity—a difficult technical feat at such depths and a goal that critics of for-profit archaeology are likely to doubt. Many archaeologists abhor the sale of recovered artifacts, arguing that this inhibits scholarly analysis and public display. The agreement, however, draws a distinction between different classes of artifacts, recognizing that cultural items have greater archaeological value than coins, which it allows to be sold to help pay for the project.

Passage B

"Underwater cultural heritage" (UCH) means all traces of human existence that have been partially, totally, or periodically situated underwater for at least 100 years.

1. The protection of UCH is best achieved through in situ (original site) preservation, which should be considered as the first option. Accordingly, activities directed at UCH shall be authorized by the competent authority of the concerned State only when they make a significant contribution to knowledge, protection, and/or enhancement of UCH.

2. The commercial exploitation of UCH for trade, sale, barter, or speculation...is fundamentally incompatible with the protection and proper management of the UCH.

3. Activities directed at UCH shall not adversely impact UCH more than is necessary for the objectives of the project;

4. must use nondestructive techniques and prospection and limited sampling in preference to recovery of objects. If excavation is necessary for the purpose of scientific studies, the methods and techniques used must be as nondestructive as possible and contribute to the preservation of the remains;

5. shall avoid the unnecessary disturbance of human remains or venerated sites;

6. shall be strictly regulated to ensure proper recording of historical, cultural, and archaeological information.

7. Public access to conduct activities relating to UCH that are nonintrusive (such as photography) should, where practicable, be encouraged.
items.stemText: Which one of the following projects would most clearly not fall within the scope of the provisions specified in passage B?

options.optionContent: The recovery of a sunken eighteenth-century Spanish treasure fleet by private, freelance treasure hunters.
The recovery of a nineteenth-century shipwreck of unknown origin in one of the Great Lakes.
The recovery of underwater artifacts from the ruins of a long-submerged ancient city built when sea levels were much lower than they are today.
The recovery of the cargo of a privately owned merchant ship that sank in 1970 off the coast of Ireland.
The recovery of prehistoric cultural artifacts recently uncovered by the damming and rerouting of a major river.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this bring up artifacts that aren't underwater or haven't been underwater for more than 100 years? Nope. If it sank in the eighteenth century (1700s), it's been underwater for more than 100 years. It's UCH, and the provisions in passage B apply. Let's cross off (A).

Does this bring up artifacts that aren't underwater or haven't been underwater for more than 100 years? No. If this stuff sank in the nineteenth century (1800s), it's been underwater for more than 100 years. It's UCH, and the provisions in passage B apply. We can eliminate (B).

Does this bring up artifacts that aren't underwater or haven't been underwater for more than 100 years? Negative. If this stuff sank in ancient times, it's been underwater for more than 100 years. Therefore, we can conclude that it's UCH and passage B's provisions apply. We can toss (C) away.

Does this bring up artifacts that aren't underwater or haven't been underwater for more than 100 years? Yes! If this cargo sank in the 1970s, it hasn't been underwater for 100 years. It's not UCH, so passage B's provisions do not apply the cargo. We can select (D) and march along to the next question.

Does this bring up artifacts that aren't underwater or haven't been underwater for more than 100 years? Nope. If this stuff wound up in a river in prehistoric times, it's certainly been underwater for more than 100 years. Therefore, it's UCH and passage B's provisions apply. We can eliminate (E).

items.stemText: Which one of the following is most strongly implied by passage A?

options.optionContent: A government's property rights in a ship that sank several centuries ago are not forfeited merely by their not having salvaged the ship during the intervening time.
Governments have a legal obligation to ensure the archaeological integrity of efforts to salvage or explore old shipwrecks.

Gold coins salvaged from an old shipwreck should not be regarded as archaeologically significant cultural property if they can be used to fund the exploration and recovery of the shipwreck for scientific and cultural reasons.
If neither the original owner of a sunken ship nor any legitimate heirs of the owner still exist, the ownership of that ship devolves to the government under whose laws it was originally owned.
When there is no salvage agreement between the owner of a sunken ship and some other party, then freelance treasure hunters have a legal right to salvage the remains of that ship.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with passage A's main point or reflected in our notes for passage A? Well, our note for the second paragraph of passage A is, “Author on ocean exploration tech and legal agreement (allows governments to recover sunken objects, end unauthorized treasure hunting).” That suggests that governments retain a right to ships that sank long ago and haven't been recovered since. Therefore, it's worthwhile to check the passage to confirm that (A) is true. Reviewing the second paragraph, we'll notice that the author says that “governments often lack the money and skills to retrieve ... the government's treasure” (PA, P2, S2). The author also says that the agreement between the company and the British government could allow “nations to oversee the recovery of their lost fleets” (PA, P2, S3). The author says that the “treasure” and “fleets” are still the government's property. Of course, the relevant treasure and fleet have been underwater since 1694. So, governments can retain ownership of these vessels even though the vessels have been submerged for over 300 years. Therefore, it's fair to say that “a government's property rights” in a long sunken ship “are not forfeited merely by their not having salvaged the ship during the intervening time.” We can confidently select (A) and advance to the following question.

Is this consistent with passage A's main point or reflected in our notes for passage A? Well, our notes for the third paragraph mention “archaeological integrity,” so many test-takers may elect to check the passage to see whether (B) is supported. Reviewing the third paragraph, we'll see that the company that plans to recover the sunken treasure on the HMS Sussex—not the government—promises to maintain “archaeological integrity” (PA, P3, S3). So, there's nothing in the passage about governments being required to “ensure the archaeological integrity.” Moreover, if a promise to “ensure the archaeological integrity” has to be specified in an agreement, it doesn't seem like anyone is under a legal obligation to maintain archaeological integrity. We can cross off (B).

Is this consistent with passage A's main point or reflected in our notes for passage A? Nope. Our notes mention that the company promises to “only sell coins” recovered from the expedition. But that doesn't mean that coins are not “archaeologically significant cultural property.” Moreover, this answer choice makes a bold prescriptive claim. These kinds of claims are hard to support and are thus unlikely to appear in the correct answer to a Must Be True question. For these reasons, we can eliminate—or at least table—(C) without checking the passage. If we had to check the passage to eliminate (C), we'd see that the author claims that the company and British government agreed that “cultural items have greater archaeological value than coins” and that the coins will be sold for the company to recoup their costs (PA, P3, S5). Even if cultural property has a “greater archaeological value than coins,” that does not mean the coins lack archaeological value. It also doesn't mean that the fact that the coins can be sold removes the archaeological value from the coins, as (C) implies.

Is this consistent with passage A's main point or reflected in our notes for passage A? Nope, our notes don't mention the “original owner” of the ship or “legitimate heirs” of that owner. So, we can eliminate—or at least table—(D) without checking the passage. Besides, we wouldn't find any reference to the “original owner” or their heirs if we re-read all of passage A. The author says the British government owns the HMS Sussex (PA, P1, S1). However, the author doesn't suggest that that ownership resulted from the original owner losing ownership in probate or anything like that.

Is this consistent with passage A's main point or reflected in our notes for passage A? No. Our notes suggest that this kind of freelance treasure hunting is “unauthorized”—not legal. So, we can eliminate—or at least table—(E) without checking the passage. Besides, we wouldn't find any support for this claim if we re-read all of passage A. In fact, the author says, the agreement between the company and the British government “could end the days of freelance treasure hunting and allow nations to oversee the recovery of their lost fleets.” The author's claim these lost fleets belong to “nations” suggests that freelance treasure hunters do not have a legal right to salvage the remains of those fleets.
