When people long for connection to a global human community, they tend to engage in behavior that results in the acquisition of knowledge about other cultures but rarely produces genuine emotional connection to those cultures.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This expresses the same idea as the first sentence in the argument. This sentence just provides background information about why some people use the internet. The conclusion discusses why these people will probably not establish a connection with the international human community online.

This expresses the same idea as the second sentence in the argument. This sentence just provides background information about how some people use the internet. The conclusion discusses why these people will probably not establish a connection with the international human community online.

This mischaracterizes the last sentence in the passage. That sentence says that people use the internet primarily for acquiring information rather than developing feelings of interconnectedness. “Rather than” means these people aren't using the internet to develop feelings of interconnectedness — not even as a “secondary[]” purpose. Plus, the last sentence is a premise to the argument's main conclusion, anyway. The conclusion argues these people will probably not develop feelings of interconnectedness with the international human community.
This expresses the same idea as the main conclusion we identified, so we can select it and advance to the following question.

This answer choice combines information from every claim other than the main conclusion of the argument. (It's arguably a bit stronger than the claims from the argument since this says people “tend” to engage in certain behaviors while the argument says people “often” engage in these behaviors.) The main conclusion takes this information and concludes that people who long for connection to a global human community probably won't find that connection on the internet.

items.stimulusText: Democratic societies in which there is widespread discontent more often blame their politicians than they do other powerful figures who are at least as responsible for those societies' woes. This is not primarily because politicians are more familiar to people than are other powerful figures; rather it is because people in democratic societies feel that they have more power over politicians than they have over other powerful figures.
items.stemText: The case described above best illustrates which one of the following generalizations?

options.optionContent: Often the people who have the most power in a society are not the people who are generally perceived by the public as having the most power.
People tend to ascribe more power to a person with whom they are familiar than to one with whom they are unfamiliar.
To the extent that a person is well known to the public, that person is more likely to be blamed for the woes of society.
Publicly known people are usually not held sufficiently responsible for the problems they cause.
People are more inclined to blame a publicly known person if that person is someone over whom they feel they have power.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage doesn't discuss which figures people view as “having the most power.” It discusses which powerful figures people blame for society's problems and explains why people blame them.
The passage doesn't identify which figures people “ascribe more power to.” The passage identifies which powerful figures people blame for society's problems and explains why people blame them.

The passage explicitly rules out this explanation. The passage says that people don't blame politicians for society's ills because politicians are more well-known than other responsible parties. The passage says that people blame politicians because people feel like they have more sway over politicians.

The passage doesn't make any evaluative claims that would support a generalization like this one. The author doesn't say or imply that politicians or other responsible figures should be held more responsible for society's problems. Instead, the author identifies which powerful figures people blame for society's problems and explains why people blame them.

We anticipated that the correct answer would say something like, “People sometimes blame those over whom they feel like they have more power or control, even when there are other equally blameworthy parties.” This answer choice matches that idea, as it states that people are more likely to blame the figures that they believe they have power over. This answer choice would certainly be better if it was stated in weaker, easier-to-support language. However, since this is the only answer choice related to the phenomenon and explanation in the passage, we'll put aside any reservations and select this option.

items.stimulusText: The mu mesons generated by cosmic rays just outside Earth's atmosphere travel to Earth at speeds approaching the speed of light. Mu mesons generated in the laboratory, however, are nearly at rest. Mu mesons generated in the laboratory typically decay in much less time than it takes for a mu meson to travel from just outside Earth's atmosphere to our detection apparatus on Earth. If mu mesons traveling through the atmosphere at speeds approaching the speed of light typically decay as fast as they do in the laboratory, then we should detect only about one one-hundredth of the number we actually do detect. Apparently, mu mesons moving at speeds near the speed of light _______.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most logically completes the argument?

options.optionContent: take longer to reach Earth than was supposed
are quite difficult to detect with available equipment
are much less numerous than previously thought
decay more slowly than mu mesons almost at rest
are probably not generated by cosmic rays

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We know that the correct answer should say that mu mesons traveling at the speed of light do not decay as quickly as mu mesons in a lab. This answer choice doesn't say that, so it can be a quick elimination. If we didn't make that anticipation, we could conclude that this isn't an appropriate way to complete the argument. Other than telling us that mu mesons travel at nearly the speed of light, the passage doesn't provide any information on how long it takes them to reach Earth. And just because mu mesons in a laboratory are stationary does not mean that mu mesons that travel to Earth are slower than we once thought.

We know that the correct answer should say that mu mesons traveling at the speed of light do not decay as quickly as mu mesons in a lab. This answer choice doesn't say that, so we can cross it off without a second thought. Even if we didn't make that anticipation, we could conclude that this isn't an appropriate way to complete the argument. The passage doesn't suggest that mu mesons are difficult to detect with our current equipment. The penultimate sentence says that we do detect quite a few mu mesons — 100 times more than we would if they decayed as quickly as lab mu mesons, anyway — so we don't have any reason to think our equipment makes it difficult to detect mu mesons.

We know that the correct answer should say that mu mesons traveling at the speed of light do not decay as quickly as mu mesons in a lab. This answer choice doesn't say that, so we can eliminate it unhesitatingly. Even if we didn't make that anticipation, we could conclude that this isn't an appropriate way to complete the argument. The penultimate sentence says that we do detect quite a few mu mesons — 100 times more than we would if they decayed as quickly as lab mu mesons. And we don't know whether we previously thought we'd detect even more mu mesons — the passage doesn't say anything about those past beliefs.

We know that the correct answer should say that mu mesons traveling at the speed of light do not decay as quickly as mu mesons in a lab. This answer choice says that mu mesons traveling at the speed of light decay more slowly than mu mesons almost at rest. This isn't exactly what we anticipated, but it's equally supported. The passage says that mu mesons in a laboratory are “nearly at rest.” Since this answer choice matches our anticipation, we can select it and advance to the following question.

We know that the correct answer should say that mu mesons traveling at the speed of light do not decay as quickly as mu mesons in a lab. This answer choice doesn't say that, so we can immediately toss it away. Even if we didn't make that anticipation, we could conclude that this isn't an appropriate way to complete the argument. The passage gives us no reason to suppose that cosmic rays don't generate mu mesons. In fact, we're told that the mu mesons that are generated by cosmic rays travel nearly at the speed of light, and the beginning of the conclusion specifies that we're talking about those mu mesons! So, adding (E) to the blank space would make a self-contradictory statement.

items.stimulusText: Buyer: As a buyer for a large chain of department stores, I will buy a garment only if it is fashionable and not too expensive for our clientele. The evening dress from the fall collection by Peruka is certainly fashionable, but it is far too expensive for our clientele. Therefore, I will not buy that dress.
items.stemText: The pattern of reasoning in which one of the following arguments most closely resembles the pattern of reasoning in the buyer's argument?

options.optionContent: A snowflake will melt if it is in a warm place and not protected by insulation. This snowflake is in a warm place, but it is protected by insulation. Therefore, this snowflake will not melt.

A stuffed animal, in order to pass inspection, must be free of sharp edges and completely sealed. This stuffed hippo is free of sharp edges, but it is not completely sealed. Therefore, this hippo will not pass inspection.
A sidewalk is accessible if its edges are fully graded and if it has no sizable bumps. This sidewalk's edges are fully graded, and it has no sizable bumps. Therefore, this sidewalk is accessible.

A poetic translation is accurate only if it adequately expresses the meaning of the original poem and gives an idea of the meter. This translation adequately expresses the meaning of the original and gives an idea of the meter. Therefore, this translation is accurate.

An assembly may call a meeting of the executive board only if the assembly meets quorum requirements and the motion passes by two-thirds. This assembly meets quorum requirements, so unless the motion does not pass by two-thirds, this assembly may call a meeting of the executive board.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice's conclusion resembles the passage's conclusion that “I will not buy the dress.” However, its premises do not resemble the passage's premises. Remember, we're looking for an “if-then” premise that has an “and” on the “then” side. This answer choice's “if-then” premise has an “and” on the “if” side, which is enough to eliminate (A). If we did look further into this entire answer choice, we'd see that it does not resemble the passage's structure: Unlike the passage, this is not a valid argument.

This answer choice's conclusion resembles the passage's conclusion that “I will not buy the dress.” At a glance, its premises resemble the passage's premises, too. Like the passage, this answer choice features an “if-then” premise with an “and” on the “then” side and a factual premise. Since this answer choice's identifiable characteristics match the passage's, we can symbolize this entire answer choice to confirm that it also parallels the passage's structure: P: if Pass Inspection, then NOT Sharp Edges and Sealed  (if Sharp Edges or NOT Sealed, then NOT Pass Inspection) P: NOT Sharp Edges and NOT Sealed Conclusion: NOT Pass Inspection Like the passage, this is a valid argument. It also mirrors the way the passage draws a valid conclusion. Like the passage, this answer choice applies the flipside of the “if-then” statement. It concedes that an item lacks one of the flipside's “if” conditions (“NOT Sharp Edges”). But the answer choice shows that the item also has one of the flipside's “if” conditions (“NOT Sealed”), which is sufficient to conclude that the item has the flipside's “then” condition (“NOT Pass Inspection”). This mirrors the passage's structure, so we can select (B).

This answer choice's conclusion doesn't quite resemble the passage's conclusion that “I will not buy the dress.” Instead of a “not” statement like the passage, this answer choice's conclusion is a positive statement. Moreover, its premises do not resemble the passage's premise. Remember, we're looking for an “if-then” premise that has an “and” on the “then” side. This answer choice's “if-then” premise has an “and” on the “if” side, which is enough to eliminate (C).

This answer choice's conclusion doesn't quite resemble the passage's conclusion that “I will not buy the dress.” Instead of a “not” statement like the passage, this answer choice's conclusion is positive. That said, this difference probably isn't enough to guarantee that (D) is incorrect. Plus, (D)'s premises resemble the passage's, as (D) features an “if-then” premise that has an “and” on the “then” side. Moreover, unlike the passage, this is not a valid argument.

This answer choice's conclusion doesn't quite resemble the passage's conclusion that “I will not buy the dress.” This conclusion is an “if-then” statement. Plus, this answer choice's conclusion is not expressed with the same strength. Rather than the bold, certain statement in the passage, this answer choice presents a softer “may” statement. This is enough reason to eliminate (E).

items.stimulusText: Psychologists report that children in nine-month schools typically forget a significant amount of schooling during summer breaks. So, some educators have proposed a twelve-month schedule in which there are three month-long breaks spread throughout the year. We should conclude, on the basis of the psychologists' research, that the twelve-month schedule is to be preferred insofar as academic learning is concerned, since this schedule will insure that students will not forget their schooling during their breaks.
items.stemText: The reasoning above is most vulnerable to the criticism that it

options.optionContent: relies on an unsubstantiated assumption about the comparative worth of academic and nonacademic learning experiences
draws on an arbitrary distinction between two groups
takes for granted, in comparing two situations, that a certain undesirable result is correlated with only one of them
fails to show that the data on which the psychologists' conclusions were based was adequately representative of children in the population as a whole
claims to accept a view, but then rejects it in the course of argument

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author doesn't rely on any assumptions about “nonacademic learning experiences” because the author doesn't make any claims about “nonacademic learning experiences.” Notice how the conclusion is only about “academic learning”? That shows that the author's argument only cares about academic learning experiences and doesn't rely on any assumptions that compare academic and nonacademic learning.

The author doesn't draw an “arbitrary distinction between two groups.” What would those two groups even be? Students on a nine-month school schedule and students on a twelve-month school schedule? Well, the distinction between those two groups is hardly arbitrary! The students are on different schedules that could plausibly affect their ability to learn and retain information! It's also worth pointing out that the twelve-month schedule is entirely hypothetical as far as this argument is concerned. The author doesn't cite any students about schools that use such a schedule. So, it's a stretch to refer to students on a twelve-month schedule as an actual “group.”

When we see “takes for granted” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the author definitely believes that “a certain undesirable result” is only associated with one of two situations. The author thinks that students forgetting what they learned (the undesirable result) is only associated with the nine-month school schedule, not the twelve-month school schedule (so, only one of two situations). The author reveals this belief when they assert that the twelve-month schedule will “ensure that students will not forget their schooling during their breaks.” This assumption isn't necessarily warranted. The psychological research the author relies on only shows that students forget what they learned during three-month breaks. It doesn't assert students don't forget what they learned during month-long breaks. Additionally, this unwarranted assumption strengthens the author's argument. If students only forget what they learn in the nine-month school schedule — and not in the twelve-month school schedule — then we have a compelling reason to believe that the twelve-month schedule is better at promoting academic learning. Since the author definitely relies on this unwarranted assumption to make their conclusion, this is a flaw in the author's argument. We can select (C) and advance to the following question.

This certainly sounds like it could be a flaw in an argument, which is probably why many test-takers select this answer choice. However, the psychologists' report doesn't make a conclusion about “children in the population as a whole.” The psychologists' report only concludes that children in nine-month schools forget much of what they learn during summer breaks. So, the psychologists' conclusion only addresses children in nine-month schools — not all students. Therefore, the psychologists' data need only to represent all children in nine-month schools, not all children in the population.

The author doesn't reject any views in this argument. The author agrees with the psychologists' view that children in nine-month schools forget a lot of what they learn during summer breaks. The author also agrees with the educators who propose a twelve-month schedule.

items.stimulusText: The Industrial Revolution decreased the value that society conferred on physical labor because it enabled unskilled workers to quickly produce goods that formerly took skilled craftspeople long periods of time to produce. Clearly, our most important intellectual skills will similarly be devalued by electronic data-processing technology. Computations that once took skilled mathematicians a long time to perform can now be quickly performed by moderately well-trained high school students using computers.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?

options.optionContent: Much industrial machinery is now designed and built with the aid of computers.
Before electronic data-processing technology, improvements in mathematical techniques reduced the amount of time it took to perform computations.
On average, skilled mathematicians tend to be much younger when they are in their most productive years than are skilled craftspeople.
The intellectual skills that society values most highly are not computational ones.
Electronic data-processing technology has enabled people to perform some tasks that previously could not be performed at all.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: If we anticipated that the correct answer should bring up why these kinds of computations are not among this era's most important intellectual skills, we can eliminate — or at least table — this answer choice without thinking about it too deeply. It doesn't discuss the conclusion's new idea (the era's “most important intellectual skills”), so it doesn't impact the flaw we identified in the argument. So, we shouldn't dwell on this answer choice as we take our first pass through the answer choices. Besides, this answer choice is irrelevant to the author’s argument. It doesn’t show that data-processing technology may not devalue our most important intellectual skills, even if they help people make quick computations. In fact, the author's conclusion doesn't have anything to do with “industrial machinery”! The discussion of the machinery produced during the Industrial Revolution was simply part of an analogy to show how technology can devalue certain skills. The author's conclusion doesn't suggest that computers will affect industrial machinery in any way.

If we anticipated that the correct answer should bring up why these kinds of computations are not among this era's most important intellectual skills, we can eliminate — or at least table — this answer choice without thinking about it too deeply. It doesn't discuss the conclusion's new idea (the era's “most important intellectual skills”), so it doesn't impact the flaw we identified in the argument. So, we shouldn't dwell on this answer choice as we take our first pass through the answer choices. Besides, this answer choice is irrelevant to the author’s argument. Even if mathematical techniques reduce the time it takes to perform computations, we know that electronic data-processing technology will reduce the time even more. Moreover, we also know that this tech will reduce the expertise needed to perform these computations. Reducing the time and expertise needed to perform these computations could lead to a devaluation of that computational skill. So, this answer choice doesn't show that data-processing technology may not devalue our most important intellectual skills.

If we anticipated that the correct answer should bring up why these kinds of computations are not among this era's most important intellectual skills, we can eliminate — or at least table — this answer choice without thinking about it too deeply. It doesn't discuss the conclusion's new idea (the era's “most important intellectual skills”), so it doesn't impact the flaw we identified in the argument. So, we shouldn't dwell on this answer choice as we take our first pass through the answer choices. Besides, this answer choice is irrelevant to the author’s argument. It doesn't matter if skilled mathematicians tend to be younger than the pre-Industrial-Revolution “skilled craftspeople.” Electronic data-processing technology can devalue these mathematicians' computational skills, regardless of their age!

This definitely weakens the author’s argument. It shows that the kinds of mathematical computations electronic data-processing tech can make easier are not among our era's most important intellectual skills. So, even if such technology makes these computations easier, the technology may not devalue our most important intellectual skills. If such technology cannot reduce the time or expertise required to perform the most valued skills, we have compelling reasons to doubt this author's conclusion.

If we anticipated that the correct answer should bring up why these kinds of computations are not among this era's most important intellectual skills, we can eliminate — or at least table — this answer choice without thinking about it too deeply. It doesn't discuss the conclusion's new idea (the era's “most important intellectual skills”), so it doesn't impact the flaw we identified in the argument. So, we shouldn't dwell on this answer choice as we take our first pass through the answer choices. Besides, this answer choice doesn't weaken the author’s argument. We have no idea if the tasks that “previously could not be performed at all” rely on “our most important intellectual skills.” If they do rely on such skills, then this answer choice strengthens the author's argument — it provides another example of why technology may devalue certain skills. If they don't, then this answer choice is irrelevant to the argument.

items.stimulusText: Wounds become infected because the break in the skin allows bacteria to enter. Infection slows healing. Often bacteria-killing ointment is applied to wounds after they have been cleaned, but a study at a Nigerian hospital found that cleaned wounds that were treated with honey—which contains significant quantities of bacteria—healed faster, on average, than both cleaned wounds treated with antibiotic ointment and wounds cleaned but not otherwise treated.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy between the results of the study and the stated facts about wounds, bacteria, infection, and healing?

options.optionContent: Wounds that have simply been cleaned with soap and water and not otherwise treated heal faster than wounds that have been cleaned and then treated with antibiotic ointment.

The bacteria found in honey are present in much lower concentrations than the concentrations of bacteria typically present in infected wounds, and applying antibiotic ointment to a wound rarely if ever kills all of the bacteria infecting the wound.
Honey has properties that inhibit the growth of bacteria in wounds, including the bacteria the honey contains, and antibiotic ointments damage sensitive wound tissue, which slows healing.
The high concentration of sugar in honey inhibits the growth of bacteria in wounds, including the bacteria contained in the honey itself.
The antibiotic ointment used in the study damages sensitive tissue in wounds, which slows healing, but honey does not have this effect if the wound has been cleaned.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is irrelevant to the paradox. We're not trying to explain why wounds cleaned but not treated heal faster than wounds cleaned and treated with antibiotic ointment. We're trying to explain why wounds treated with honey heal faster than wounds cleaned but not treated and wounds cleaned and treated with antibiotic ointment. This answer choice doesn't suggest why honey would heal faster than either method described, so we can cross off (A).

This doesn't resolve the paradox. This just says the amount of bacteria in honey is low and that applying antibiotic ointment doesn't kill all the bacteria in a wound. Even with this information, honey still adds bacteria to the wound, while the antibiotic ointment reduces the bacteria in the wound. If we know that bacteria slows the healing process, it would still seem strange that honey heals wounds faster than ointment.

This shows how honey helps wounds heal faster, even if that honey contains bacteria that could infect the wound and slow the healing process. As expected, this answer choice describes a benefit of honey that helps speed up the healing process. What's more, it further tips the scales in favor of honey by showing the downside of antibiotic ointments. If we know that honey slows the growth of bacteria while antibiotic ointments damage wound tissue and slow healing, it makes sense that wounds treated with honey heal faster than wounds treated with antibiotic ointments and wounds not treated with anything. Honey helps remove bacteria, while the other two methods either further damage the wound or have no effect on the bacteria in the wound. Because this answer choice resolves this paradox exactly as we expected, we'd be justified in selecting (C) and giving the remaining answer choices an at-most cursory reading.

This answer choice is very tempting! Like (C), this answer choice describes why the bacteria in honey may not be as harmful as we expected. However, unlike (C), this answer choice does not explain how honey can heal wounds faster than antibiotic ointment. Honey might inhibit the growth of bacteria, but it still adds bacteria to the wound. If antibiotic ointment subtracts the bacteria from the wound, we'd still expect antibiotic ointment to heal the wound faster. While (D) isn't a bad answer choice in a vacuum, it resolves the paradox much less than (C).

This is another tempting answer choice! It describes why antibiotic ointment can slow the healing process. However, unlike (C), this answer choice does not definitely explain why honey can heal wounds faster than antibiotic ointment. Even if antibiotic ointment damages tissue and slows healing, it's still subtracting the amount of bacteria in a wound. Because honey adds bacteria to the wound, we'd still expect antibiotic ointment to heal wounds about as fast or faster than honey. While (E) isn't a bad answer choice in a vacuum, it resolves the paradox much less than (C).

items.stimulusText: Art student: Great works of art evoke passionate responses in those who view them. Thus, since it is well known in art circles that the provocative work of abstract painter Ezekiel Reilly elicits intensely emotional responses in those who view them, his art is great.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the argument's reasoning?

options.optionContent: One of the premises used to support the argument's conclusion assumes the truth of that conclusion.
The argument treats a condition that is necessary for having a certain quality as if it must also be sufficient for having that quality.
The argument misapplies a general claim about the members of a class to an atypical instance of that class.
The argument contains a generalization derived from an insufficient number of instances.
The argument draws a conclusion expressing a value judgment from premises that do not involve statements about values.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the passage's “converse” flaw or an “illegal reversal.” So, we can cross off (A) without thinking about it too deeply. Besides, this answer choice refers to “circular reasoning.” Circular reasoning occurs when the conclusion merely restates a premise. Arguments that rely on circular reasoning typically have this pattern on the LSAT: “X is true. We know this because, even when X doesn't appear to be true, X still must be true because X is always true.” The art student's argument doesn't rely on circular reasoning. The art student's premises are an “if-then” statement and a factual premise about the passionate responses provoked by a particular artist, and the conclusion asserts that the artist's work must be great. Therefore, the art student's conclusion is not a mere restatement of their premise.

This answer choice matches our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the passage's “converse” flaw or an “illegal reversal.” The art student indeed treats a condition necessary for having a certain quality (provoking a passionate response is necessary for an artwork's greatness) as if the condition must be sufficient for having that quality. We know the art student thinks provoking a passionate response is sufficient to conclude that an artwork is great because the art student argues that the passionate response provoked by Reilly's work is enough evidence to conclude that Reilly's work must be great. However, Reilly's work may not be great, even if it produces a passionate response. Because this answer choice closely matches our anticipated flaw, we can select (B) and give the remaining answer choices a quick once-over.

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the passage's “converse” flaw or an “illegal reversal.” So, we can cross off (C) without giving it too much consideration. Besides, this answer choice misdescribes the flaw in the art student's argument. The art student's general claim applies to all “great works of art.” There's nothing in the argument that suggests Reilly's work may be “an atypical instance” of a great work of art. In fact, the issue is that we don't know whether Reilly's work is a great work of art. Rather than an atypical instance of this class, Reilly's work may not belong to the class in the first place.

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the passage's “converse” flaw or an “illegal reversal.” So, we can cross off (D) without spending too much time thinking about it. Besides, this answer choice misdescribes the art student's conclusion. Their conclusion does not derive a “generalization” about artists. The conclusion is just about one artist! And even if we interpret the “generalization” to refer to all of Reilly's artworks,  the art student's conclusion does not base this generalization on “an insufficient number of instances.” The art student's premise describes all of Reilly's “provocative work.”

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the passage's “converse” flaw or an “illegal reversal.” So, we can cross off (E) without hesitating. Besides, this answer choice misdescribes the flaw in the art student's argument. Although the art student's conclusion expresses a value judgment (that Reilly's art is “great”), the art student's premises involve “statements about values.” The “if-then” statement describes “[g]reat works of art.” And its flipside (“if an artwork does not evoke passionate responses, then it is not great”) would allow the art student to conclude that a specific work of art is not great, which would be a justifiable conclusion that expresses a value judgment.

items.stimulusText: In northern Europe, archaeologists have discovered 400,000-year-old sharpened wooden poles alongside flint cutting implements and the remains of horses. Since it is normally assumed that Homo sapiens did not inhabit Europe prior to 200,000 years ago, this discovery effectively disproves the widespread belief that the humanlike precursors of Homo sapiens were entirely gatherers and scavengers and did not hunt.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would add the most support to the argument?

options.optionContent: Sharpened wooden poles were not used by humanlike precursors of Homo sapiens for self-defense or to cut or transport scavenged carcasses.
Humanlike inhabitants of northern Europe are known to have used stones and wooden sticks as tools more than 400,000 years ago.
Homo sapiens evolved from humanlike precursors at least 200,000 years earlier than is normally assumed.
The humanlike precursors of Homo sapiens developed widely divergent patterns of behavior in the very different ecosystems they inhabited.
Prehistoric Homo sapiens who adopted hunting as a means of food acquisition did not abandon scavenging and gathering.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Right off the bat, we find an answer choice that shows that humans' predecessors used these wooden tools for hunting and not gathering or scavenging. As we anticipated, this answer choice shows that the poles were not used for a purpose other than hunting. If the poles were not used by the precursors to cut or transport scavenged carcasses, it is a little more probable that the poles were used to hunt live animals. This information certainly doesn't prove that the poles were used for hunting, but it does make that conclusion a little more likely. And on a Strengthen question, that's all the correct answer needs to do. Since this answer choice conforms to our anticipation, we can justifiably select it and, at most, quickly glance at the remaining options.

This answer choice has no effect on the argument. Even if humans' predecessors used stones and wooden tools more than 400,000 years ago, that doesn't mean they used stones or wooden tools to hunt animals. These tools could have been used for gathering, scavenging, or other purposes. Therefore, (B) doesn't show that humans' predecessors used the recently discovered wooden poles for hunting.

This answer choice has no effect on the argument. From this information, we can validly conclude that the human species is at least 400,000 years old, as we know humans were in Europe 200,000 years ago. This answer choice wants us to use that information to conclude that humans occupied Europe much earlier than we assumed — perhaps humans were even in Europe 400,000 years ago. There are a few problems with this line of reasoning, however. First, it can't definitively use this information to conclude that humans occupied Europe 400,000 years ago. Humans could have evolved from their predecessors somewhere other than Europe. So, even if the human species is 400,000 years old, it may have taken humans a long time to migrate to Europe. Second, even if humans did occupy Europe 400,000 years ago, this would only weaken the argument. In that case, the wooden poles could belong to humans, not humans' predecessors.

This answer choice has no effect on the argument. Even if humans' predecessors' behavior varied based on their ecosystem, that doesn't show that predecessors settled in Europe must have hunted. Their behavior could have varied in all sorts of ways. All of the predecessors could have been exclusively gatherers and scavengers, but their sleep, communication, mating, and child-rearing practices could have varied dramatically based on their ecosystem.

This answer choice has no effect on the argument. It doesn't show that humans' predecessors used the wooden poles for hunting because it doesn't tell us anything about humans' predecessors. This answer choice is about humans, so it's irrelevant to the argument.

items.stimulusText: Politician: Our public libraries are open only on weekdays and generally at times when most children are at school and most adults at work. Hence, most taxpayers and their families have few opportunities to use public libraries. Therefore, no new taxes supporting the library system should be approved unless the library hours are changed to better suit taxpayers and their families.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, would most help to justify the politician's reasoning?

options.optionContent: Libraries and other public facilities that serve an educational purpose should be made as convenient as possible for taxpayers and their families to use.
If use of a public facility is made more convenient for taxpayers and their families, then new taxes supporting that facility should be approved.
Taxpayers who have plenty of opportunities to use a public facility should have to pay taxes to support that facility.
The best way to increase usage of public libraries is to change the library hours for the convenience of most people.
A new tax supporting a public facility should be approved only when most taxpayers have ample opportunities to use that facility.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This principle doesn't quite resemble “if Premises, then Conclusion.” While it's reasonable to say that public libraries “serve an educational” purpose, that's not what the politician's premise says. Further, the politician's conclusion doesn't assert that public libraries should be made more convenient for taxpayers and their families. The politician concludes that the government shouldn't approve new taxes to support public libraries. So, this principle doesn't bridge the gap between the politician's premises and conclusion.

This principle doesn't resemble “if Premises, then Conclusion.” In fact, the “then” part of this principle says that we should support new taxes for a public facility. To justify the politician's argument, a principle would need to feature a “then” condition that says we should not support new taxes for a public facility, as the politician concludes that the government should not approve new taxes to support public libraries. (A principle with an “if” condition that says we should support new taxes for a public facility would also work, as we could take the flipside.) The inverse of this principle would strengthen the politician's argument (“If the use of a public facility is not made more convenient for taxpayers and their families, then new taxes supporting that facility should not be approved”). However, this answer choice, as it is currently written, does not support the politician's argument.

This principle doesn't resemble “if Premises, then Conclusion.” In fact, the “then” part of this principle says that we should pay new taxes for a public facility. To justify the politician's argument, a principle would need to feature a “then” condition that says we should not support new taxes for a public facility, as the politician concludes that the government should not support new taxes to support public libraries. (A principle with an “if” condition that says we should support new taxes for a public facility would also work, as we could take the flipside.) So, this principle's “then” condition is positive when it should be negative. It also is about paying new taxes, not supporting new taxes. Therefore, this principle does not strengthen the politician's argument.

This principle doesn't resemble “if Premises, then Conclusion.” This principle focuses on the best way to increase how many people use public libraries. That wasn't the politician's focus. Instead, the politician's conclusion asserted that the government should not approve new taxes for public libraries. So, this principle will not bridge the gap between the politician's premises and conclusion.

Finally, a principle that resembles “if Premises, then Conclusion.” To symbolize this principle, we'll use the “then” keyword “only.” That will give us, “if Should approve new taxes supporting public facility, then Most taxpayers have an opportunity to use the facility.” Let's take the flipside of this principle. We'll get, “If most taxpayers do not have ample opportunities to use a public facility, then we should not approve new taxes that support that facility.” This closely resembles our anticipation: “If most taxpayers and their families have limited opportunities to use a resource, then the government should not approve new taxes that support that resource.” This principle will bridge the gap between the politician's premise and conclusion. It connects the politician's premise — which asserts that the libraries' hours do not give most taxpayers and their families many opportunities to use the libraries — to their conclusion — which asserts that the government should not approve new taxes supporting public libraries. Therefore, we can confidently select (E).

items.stimulusText: The introduction of mass production techniques in modern industrial economies allowed the owners of industries to lower prices because they could employ fewer workers, many of whom required little training. The lower prices allowed workers to buy goods that they previously would not have been able to afford. But since jobs for workers with little training are more vulnerable to elimination than those for more highly trained workers, _______.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most logically completes the argument?

options.optionContent: highly trained workers have more purchasing power in modern industrial economies than workers who are less trained
the introduction of mass production techniques has decreased benefits for workers as it has increased the profits for owners of industries
even the highest paid employees in modern industrial economies are never able to achieve job security
a source of increased purchasing power for workers in modern industrial economies also undermines their job security
the percentage of workers who can afford to purchase goods produced by modern industrial techniques is shrinking

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice makes “highly trained workers” the subject of the conclusion. Although the passage concedes that they have more job security than workers with less training, the passage focuses on mass production techniques in modern industrial economies and their effect on workers with little training. Making “highly trained workers” the subject of the conclusion would represent a jarring shift in the argument's focus. It's probably true that highly trained workers have more purchasing power than less skilled workers (since highly skilled workers have more job security and, therefore, more dependable income and more access to credit). However, this answer choice still doesn't work as the argument's conclusion since the argument only uses highly trained workers to make a point about workers with little training.

This answer choice only focuses on mass production techniques' downsides—that they “decrease benefits for workers.” That's not accurate, as the premise brings up a benefit—workers increased ability to purchase goods. Moreover, this answer choice says that mass production techniques increase owners' profits. That's not supported by the premises. We know that owners are selling goods at a lower price, which may reduce their overall profits.

This answer choice brings up the “highest paid employees [sic],” whom the passage never discusses. We know that workers with little training have low job security. But perhaps the highest-paid employees are highly skilled or otherwise needed to run modern industries. Therefore, this doesn't work as the argument's conclusion.

This answer choice matches our anticipation. As we anticipated, this answer choice matches the ambivalence the passage conveys about mass production techniques in modern industrial economies. And the passage supports both inferences about mass production techniques. It's true that these techniques “increase purchasing power for workers,” as workers can “buy goods that they previously would not have been able to afford.” It's also true that these techniques “undermine[ workers'] job security,” as the techniques make “workers with little training ... more vulnerable to elimination.” Since this answer choice is a conclusion we can validly draw from the premises and conforms to the point the premises appear to make, it functions as an appropriate conclusion to this argument.

This answer choice is too bold. We know that modern industrial economies reduce the job security of workers with little training. But we don't know how many workers lose their jobs. Given that the lower price of goods allows more “workers to buy goods that they previously would not have been able to afford,” all of these workers would need to be laid off to offset this increase and result in a net reduction of the percentage of workers who can afford to purchase goods.

items.stimulusText: Child psychologist: Psychologists have found that most children under the age of six are egocentric and selfish in their attitudes toward animals. Ordinarily, it is only between the ages of six and nine that children begin to understand that animals are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs. Hence, most children should not have pets until they are at least six years old.
items.stemText: The child psychologist's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?

options.optionContent: Most children who are egocentric and selfish in their attitudes towards animals rely on others to take care of a pet.
Children who are old enough to understand that animals are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs should be allowed to have pets.
Most children who are egocentric and selfish in their attitudes towards animals do not have pets.
Most children are egocentric and selfish in their attitudes towards their pets and do not understand that their pets are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs.
The only children who should have pets are those who understand that their pets are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't bring up the new idea from the conclusion—that children “should not have pets.” Instead, it discusses who takes care of pets for children. This answer choice doesn't definitively establish that certain children should not have pets, so it doesn't make the conclusion valid.

This doesn't connect the psychologist's premise to their conclusion (“If a child doesn't understand that animals are independent creatures with feelings and needs, then that child should not have pets”). Instead, if we take the flipside of this answer choice, we'll see that it connects the psychologist's conclusion to their premise (“If a child should not be allowed to have pets, then the child is not old enough to understand that animals are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs”). For this reason, (B) is incorrect.

Like (A), this doesn't even bring up the new idea from the conclusion—that children “should not have pets.” Instead, it discusses whether children do have pets. Whether children have pets is irrelevant to this psychologist's prescriptive conclusion that suggests that certain children are not old enough to have pets. Because this answer choice doesn't definitively establish that certain children should not have pets, it doesn't make the conclusion valid.

This doesn't bring up the new idea in the conclusion—that children “should not have pets.” Instead of connecting the premises to the conclusion, this answer choice just connects the two premises. Therefore, this answer choice doesn't definitively establish that certain children should not have pets, and it doesn't make the conclusion valid.

This connects the psychologist's premise to their conclusion. We may need to symbolize this answer choice and take its flipside to see that it bridges this gap. To do so, we can recall that the phrase “the only” comes before “if” conditions. That gives us this: If Child should have a pet, then Child understands that pets are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs. Once we take the flipside of this, we'll get: if Child does NOT understand that pets are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs, then Child should NOT have a pet. If we add this premise to the psychologist's argument, it becomes valid. Suppose that (E) is true. In that case, we know that most children under six don't understand that pets are independent creatures with their own feelings and needs. Therefore, most children should not have pets until they're at least six years old. So, this answer choice makes the psychologist's argument valid. We can select it and advance to the following question.

items.stimulusText: The average tax refund received by taxpayers who use tax preparation services is about 50 percent higher than the average refund received by those who do not. So if you want a large refund, you should use a tax preparation service.
items.stemText: Which one of the following arguments exhibits flawed reasoning most similar to the flawed reasoning exhibited by the argument above?

options.optionContent: People who invest heavily in the stock market generally have higher incomes than people who do not; so if you want to have a high income, you should invest heavily in the stock market.

Establishing an in-house print shop usually enables companies to produce their publications more efficiently. So if your company produces publications, then it should establish an in-house print shop.

Quitting smoking will lower your life insurance premium and will also decrease your risk of lung cancer. So if you want to lower your life insurance premium, you should try to reduce your risk of lung cancer.
People with larger-than-average estates to manage usually find it helpful to have their own lawyers; so if you have a larger-than-average estate to manage, you should get your own lawyer.

In deciding who they will call, telemarketers target people who have purchased from telemarketers in the past. So if you do not want to receive calls from telemarketers, you should not purchase anything from them.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conclusion sounds a lot like the passage's conclusion! It matches, “if you want a high A, use B,” with “income” standing in for “A” (rather than “tax refund”) and “invest heavily in the stock market” standing in for “B” (rather than “use a tax preparation service”). This matches the passage's conclusion, so we should examine the premises to see if they also match. The premises sound a lot like “A is, on average, higher for those who use B than for those who don't use B,” too. In this answer choice, we learn that those who invest heavily in the stock market (i.e., “use B”) have, on average, higher incomes (i.e., higher “As”) than those who do not invest (i.e., “do not use B”). So, this argument's premises and conclusion match the passage's. And, of course, this is the same causation flaw as the one committed in the passage. Just because people who invest in the stock market have higher incomes doesn't mean that investing causes their incomes to be higher. There could be another explanation for their higher incomes—people who invest could be more money-motivated than those who do not, so they pursue jobs with higher salaries. This parallels the causation flaw in the passage, so we can select (A) and advance to the following question.

This conclusion doesn't quite sound like the passage's conclusion. Rather than saying, “if you want a high A, use B,” it says, “if you do A, use B.” So, rather than setting a goal that “B” can accomplish, this answer choice specifies a group to which “B” applies. So, this answer choice's conclusion doesn't imply a cause-and-effect relationship, unlike the passage. This is enough reason to eliminate (B) without reviewing the premises. If we reviewed the rest of the argument, we'd also see that it doesn't parallel the passage's flaw. Rather than comparing two groups, this answer choice's premise shows that using one thing usually causes something to occur (using an in-house print shop usually causes companies to produce publications more efficiently). Because this answer choice puts the cause-and-effect relationship in the premise, it doesn't commit the same causation flaw as the passage.

This conclusion sounds a bit like the passage's conclusion, as long as we modify “high A” to “low A.” So, it resembles, “if you want a low A, use B,” with “life insurance premium” standing in for “A” (rather than “tax refund”) and “reduce risk of lung cancer” standing in for “B” (rather than “use a tax preparation service”). Since this matches the passage's conclusion, we should examine the premises to see if they also match. Once we review the rest of the argument, we'll see that it doesn't parallel the passage's flaw. Rather than comparing two groups, this answer choice's premise shows that using one thing usually causes two things to occur (quitting smoking causes one to have a lower life insurance premium and lower risk of lung cancer). This answer choice commits a causation flaw (A causes B and C, so B must cause C). But it's not the same type of causation flaw as the one in the passage (A is higher for those who do B, so B must cause A).

This conclusion doesn't match the passage's. It doesn't say, “if you want a high A, use B.” Instead, it says, “if you have A, use B.” So, rather than setting a goal that “B” can accomplish, this answer choice specifies a group to which “B” applies. In other words, this answer choice's conclusion doesn't imply a cause-and-effect relationship, unlike the passage. That's reason enough to eliminate (D) without reviewing the premises. If we reviewed the rest of the argument, we'd see that it doesn't parallel the passage's flaw either. Rather than comparing two groups, this answer choice's premise shows a particular group usually finds something helpful (those with larger-than-average estates usually find having their own lawyers helpful). This argument doesn't express any cause-and-effect relationships, so it doesn't commit the same causation flaw as the passage.

This conclusion sounds a bit like the passage's conclusion, although it's a negative (rather than a positive) statement. It implies a cause-and-effect relationship— that purchasing things from telemarketers causes telemarketers to call you. This is close enough to the passage's conclusion, so we should examine the premises to see if they also match. Once we review the rest of the argument, we'll see that it doesn't parallel the passage's flaw. Rather than comparing two groups, this answer choice's premise says that purchasing things from telemarketers actually causes them to call you in the future. So, this doesn't commit a correlation-to-causation flaw. In fact, it's a reasonable argument!

items.stimulusText: In an experiment, each of 200 randomly selected people was videotaped while describing action-packed excerpts from previously unfamiliar cartoons. Half the subjects were allowed to gesture while speaking, and the other half were not. Those who gestured spoke more quickly and repeated themselves less. This indicates that gesturing helps speakers quickly find the phrases they want.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if assumed, enables the conclusion in the argument to be properly drawn?

options.optionContent: Ordinarily almost everyone regularly gestures when speaking quickly and with little repetition, regardless of the topic being discussed.
The cartoons were chosen by those who conducted the experiment and were selected from a variety of sources.
Any form of behavior correlated with quicker speech and less repetition in speech helps speakers find the phrases they want quickly.

Any form of behavior that helps speakers quickly find the phrases they want also enables them to speak more quickly and repeat themselves less than they would if they were not engaged in that behavior.
Of the subjects who were allowed to gesture, those who spoke the most quickly and repeated themselves least were among those who gestured the most.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't bring up the new idea from the conclusion—that gesturing “helps speakers quickly find the phrases they want.” Instead, it just says that almost everyone gestures when speaking quickly and with little repetition. That may strengthen this argument (since it shows gesturing is associated with quick and concise speech outside of the study), but it doesn't prove that the conclusion is true. For instance, even if (A) is true, gesturing could help people speak more quickly and with less repetition because it makes people more relaxed, not because it helps them locate the phrase they want to use.

This doesn't bring up the new idea from the conclusion—that gesturing “helps speakers quickly find the phrases they want.” Instead, it just tells us about the cartoons chosen by the researchers. Regardless of how varied these cartoons were, this answer choice tell us anything about how gesturing helps people speak more quickly and less repetitively or whether it allows people to locate the phrases they want to use. Moreover, this answer choice may weaken the argument. If the cartoons were chosen from various sources, this introduces a new variable to the study. The study results would be more persuasive if all the subjects were asked to describe the same cartoon. If the cartoons were different, it's possible that those who were allowed to gesture spoke more quickly and with less repetition because the cartoons they described were simpler or less action-packed.

This answer choice connects the argument's premise to its conclusion. We may need to translate this answer choice to see that it bridges this gap. To do so, we can recall that the word “any” is an “if” keyword. So, we can translate this claim to, “If a behavior is correlated with quicker speech and less repetition, then it helps speakers find the phrases they want quickly.” That is a precise match for our anticipation, so we can select (C) confidently. After all, if we add this premise to the argument, it becomes valid. Suppose that (C) is true. In that case, we know gesturing, which the study shows is correlated with quicker and less repetitive speech, must help people quickly find the phrases they want. So, this answer choice makes the argument valid. We can select it and advance to the following question.

This doesn't connect the author's premise to their conclusion (“If a behavior is associated with speaking more quickly and less repetitively, then the behavior helps speakers find the phrases they want to use”). Instead, it connects the author's conclusion to their premise (“If a behavior helps speakers find the phrases they want to use, then that behavior is associated with speaking more quickly and less repetitively”).  For this reason, (D) is incorrect.

This doesn't even bring up the new idea from the conclusion—that gesturing “helps speakers quickly find the phrases they want.” Instead, it just says that the subjects who gestured the most spoke the quickest and with the least repetition. This information may strengthen this argument, as it affirms that there's a positive correlation between gesturing and speaking quickly and concisely. But it doesn't prove that these people spoke quickly and concisely because gesturing helped them find the right phrases. Even if this answer choice is true, these subjects could have gestured the most and spoken the most quickly because they were the most energetic subjects, not because gesturing helped them find the phrase they wanted to use.

items.stimulusText: Committee chairperson: No new course will be approved for next year's schedule unless a proposal for it has already been received either by this committee or by Dean Wilson. Dean Wilson has received only one new course proposal, and all of the new course proposals that this committee has received are for upper-level courses. It has been decided that, beginning next year, all upper-level courses will have prerequisites.
items.stemText: Which one of the following can be properly inferred if the chairperson's statements are true?

options.optionContent: If there are no new upper-level courses next year, then there will be no new courses next year that have prerequisites.
If all of the new courses next year are upper-level courses, then all of the new course proposals submitted to the committee will have been approved.
If there is more than one new course next year, at least one of them will be a course that has a prerequisite.
If the new course proposal that Dean Wilson received is for an upper-level course, then all courses offered next year will have prerequisites.
If there are no new upper-level courses next year, then the new course proposal that was submitted to Dean Wilson will have been approved.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: If we symbolized this claim, it would be “if NOT upper-level, then NOT prerequisite.” This is an inaccurate version of the third premise. We know that if there are upper-level courses, then they will have prerequisites. However, that doesn't mean that upper-level courses are the only courses with prerequisites. Some lower-level courses could have prerequisites, too.

If we symbolized this claim, it would be “if All upper-level approved, then Committee approved all courses.” This is an inaccurate version of the second premise. This answer choice also misconstrues the second premise's conditions since this answer choice is about approving all the courses rather than just approving one course. And, if we compare this statement to the rest of the premises, we'll see that it's not necessarily true. The committee would not have to approve all the proposals for all the new courses to be upper-level. The committee could have rejected a few upper-level proposals it received, and Dean Wilson could have rejected all the proposals they received, and all the new courses would still be upper-level courses. For these reasons, we can eliminate (B).

This statement must be true. If there is more than one new course next year, then at least one of them will have a prerequisite. We know that Dean Wilson only received “one new course proposal.” Even if that is a lower-level course without a prerequisite and Dean Wilson approves it, that would only represent one new course. If there's at least one other new course, its proposal would have been reviewed by the committee. The committee only reviewed upper-level courses with prerequisites, so that course would necessarily have a prerequisite. Since (C) is a demonstrably true statement based on these premises, we can select it and advance directly to the next question.

This is a very tempting answer choice! If it said that, “If the new course proposal that Dean Wilson received is for an upper-level course, then all new courses offered next year will have prerequisites,” it would be accurate. That would mean that all the courses the committee and Dean Wilson reviewed and approved were upper-level, all with prerequisites. However, (D) doesn't quite say that. It says, “If the new course proposal that Dean Wilson received is for an upper-level course, then all courses offered next year will have prerequisites.” It doesn't specify that all new courses will have prerequisites. It describes all courses generally. And we don't know anything about preexisting courses. Many of them could be lower-level courses lacking prerequisites, making this answer a potentially false statement.

This isn't necessarily true. If there are no new upper-level courses next year, that would mean that the committee rejected all of the proposals it received. But that doesn't mean that Dean Wilson would have had to accept the proposal they received. The Dean could have rejected that proposal, too. There's no stipulation that there has to be at least one new course this year.

items.stimulusText: The olecranon process is a bony part of the mammalian elbow. The shorter the olecranon process, the faster the forelimbs can typically be moved. Predatory mammals must move their forelimbs very quickly when attacking prey, and thus generally have short olecranon processes. It has recently been found that the extinct mammal Megatherium had a short olecranon process. Hence, in all probability, Megatherium was a predator.
items.stemText: The argument is most vulnerable to criticism on which one of the following grounds?

options.optionContent: It fails to address the possibility that most mammals with short olecranon processes have not been predators.
It takes for granted that the only reason predators need to move their forelimbs quickly is to attack prey.
It overlooks the possibility that Megatherium could have been a successful predator even if it did not have a short olecranon process.
It takes for granted that, on average, the olecranon processes of extinct mammals were no shorter than those of living mammals are.
It fails to address the possibility that a longer olecranon process may confer some other advantage, such as greater strength.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: When we see “fails to address” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” If most mammals with short olecranon processes were not predators, that would certainly weaken this author's argument. In fact, all else being equal, that would make it more likely that the Megatherium was not a predator. At any rate, we wouldn't be able to convincingly argue that the Megatherium was a predator based solely on its short olecranon process. So, this fact would undermine the author's argument if it were true. Therefore, this is a flaw in the author's reasoning. We can pick (A) and give the remaining answer choices an, at most, quick review.

When we see “takes for granted” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the author doesn't necessarily believe that the only reason predators need to move their front legs quickly is to attack prey. Although the author says this is one reason predators need to move their front legs quickly, the author doesn't say or imply that this is the sole reason. This is enough reason to eliminate (B). And this wouldn't really strengthen the author's argument if true, either. This could be the only reason predators need to move their front legs quickly, but non-predators could have other reasons they need to move their front legs quickly (such as evading predators). Therefore, even if (B) were true, non-predators could benefit from short olecranon processes, making it possible that Megatherium was not a predator. This provides another reason to cross off (B). (Compare this to a different version of (B), which says, “It takes for granted that the only reason mammals need to move their forelimbs quickly is to attack prey.” While the author doesn't necessarily believe this, this would at least strengthen the argument if true.)

When we see “overlooks the possibility” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” This definitely wouldn't weaken the author's argument. Even if the Megatherium was a successful predator without a short olecranon process, it would still be a predator. That would support the author's conclusion that the Megatherium was probably a predator

When we see “takes for granted” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, it's easy to assume that the author believes that the olecron processes were not generally shorter for extinct mammals. After all, the author bases the conclusion on the fact that the Megatherium had a “short olecranon process.” If extinct mammals generally had shorter olecranon processes, the Megatherium could have had an average olecranon process for its era. However, the author doesn't make any statements about “extinct mammals” generally. So, it's a stretch to say the author definitely believes that the olecranon processes of extinct mammals were no shorter than living mammals'. Moreover, (D) wouldn't weaken the author's argument if true. Even if extinct mammals generally had shorter olecranon processes, it would still be true that “the shorter the olecranon process, the faster the forelimbs can typically be moved.” So, extinct mammals would generally be able to move their forelimbs very fast. This would help a mammal like the Megatherium attack prey, which would still support the conclusion that the Megatherium was probably a predator.

When we see “fails to address” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” This definitely wouldn't weaken the author's argument. A longer olecranon process could provide some advantages, but those advantages would not necessarily outweigh the advantages of a shorter olecranon process for a predatory mammal. Therefore, the Megatherium's short olecranon process could still provide evidence that the Megatherium was probably a predator.

items.stimulusText: Essayist: Commitment to relationships or careers is commonly held to be virtuous. But all commitments should be seen as morally neutral. After all, what one is committed to might be either good or bad; for example, commitment to a relationship that benefits none of the people involved deserves no praise. Often, commitment is nothing more than involvement that has outlasted its original justification.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the essayist's reasoning?

options.optionContent: Any commitment that is morally neutral either has outlasted its original justification or deserves no praise, or both.
Commitment to a relationship or career is virtuous when, but only when, the relationship or career is good.
If a commitment deserves no praise, then that commitment is morally neutral.
If a commitment has outlasted its original justification, then it cannot be virtuous.
All commitments are morally neutral if there are any commitments that are undeserving of praise.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The “if” part of this principle says a commitment is morally neutral. That part should go in the “then” part of the principle because that's the conclusion the essayist reaches. Moreover, the “has outlasted its original justification or deserves no praise” part should go on the “if” side since those are premises the essayist uses. For this reason, (A) is incorrect.

This principle won't justify the essayist's conclusion that all commitments are morally neutral. It would establish that the commitments made to bad careers and relationships are not morally virtuous. That doesn't imply that these commitments are morally neutral, however. They could be morally bad! Moreover, this principle would establish that commitments made to good careers and relationships are morally virtuous, not neutral.

This answer choice is tempting, but it won't help justify that all commitments are morally neutral. The essayist states that some commitments deserve no praise. According to this principle, those commitments would be morally neutral. But what about the commitments that deserve praise? Are those morally neutral, too? This principle doesn't tell us that, so it doesn't strengthen the essayist's reasoning.

The essayist establishes that some commitments outlast their original justification. According to this principle, that would mean that those commitments are not morally virtuous. But that doesn't mean that they're morally neutral. They could be morally bad. Moreover, this principle doesn't tell us whether other commitments are morally neutral. Therefore, it doesn't establish that all commitments are morally neutral.

This connects one of the essayist's premises to their conclusion.” Translated to a more straightforward “if-then” statement, this says, “If any commitments are undeserving of praise, then all commitments are morally neutral.” This connects the essayist's premise that “commitment to a relationship that benefits none of the people involved deserves no praise” to the conclusion that “all commitments should be seen as morally neutral.” The essayist identifies one commitment undeserving of praise, so this principle would establish that all commitments must be morally neutral. Therefore, this principle bridges the gap between the essayist's premise and conclusion. We can confidently select (E).

items.stimulusText: Because of the ubiquity of television in modern households, few children today spend their free time reading stories, which lack the visual appeal of flashy television programs. Thus, few children today will develop a lifelong interest in literature.
items.stemText: The conclusion drawn above follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?

options.optionContent: No children who spend their free time reading stories fail to develop a lifelong interest in literature.
Only those people who currently spend their free time reading stories will develop a lifelong interest in literature.
No children who grow up in a household that lacks a television fail to spend their free time reading stories.
Few people who watch a great deal of television develop a lifelong interest in literature.
Few children who spend their free time reading stories watch television.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: To translate this, we'll need to use the “No,” a “then-denying” keyword. That would give us this “if-then” statement and flipside: if Read stories, then NOT fail to develop a lifelong interest in literature (if Fail to develop a lifelong interest in literature, then NOT read stories). If we use a “positive mindset” on the “NOT fail” double negative, we can translate that to simply “develop a lifelong interest in literature”: if Read stories, then Develop a lifelong interest in literature (if NOT Develop a lifelong interest in literature, then NOT read stories). Rather than connect the premise to the new idea in the conclusion, it says that if we don't have the premise, then we won't have the new idea in the conclusion. For this reason, (A) is incorrect.

We'll need to notice that the “only” is a “then” keyword. That will give us this “if-then” statement and flipside: if Develop a lifelong interest in literature, then Read stories (if NOT read stories, then NOT develop a lifelong interest in literature). The flipside matches our anticipation, so we can confidently select (B). After all, if we add this premise to the argument, it becomes valid. Suppose that (B) is true—suppose that we know that if you don't spend your free time reading, then you won't develop a lifelong interest in literature. In that case, most children who spend their time watching TV rather than reading will not develop a lifelong interest in literature. So, this answer choice makes the argument valid. We can select it.

We can eliminate this answer choice immediately because it lacks the new term in the conclusion. It doesn't discuss whether any kids “develop a lifelong interest in literature.” Therefore, this can't make the conclusion valid. You can't have a valid conclusion with a term that doesn't appear in any of the premises, so adding this premise won't make the conclusion follow logically.

This doesn't connect the author's premise to their conclusion. Instead, it just establishes that people who watch a “great deal of television” will usually not develop a lifelong interest in literature. However, the author's premises don't say that most children watch a great deal of television. The premises just say that televisions are common and that few children “spend their free time reading stories.” These children may spend their free time watching television instead of stories, but that doesn't mean they're necessarily watching “a great deal of television.” In other words, since the author doesn't include a premise that establishes that most children watch a great deal of television, this answer choice does not connect the author's premise to their conclusion.

Like (C), we can immediately cross this answer choice off once we see that it lacks the new term in the conclusion. It doesn't discuss whether kids “develop a lifelong interest in literature.” Therefore, this can't make the conclusion valid. A conclusion that features an idea that isn't discussed in any of the premises will never be valid, so adding this premise won't make the conclusion follow logically.

items.stimulusText: Filmmaker: I use hidden cameras when filming documentaries, because people behave differently when they are aware of being filmed. Although my subjects have been told that a camera is present, they remain unaware of its location and act naturally. Hence, my documentaries are more worthwhile than documentaries in which, for example, people speak directly to the camera.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the filmmaker's argument?

options.optionContent: A documentary with no purpose other than authentically depicting the behavior of its human subjects can be legitimate.
A documentary can be authentic only if it does not include any subjects speaking directly to a camera.
Makers of documentaries do not have a moral obligation to reveal to their subjects the location of the cameras filming them.
The more authentically a documentary depicts its subjects, the more worthwhile it is.
Subjects of documentaries should not try to discover the locations of the cameras filming them.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This principle doesn't discuss whether documentaries where the subjects are unaware of the camera's location and act naturally are “more worthwhile” than other documentaries. It just says these documentaries “can be legitimate.” Sure, they're legitimate, but are they worthwhile? This answer choice doesn't say. For these reasons, we can cross off (A).
