This principle takes the form “if Documentary authentic, then Subjects do NOT speak directly to the camera.” (The “only” is a “then” keyword, so we have to put that part on the “then” side.) The flipside of this — “if Subjects speak directly to the camera, then Documentary NOT authentic” — would prove that the kinds of documentaries this filmmaker criticizes are “not authentic.” But it doesn't show that these documentaries are not worthwhile. In other words, we can cross this answer choice off because it focuses on documentaries' authenticity rather than their worth.

This answer choice only establishes that this filmmaker did not violate a moral obligation. It doesn't discuss whether the filmmaker's documentaries are more worthwhile than any other documentary. Just because something passed a (fairly low) moral bar doesn't mean it's “worthwhile.”

This principle gets pretty close to our anticipation of “If the subjects of a documentary act more naturally, then the documentary is more worthwhile than documentaries where subjects are aware of the camera's location and that they're being filmed.” It's not a perfect match. The answer choice uses the term “authenticity” rather than “act naturally.” And it's a proportional claim rather than a conditional one. But—crucially—it's the only answer choice so far that brings up how “worthwhile” the filmmaker's documentaries are. So, this answer choice merits a closer examination. Upon review, we can see how this would strengthen the filmmaker's argument. If the filmmaker's subjects don't know where the cameras are and therefore act naturally, we can reasonably argue that these subjects are depicted fairly authentically. These subjects are definitely depicted more authentically than those subjects who speak directly to a camera. This principle would, therefore, establish that the filmmaker's documentaries—which depict their subjects more authentically—would be more worthwhile than other documentaries. Since this isn't a perfect match for our anticipation, we should probably review the remaining answer choice to confirm that it's wrong. But once we confirm that it's wrong (for instance, if we see that it doesn't describe whether the filmmaker's documentaries are worthwhile), we can select (D) confidently.

This principle doesn't discuss whether documentaries where the subjects are unaware of the camera's location and act naturally are “more worthwhile” than other documentaries. It just says these subjects shouldn't look for the cameras. Fine, but are the resulting documentaries “worthwhile”? This answer choice doesn't say, so it's wrong.

items.stimulusText: The more profitable a corporation is, the more valuable its managers' time is. As a result, it is especially costly for highly profitable corporations to have their managers spend time monitoring employees. Such corporations can save money by reducing this monitoring, as long as the employees are given strong incentives to keep working hard. So highly profitable corporations can save money by giving their employees expensive bonuses.
items.stemText: The argument requires the assumption that

options.optionContent: only a few corporations give their employees bonuses that provide strong enough incentives for the employees to keep working hard even when they are not being monitored

if a highly profitable corporation could save money by giving its employees expensive bonuses, it is because giving such bonuses would reduce the amount of time its managers must spend monitoring those employees
the more valuable the managers' time is at a corporation, the less likely it is that the corporation will actually have those managers spend time monitoring employees
for people who are employees of highly profitable corporations where monitoring is reduced, expensive bonuses constitute strong incentives to keep working hard
a highly profitable corporation can save money by reducing its managers' monitoring of employees only if its employees are given expensive bonuses

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This strengthens the argument, but it isn't necessary. This answer choice strengthens the argument because it establishes that expensive bonuses can incentivize employees to work hard even though they're not being monitored. However, this isn't necessary to the argument because we don't need to know that some corporations already give out these bonuses as an incentive to work hard. Even if no corporations give out these bonuses, these bonuses could still incentivize employees to work hard and thus save highly profitable corporations money. Finally, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “Managers' time is more valuable in highly profitable corporations. So, monitoring employees is very costly for highly profitable corporations. Reducing monitoring can save highly profitable corporations money. But, employees need incentives to work hard. But, it's not true that only a few corporations give their employees bonuses that provide strong enough incentives for the employees to keep working hard even when they are not being monitored. So, giving employees expensive bonuses won't save highly profitable corporations money.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. Why would knowing that no corporations give out big bonuses prove that giving out bonuses won't save the corporations money? This argument doesn't provide any evidence that expensive bonuses won't incentivize employees to work hard. So, this answer choice doesn't pass the backup test. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (A).

This answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument. It puts the conclusion in the “if” part of an “if-then” statement. The correct answer to a Strengthen with a Necessary Premise question can't do that. Such statements presuppose that the conclusion is true. However, such a presupposition won't help the argument since we don't know whether the conclusion is true! Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “Managers' time is more valuable in highly profitable corporations. So, monitoring employees is very costly for highly profitable corporations. Reducing monitoring can save highly profitable corporations money. But, employees need incentives to work hard. But, it's not true that if a highly profitable corporation could save money by giving its employees expensive bonuses, it is because giving such bonuses would reduce the amount of time its managers must spend monitoring those employees. So, giving employees expensive bonuses won't save highly profitable corporations money.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. The “But, it's not true that part” establishes that a highly profitable corporation can save money through expensive bonuses for reasons other than reducing its need to monitor employees. Even if that's true, the corporation is still saving money through the bonuses. So, giving employees expensive bonuses would save highly profitable corporations money! So, this answer choice doesn't pass the backup test. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (B).

This answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument. In fact, it weakens it! If managers at highly profitable corporations aren't monitoring their employees, then these corporations wouldn't save money through expensive bonuses. These bonuses only save the company money, according to this argument, because they replace the need for managers to use their valuable time monitoring their employees. But if these bonuses aren't replacing that monitoring, they'll only cost the corporation money. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “Managers' time is more valuable in highly profitable corporations. So, monitoring employees is very costly for highly profitable corporations. Reducing monitoring can save highly profitable corporations money. But, employees need incentives to work hard. But, it's not true that the more valuable the managers' time is at a corporation, the less likely it is that the corporation will actually have those managers spend time monitoring employees. So, giving employees expensive bonuses won't save highly profitable corporations money.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. The “But, it's not true that part” establishes that managers of highly profitable corporations monitor their employees' activity. The premises establish that this is very costly. So, it's unclear why replacing this monitoring with bonuses wouldn't save the corporations money, as this conclusion asserts. Giving employees expensive bonuses instead of wasting the manager's valuable time could save highly profitable corporations money! So, this answer choice doesn't pass the backup test. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (C).

This answer choice strengthens the argument by establishing that expensive bonuses is a strong incentive for employees of highly profitable corporations to work hard. If employees of highly profitable corporations are given bonuses instead of being monitored, and these bonuses incentivize the employees to work hard, then it makes sense that these bonuses can save the corporation money. After all, these bonuses would replace managers' need to waste their valuable time by monitoring their employees while ensuring the employees continue to work hard. We also need to know this to draw the conclusion. If these bonuses didn't incentivize employees to work hard, then the bonuses might not save the company money. Managers would need to monitor the employees again (wasting their valuable time and costing the corporation money), or the corporation would not function properly (potentially losing money in the process). Since this answer choice strengthens and is needed to draw the conclusion, it is the correct answer. Alternatively, we can also evaluate this answer choice using the backup plan. Here's the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified the answer choice to make this easier to read): “Managers' time is more valuable in highly profitable corporations. So, monitoring employees is very costly for highly profitable corporations. Reducing monitoring can save highly profitable corporations money. But, employees need incentives to work hard. But, it's not true that expensive bonuses constitute strong incentives for employees of highly profitable corporations to keep working hard. So, giving employees expensive bonuses won't save highly profitable corporations money.” This makes sense. If expensive bonuses don't ensure that employees work hard, these bonuses won't necessarily save the company money. The bonuses will be costly. And, because employees may not work as hard, the managers might need to monitor the employees again (which would waste their valuable time and cost the corporation money), or the corporation would not function properly (which could be very costly). Since this argument makes sense, (D) also passes the backup test. Therefore, no matter which approach we used, we can be confident that (D) is the correct answer.

If we translate it into a simple “if-then” statement, we'll see that it asserts that if corporations save money by reducing their managers' monitoring, they have to give their employees expensive bonuses. In its translated form, we can see that this answer choice strengthens the argument but isn't necessary. This answer choice strengthens the argument by establishing that expensive bonuses can incentivize employees to work hard even though they're not being monitored. However, this isn't necessary to the argument because we don't need to know that expensive bonuses are the only way to incentivize employees to work hard or for a corporation to save money. The argument only asserts that such bonuses can help a corporation save money. It doesn't assert that there are no other ways to save money or keep employees working hard. For this reason, (D) is not a necessary premise for this argument. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “Managers' time is more valuable in highly profitable corporations. So, monitoring employees is very costly for highly profitable corporations. Reducing monitoring can save highly profitable corporations money. But, employees need incentives to work hard. But, it's not true that a highly profitable corporation can save money by reducing its managers' monitoring of employees only if its employees are given expensive bonuses. So, giving employees expensive bonuses won't save highly profitable corporations money.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. Even if there are other ways to save money, couldn't expensive bonuses still save corporations money? Moreover, this argument doesn't provide any evidence that expensive bonuses won't incentivize employees to work hard. So, this answer choice doesn't pass the backup test. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (E).

items.stimulusText: Columnist: Consent forms filled out by subjects prior to their participation in tests of experimental medicines designed to treat the diseases from which they are suffering show that almost all subjects accept the risk of receiving ineffective substances. This casts doubt on the claim made by some medical ethicists that many test subjects resent being given placebos (as happens to roughly half of all test subjects) or resent being given medicines that turn out to be ineffective (as also often occurs).
items.stemText: The reasoning in the columnist's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument

options.optionContent: infers that two phenomena are associated merely from the claim that there are many instances in which both phenomena are present
uses as evidence the opinions of people who are unlikely to be qualified to make informed judgments about the scientific value of placebos
uses evidence drawn from a sample that is likely to be unrepresentative
takes for granted that most test subjects do not change their attitudes toward the chance of taking ineffective substances once the substances they take turn out to be ineffective
draws a conclusion that is essentially about a moral issue by appealing to evidence that is purely factual

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The columnist's argument doesn't infer that two phenomena are associated. The columnist's conclusion discusses two phenomena—subjects resenting being given placebos and resenting being given ineffective medicine. But the author doesn't say they're associated—just that the consent forms cast doubt on whether either phenomenon occurs.

It's not a flaw that the columnist uses the opinions of unqualified people to make this conclusion. In fact, the columnist's conclusion asserts that test subjects do not actually resent being given placebos or ineffective treatments. To draw that conclusion, the columnist must rely on the test subject's opinions!

The columnist doesn't even use a sample to draw this conclusion. As far as we can tell, the columnist uses the consent forms of all subjects who sign up for tests of experimental medicines. If we knew that, for instance, the columnist only looked at subjects who were paid to sign up for these tests, this would be an appealing answer choice. But the argument doesn't give us any reason to think the consent forms the columnist cites are unrepresentative of the test subject's general feelings.

When we see “takes for granted” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the columnist definitely believes that “most test subjects do not change their attitudes” toward the risk of taking ineffective substances after they take ineffective substances. After all, the columnist uses evidence about what the subjects agree to before the study to conclude how they feel after they take the study. (Notice the shift in verb tense between the premise and conclusion. The premises say the subjects “filled out” the consent forms “prior to their participation in tests.” The conclusion says the test subjects may not “resent” being given placebos or ineffective medicines.) So, the columnist must believe that the subjects' attitudes do not change between filling out the forms and being given ineffective treatments. This assumption isn't necessarily warranted. People change their minds all the time. It would be very understandable and not at all surprising if a test subject given an ineffective treatment for a disease they're suffering from would change their mind and resent the treatment. Additionally, this unwarranted assumption strengthens the columnist's argument. If test subjects do not change their mind after filling out the consent form, they will continue to accept the risk of taking ineffective treatment even after being given an ineffective treatment. Therefore, those forms would cast doubt on the medical ethicists' claims that subjects resent being given ineffective medicine in these studies. Since the columnist relies on this unwarranted assumption to make their conclusion, this is a flaw in their argument. We can select (D) confidently.

The columnist doesn't draw a conclusion about a moral issue. In fact, the columnist's conclusion isn't evaluative or normative; the columnist doesn't argue that subjects should not be or have no right to be resentful. The columnist's conclusion is a factual one—the consent forms undermine the medical ethicists' argument that subjects actually resent being given placebos.

sections.directions: Directions: Each question in this section is based on the reasoning presented in a brief passage. In answering the questions, you should not make assumptions that are by commonsense standards implausible, superfluous, or incompatible with the passage. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText: Over the long run, apple orchards that use organic farming methods cost no more to run than, and are just as productive as, apple orchards using conventional methods. However, organically grown apples tend to be better tasting, and thus, organic orchards are likely to be more profitable than conventional orchards in the long run.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.optionContent: The use of organic farming methods has recently increased in the commercial apple farming industry.
The apple orchards that tend to be most profitable in the long run tend to be those that are most profitable in the short run.
Demand for a given kind of apple is based primarily on flavor.
Most people prefer to buy apples that have the lowest price.
Many consumers prefer the appearance of apples grown using conventional methods to that of apples grown organically.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This might weaken the argument. If there are more organic apple orchards, the supply of organic apples is up. With more organic apples to sell, this might lower the price organic apples can fetch. This could reduce organic apple orchard's profitability.

This doesn't strengthen the argument because we have no idea if organic orchards tend to be more profitable in the short run. In fact, we don't know anything about either kind of orchard in “the short run.”

Here we go! As expected, this answer choice ties organic apples' superior taste to their profitability. If demand for apples is based primarily on flavor, then we can expect more people to want organic apples. If more people want organic apples, organic orchards can sell more organic apples, charge a higher price, or both. If organic orchards can do that, then they'll be more profitable in the long run, especially if they don't cost more to run than conventional orchards. Because (C) strengthens the argument, we can select it.
This doesn't strengthen the argument because we have no idea if organic apples cost less than conventionally grown apples.

This weakens the argument. If people prefer the appearance of conventionally grown apples, more people may buy them (especially if they can't sample both apples and compare their tastes before purchasing). If more people eschew organic apples to buy conventionally grown apples instead, the organic orchards will probably be less profitable over time.

items.stimulusText: Banking industry visionaries foresee a bright day in the near future when customers will be able to transact all their financial business by means of computers or telephones from the comfort of their own homes. But that may be more of a paradise for banks than for their customers. As banks eliminate their branch offices and customer-service employees, customers will have to serve as their own tellers—and pay more transaction fees for their efforts.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the conclusion of the argument?

options.optionContent: In the near future, bank customers will be able to transact all their financial business by means of computers or telephones from their own homes.
Enabling bank customers to transact all their financial business by means of computers or telephones from their own homes may be more beneficial to banks than to their customers.
As banks eliminate branch offices and customer-service employees, bank customers will have to serve as their own tellers and pay more fees.
Eliminating branch offices and customer-service employees would benefit the banking industry.
Enabling customers to transact all their financial business by means of computers or telephones from their own homes would allow banks to eliminate branch offices and customer-service employees.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't match our identified conclusion, so it's a quick cross-off. Besides, this is a misstatement of the first sentence. Bank visionaries “foresee” (predict) this type of banking, but that doesn't mean these banks will soon exist or will ever come to fruition. This argument is about a hypothetical form of banking, not a near-future one.
This expresses the same idea as the main conclusion we identified, so we can select it and advance to the following question.

This restates the last sentence in the passage. That sentence is a premise to the argument's main conclusion. According to the argument, the fact that customers will have to serve as their own tellers and pay more fees is why online and telephonic banking “may be more of a paradise for banks than for their customers.” In other words, this sentence makes the argument's prediction that online and telephonic will be better for banks than customers more convincing.

This is an assumption the author makes. The author asserts that eliminating branch offices and customer-service employees is why online and telephonic banking “may be more of a paradise for banks than for their customers.” In order for that premise and conclusion to have a logical relationship, the author must believe that eliminating these branches and employees is good for the banking industry. In other words, this answer choice reflects an unstated belief the author has when making this argument. This unstated belief cannot be the argument's conclusion. The conclusion must be stated in the argument. And, the conclusion takes the premise and assumption for granted to assert that online and telephonic will be better for banks than customers.

Like (D), this is an assumption the author makes. The author discussses the possible switch to online and telephonic banking in the first sentence. In the last sentence, the author says that this new type of banking will result in banks eliminating branch offices and customer-service employees. In order to get from the first sentence to the third, the author must believe that online and telephonic banking will allow the banks to cut offices and employees. The author doesn't say this out loud, but it's implied by the author's jump from the first to the third sentence. In other words, this answer choice reflects an unstated belief the author has when making this argument. This unstated belief cannot be the argument's conclusion. The conclusion must be stated in the argument. And, the conclusion takes the premises and this assumption for granted to assert that online and telephonic will be better for banks than customers.

items.stimulusText:
Bernard: We should not invite Carl to speak at the forum. Carl's views are clearly false, and worse, dangerous. To encourage their consideration will not only legitimize them but also help to promulgate them, both of which we should avoid, since we wish not to support their adoption.

Ayla: The best way to combat false views is to challenge them in public. Once Carl's views are subjected to the kind of public scrutiny the forum provides, people will see them for what they are because the forum will provide convincing arguments against them.
items.stemText: The dialogue provides the most support for the claim that Bernard and Ayla disagree about whether

options.optionContent: one should always avoid legitimizing a view whose adoption one wishes not to support
people will see the falsity of every dangerous idea for which they are furnished with forceful counterarguments
the best way to fight erroneous ideas involves allowing the public expression of these ideas
people who hold false views tend to pose a danger to society
one should not encourage the adoption of dangerous views

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: It seems like Bernard and Ayla are in agreement on this issue. Neither wants to legitimize Carl's false views. Bernard just thinks that inviting Carl to speak will legitimize his views, while Ayla thinks that challenging Carl's views will de-legitimize them.

While we can infer that Bernard would agree with this answer choice, it is so boldly worded that we don't know whether Ayla agrees with it. Ayla thinks counterarguments are “the best way” to challenge dangerous ideas. But that doesn't imply that Ayla thinks that counterarguments will falsify “every dangerous idea” the public faces. Even Ayla may acknowledge that some dangerous ideas will survive counterarguments.

Ayla would quite obviously agree with this statement, given that she expresses it in the first sentence. We also have good reason to believe that Bernard would disagree with this statement. He says that allowing one to speak publicly “encourages” the consideration of their false views, thereby legitimizing those views and helping to “support their adoption.” So, Bernard thinks that public expression of erroneous ideas encourages the adoption of those views. So, he would almost certainly disagree with the idea that the best way to fight erroneous ideas involves allowing the public expression of these ideas. Since Ayla would agree with (C) and Bernard would disagree with it, we can select (C) and advance to the following question.

This answer choice is so boldly worded that we can't tell whether either Bernard or Ayla would agree with it. Bernard says that Carl's ideas are both false and dangerous, but that doesn't mean Bernard thinks that everyone who holds false views poses a danger to society. Perhaps he would acknowledge that some people possess harmless false ideas. Plus, Ayala doesn't even state or imply that Carl's ideas are dangerous, so we don't know what she thinks about the relationship between false and dangerous ideas.

It seems like Bernard and Ayla agree on this issue. Bernard doesn't want to legitimize what he calls Carl's false and dangerous views. Although Ayla doesn't say that Carl's views are dangerous, she calls his views false and wants to refute them publicly. If she thinks it's important to combat false views, it would stand to reason that she would want to refute dangerous views as well.

items.stimulusText:
Principle: It is unethical for someone who has bought an item to return it to the store after getting all the use from it that he or she ever intended to get.

Application: James purchased a video camera and returned it to the store two weeks later. This return was unethical.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most justifies the above application of the principle?

options.optionContent: Before returning the camera, James used it extensively to record members of his family engaged in funny activities.
James bought the camera to avoid having to hire a professional videographer for his sister's graduation party, and he returned the camera immediately after the party.
James used the camera several times but returned it after he had dropped it and then discovered that some of the features did not work.
James returned the camera after he discovered that the same model was on sale at another store at a considerably lower price.
James used the camera in the manner for which he bought it, and, though he generally enjoyed it, he thought a different one might work better with his new computer.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We're looking for an answer choice that says that James got all the use out of the camera that he intended, and this answer choice doesn't quite say that. James may have used the camera to record his family acting funny, but that doesn't mean that this was his sole intention or that he was done filming his family. If James intended to film more family antics, he could have returned the camera before he got all the use from it that he intended.

We're looking for an answer choice that says that James got all the use out of the camera that he intended, and this answer choice says just that! If James bought the camera to avoid hiring a professional videographer for his sister's party and returned it immediately after the party, it certainly seems like recording the party was the only reason he wanted to use the camera. That would mean James would have bought the camera, got all the use out of it he intended, and then returned the camera. According to the principle, James's return would be unethical. Therefore, we can select this answer choice and give the remaining a quick once-over.

We're looking for an answer choice that says that James got all the use out of the camera that he intended, and this answer choice doesn't say that. In fact, it sounds like James is trying to return the camera because he broke it. The principle doesn't consider whether it's unethical to return a product you break, so this doesn't strengthen the application of the principle.

We're looking for an answer choice that says that James got all the use out of the camera that he intended, and this answer choice doesn't say that. Instead, James is returning the camera because he found a better deal. This answer choice doesn't say whether he's used the camera at all. The principle doesn't consider whether it's unethical to return a product to save some money, so this doesn't strengthen the application of the principle.

We're looking for an answer choice that says that James got all the use out of the camera that he intended, and this answer choice doesn't quite say that. James may have used the camera “in the manner for which he bought it,” but that doesn't mean that he got all the use out of it that he intended. In fact, it sounds like James wants to use a camera more since he wants a different one that “might work better with his new computer.”

items.stimulusText: Taylorism, the early-twentieth-century industrial efficiency movement pioneered by Frederick Taylor, has had a profound effect on industrialized societies. Increased productivity resulting from greater efficiency has led to increases in most workers' standards of living. At the same time, Taylor's methods have tended to make these workers' jobs routine and repetitive, thereby robbing their work of some of the intrinsic worth it possessed when it emphasized creativity and talent.
items.stemText: The situation described above most closely conforms to which one of the following generalizations?

options.optionContent: Sometimes measures that appear to promote efficiency are actually deleterious to it.
Some developments in industry can benefit workers financially while making their work less rewarding in other respects.
Increased efficiency in industrial settings is sometimes accompanied by decreases in the amount of effort workers devote to their jobs.
An increase in workers' standards of living will likely involve an accompanying decrease in how much they value their jobs overall.
Workers who have greater than average creativity and talent are sometimes less efficient than workers who have average creativity and talent.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage doesn't say that Taylorism made workers in any way less productive. So, we don't have any evidence that measures that appear to promote efficiency are actually “deleterious” (harmful) to efficiency.

We should anticipate that the correct answer would say something like, “A movement can benefit people in one way and harm them in other ways.” This answer choice is a touch more specific than that anticipation, but it gets across the same basic idea. Moreover, it accurately describes what happened to workers following Taylorism. It benefited these workers financially (as they could enjoy a higher standard of living) while making their jobs less rewarding in other ways (since Taylorism made this work boring and robbed it of some of its intrinsic worth). Moreover, this answer choice uses the weak and wiggly language (“some,” “can”) we need for this question. Therefore, we can select (B) and give the remaining choices an at-most cursory review.

The passage doesn't say that Taylorism led workers to decrease the effort they devoted to their jobs. The passage only says that their work became routine and repetitive. But a routine and repetitive task can still take a lot of time and effort to complete!

We can't validly conclude that increased living standards “will likely” decrease how much workers value their jobs. We know this happened in the early 1900s, but we don't know if this usually happens. For this reason, we can cross off (D).

The passage doesn't tell us anything about workers with “greater than average” or “average creativity and talent.” The passage only says that Taylorism made jobs emphasize creativity and talent less. The passage doesn't tell us anything about the creativity and talent the workers possessed.

items.stimulusText: Winchester Township cannot afford to keep its several small branch libraries supplied with a wide selection of current books. However, if the branch libraries were closed, then Winchester could afford to open one large library, which could carry broader and more current selections. Thus, Winchester would better meet its residents' needs by closing its small branch libraries and opening one larger, well-supplied library.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument above?

options.optionContent: Many Winchester residents never use the branch libraries because of the irregular hours each branch keeps.
Most Winchester residents have complained about the selection of books at the branch libraries.
The only possible site for a new library is not readily accessible to most Winchester residents.
It would cost Winchester a significant amount of money to build a larger library.
Each of Winchester's branch libraries attempts to cater to the tastes of the residents of the entire township.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice could either strengthen or weaken the author’s argument. This answer choice shows that the residents can't take advantage of the smaller branch libraries' current hours. If the centralized library fixes this issue and expands the hours, the new library could better meet residents' needs. More people would be able to visit the library and conduct their library-related business. On the other hand, if the centralized library keeps the same hours as the branch libraries, this answer choice would weaken the argument. This would be one reason the new library doesn't do a better job meeting Winchester residents' needs. If an answer choice has an ambiguous effect on the argument—if it could strengthen or weaken the argument based on additional information—it can't be said to truly weaken the argument.

This strengthens the argument by showing that residents at least care about the selection of books at the branch libraries. This gives us reason to believe that a centralized library with a broader selection of books would satisfy Winchester residents' bibliographic needs.

This definitely weakens the argument. It brings up another factor germane to Winchester residents' needs: convenience and accessibility. If the centralized library can only be built in an inaccessible location, then the library's vast and up-to-date collection won't matter to most Winchester residents. These residents won't be able to access that collection. This makes the argument's conclusion much less convincing, making (C) the correct answer. We can select it and give the remaining choices an, at most, cursory read.

This is irrelevant to the argument. The argument's conclusion didn't assert that the new library was the right policy choice for the Winchester government. The argument's conclusion only predicted that a new library would better meet residents' needs. So, the argument isn't concerned with the cost the library poses—it's only concerned with whether an improved selection would meet residents' needs. And even if the library would cost a lot of money to construct, that doesn't necessarily mean that the library wouldn't be able to afford to carry a broader and more current collection of books. After all, the centralized library eliminates the need to buy multiple books for the various branch libraries.

This is irrelevant to the argument. Even if the smaller branch libraries try to cater to the entire township's tastes, that doesn't mean that the libraries succeed in doing so. Winchester residents might still desire a broader and more up-to-date selection of books. Moreover, regardless of what the smaller branch libraries try to stock, it would still be easier for a single, centralized library to cater to the entire town's tastes. After all, the centralized library eliminates the need to buy multiple books for the various branch libraries. So, the centralized library could stock a much broader variety of titles, ensuring that it satisfies the tastes of any Winchester resident.

items.stimulusText: News report: Some recently invented television screens are built out of small tiles seamlessly joined together, each tile a separate miniature screen. Television sets with these compound screens are just a few inches thick. For a noncompound screen in a set of this thickness, the larger the screen is, the dimmer it is. However, each tile in a compound screen is small enough to be quite bright. Moreover, an unlimited number of the tiles can be joined together, without making the resulting screen any less bright or the set any thicker.
items.stemText: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the information in the news report?

options.optionContent: The technology used to make compound television screens is not appropriate for television sets with relatively small screens.
There is a great consumer demand for television sets that are just a few inches thick and that have very large screens.
In a television set with a noncompound screen, the thicker the television set, the brighter the screen.
Television sets that are just a few inches thick can now be made with screens that are both bright and very large.
Television sets with compound screens do not have any disadvantages relative to sets with noncompound screens.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Why wouldn't this technology be appropriate for small-screen television? True, one of the main advantages of the new screen is that they can be very large and maintain their brightness. But these new screens could still have advantages over older screens that are apparent even in small-screen televisions. After all, we know that the new screens are only a few inches thick, which could make the small-screen televisions very light and portable.

Well, these new television screens sound pretty sick, but the passage doesn't tell us whether people actually want to buy them yet. Remember, when we're connecting facts, we need to stick to the facts. We don't know if there's actually “a great consumer demand” for these new screens. Maybe they're too expensive right now, or maybe people don't want them for some other reason.

This misstates a claim from the passage. The passage says, “For a noncompound screen [a few inches thick], the larger the screen is, the dimmer it is.” The last sentence implies that a larger compound screen might also need to be thicker to maintain its brightness. However, this doesn't imply the proportional relationship (C) asserts. There may be limits to how much brighter we can make a screen. After a certain depth, the screen may not get any brighter.

Here it is. The passage implies that we can now make a television screen that's very large, very bright, and not very thick. We can make these sorts of televisions by connecting these small, bright tiles. And we can make this inference by connecting the facts about these small, bright tiles. Let's select (D) and give the last answer choice an, at most, quick glance.

This is far too bold. These new television screens sound cool, but they might have many disadvantages. They could be more expensive than older screens. They may project blurrier images than older screens. They may cause more retina damage than older screens. We really only know that the new screens can be bigger, brighter, and less thick than older screens. That doesn't imply that the new screens are better in every way.

items.stimulusText: Anthropologist: For early humans who moved from a hunter-gatherer lifestyle to agriculture, the transition must have been traumatic. There would have been increased incidence of disease and injury and a more homogeneous diet lacking vital nutrients more easily obtainable from the richly varied diet of hunter-gatherers. Thus, groups that made the transition were likely motivated by certain benefits that accompany the settled life of the agriculturist, such as opportunities for the accumulation of wealth by those with specialized social roles.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the anthropologist's overall argument by the statement that for early humans who moved from a hunter-gatherer lifestyle to agriculture, the transition must have been traumatic?

options.optionContent: It is a premise for which another premise is offered as support.
It is background information that plays no logical role in the argument.
It is a premise for which no support is offered.
It is the conclusion of the argument as a whole.
It is a claim that the rest of the argument seeks to rebut.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Bingo. We're looking for an answer choice that says the phrase is a premise/conclusion. This answer choice doesn't word it that way, but it gets close enough. It describes the first sentence as a “premise,” which is accurate. The first sentence supports the last. This answer choice also says that “another premise is offered as support” for the first sentence, which is also accurate. The second sentence supports the first sentence, as the second sentence explains why the transition to agriculture would be traumatic. Since we have a precise anticipation for this question and (A) matches that anticipation, we can confidently select (A) and advance to the following question.

Nope. The first sentence definitely plays a “logical role” in the argument. It supports the main conclusion by describing a major downside of the transition to agriculture, which makes it more likely that the transition to agriculture was due to ulterior motives, like the opportunity to amass wealth. The first sentence is also supported by the second sentence, as the second sentence explains why the transition to agriculture would be traumatic. Since the first sentence is supported by and used to support other claims, it has a logical role in this argument.
Nope. The first sentence is supported by the second sentence, as the second sentence explains why the transition to agriculture would be traumatic.

Nope. The first sentence supports the third conclusion by describing a major downside of the transition to agriculture, which makes it more likely that the transition to agriculture was due to ulterior motives, like the opportunity to amass wealth. Since the first sentence supports another claim, it is not the argument's main conclusion.

Nope. The argument doesn't try to rebut or disprove the first sentence. In fact, the first sentence supports the main point by describing a major downside of the transition to agriculture, which makes it more likely that the transition to agriculture was due to by ulterior motives, like the opportunity to amass wealth. Rather than try to rebut the first sentence, the argument relies on the first sentence.

items.stimulusText: Most lawyers hold that violations of the rights of those who possess sites on the web are best prevented using copyright law. Yet many of the words used to describe such sites evoke ideas that are usually associated with real estate: for example, the word "site" itself and the term "visiting" as applied to sites. The common law of trespass usually applies to cases of encroachment on real estate. Thus, it is reasonable to extend that law to protect against encroachments on property in cyberspace.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument

options.optionContent: fails to provide adequate evidence that property in cyberspace is widely considered to be real estate
has a premise that presupposes what the argument attempts to show in the conclusion
itself provides significant evidence against the conclusion that it draws
fails to provide evidence that the similarities that constitute the analogy are anything but merely verbal
defends a view solely on the grounds that the view is held by many experts

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice is pretty tempting, but it misdescribes the author's analogy. The author doesn't argue that because real estate and websites share a few terms, websites should be considered real estate. The author argues that real estate and websites will continue to exist as separate entities, but real estate laws can be extended “to protect against encroachments on property in cyberspace.” Moreover, the author wouldn't need to provide evidence that “cyberspace is widely considered to be real estate” to argue that real estate laws can be applied to websites. The author would just have to convincingly argue that real estate and websites are similar enough—regardless of what people think about them—that the same laws can work for both areas.

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the relevant differences between real estate and websites. So, we can cross it off without thinking about it too deeply. Besides, this answer choice refers to “circular reasoning.” Circular reasoning occurs when the conclusion merely restates a premise. Arguments that rely on circular reasoning typically have this pattern on the LSAT: “X is true. We know this because, even when X doesn't appear to be true, X still must be true because X is always true.” This argument doesn't rely on circular reasoning. The author never establishes the claim that “it is reasonable to extend that law to protect against encroachments on property in cyberspace” as a premise.

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the relevant differences between real estate and websites. So, we can eliminate this without a second thought. Besides, it's not a flaw to provide “significant evidence against” your conclusion. The author cites that most lawyers think copyright law should protect websites. That's pretty good evidence against the author's conclusion, but that's OK. If the author provided even better evidence that most lawyers are wrong, the author's conclusion could still be persuasive. The author's issue is that they didn't provide adequate evidence to prove their conclusion.

Here we go! The correct answer should highlight the relevant differences between real estate and websites. If “the similarities that constitute the analogy are anything but merely verbal,” then real estate and websites don't really have much in common. If those two areas don't have much in common, it's not reasonable to extend real estate laws to websites. So, it is definitely a flaw that the author didn't provide evidence that their analogy was based on anything other than verbal similarities. We can justifiably select (D) and advance to the following question.

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will refer to the relevant differences between real estate and websites. So, we can toss this away without spending much time mulling it over. Besides, the author doesn't rely on experts to make this conclusion. In fact, if it's fair to call most lawyers “experts,” the author argues against the expert view!

items.stimulusText: Journalist: Contrary to popular opinion, it is more dangerous for an individual to drive during the day than during the night. A recent study found that in each of the last ten years, the number of traffic accidents that resulted in death was greater during the day than during the night.
items.stemText: Each of the following, if true, helps to strengthen the argument except:

options.optionContent: Only during the day are there more unsafe than safe vehicles on the road.
There is decreased law enforcement presence during the day.
Persons drive more cautiously during the night than during the day.
The number of travelers per vehicle has increased over the past ten years.
Persons drive faster during the day than during the night.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This one strengthens the argument by providing more stats that suggest the daytime is more dangerous. If most cars driving during the day are unsafe, then we'd expect the daytime to be the more dangerous time to drive.

This one strengthens the argument by providing more stats that suggest the daytime is more dangerous. If there is less law enforcement during the day, there are fewer people to stop dangerous drivers and unsafe vehicles before they harm someone else. That makes it more reasonable to conclude that the daytime is the more dangerous time to drive.

This one strengthens the argument by providing more stats that suggest the daytime is more dangerous. If people drive more recklessly during the day, then there should be a higher percentage of accidents during the day. This supports the journalist's argument that the daytime is the more dangerous time to drive.

This doesn't affect the journalist's argument, so it's the correct answer to this Bizarro Strengthen question. The number of people in each car may have increased over the last ten years, but that doesn't suggest that it's more dangerous to drive during the day. Maybe if a higher percentage of cars had more people during the day, then we could expect drivers to be more distracted during the day and thus more likely to get into accidents. But, this answer choice doesn't fill in those details. In fact, it doesn't tell us anything about daytime versus nighttime. Without differentiating those times, this can't meaningfully strengthen this argument.

This one strengthens the argument by providing more stats that suggest the daytime is more dangerous. If people drive faster during the day, then there should be a higher percentage of accidents at that time. This supports the journalist's argument that driving during the daytime is more dangerous.

items.stimulusText: Biologist: The evolutionary advantage of sexual reproduction is that it increases the range of genetic variation in a species, which is an advantage for the species as a whole. However, an increased range of genetic variation in a species is not advantageous for any individual member of the species. It follows that the sole reason that sexual reproduction has become the rule among both animals and plants is that natural selection has favored some entire species over others.
items.stemText: The claim that an increased range of genetic variation in a species is not advantageous for any individual member of the species plays which one of the following roles in the biologist's argument?

options.optionContent: It is a claim offered in support of the argument's conclusion.
It is presented to raise a question that sheds doubt on the argument's conclusion.
It is a claim that the argument is designed to call into question.
It describes an observed phenomenon for which the argument seeks an explanation.
It is presented as the main explanation of the origin of an observed phenomenon.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: There it is. We're looking for an answer choice that says the second sentence is a premise that supports the main conclusion. This answer choice says just that. Since we have a precise anticipation for this question and (A) matches that anticipation, we can confidently select (A) and advance to the following question.

Nope. The second sentence supports the argument's conclusion (by ruling out another way that sexual reproduction could have become the norm among species). So, the second sentence doesn't “ shed doubt”  (cast doubt) on the conclusion. It makes the conclusion more likely to be true!

Nope. The second sentence supports the argument's conclusion (by ruling out another way that sexual reproduction could have become the norm among species). So, the argument doesn't call the second sentence into question! The second sentence makes the argument more convincing!

Nope. The second sentence isn't an observed phenomenon. We can't walk out into nature and see that an increased range of genetic variation in a species is not advantageous for any individual member of the species. And even if the second sentence was a phenomenon, the conclusion doesn't explain that phenomenon. Instead, the conclusion uses that supposed “phenomenon” to rule out an alternative way that sexual reproduction could have become the norm among species.

Nope. The second sentence isn't an explanation for any other supposed “phenomenon” in this argument. Besides, when an argument has a Phenomenon/Explanation structure, the explanation is always the conclusion. The second sentence is a premise, which shows that it can't be a conclusion.

items.stimulusText: Columnist: Vagrancy laws are supposed to reduce criminal activity, but they don't. Making vagrancy illegal means transforming many innocuous everyday occurrences into crimes. Thus, vagrancy laws increase crime while purporting to reduce it.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the columnist's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument

options.optionContent: presumes, without providing any justification, that most innocuous everyday occurrences are harmful to society
mistakenly infers, from the claim that vagrancy laws are associated with an increase in many innocuous everyday occurrences, that vagrancy laws cause that increase
fails to specify what is meant by "innocuous everyday occurrences"
fails to consider the possibility that crime will increase even in the absence of vagrancy laws
does not adequately distinguish between an increase in criminal activity and the reclassification of certain occurrences as crimes

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: When we see “presumes, without providing justification” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the columnist doesn't believe that innocuous everyday occurrences are harmful to society. In fact, the whole notion of “innocuous everyday occurrences being harmful to society” is oxymoronic. “Innocuous” literally means “harmless.” Besides, the author never claims or implies that anything related to vagrancy is harmful to society. This is enough reason to eliminate (A). If you were relying on the backup plan for this question, we can make this answer choice easier to read by replacing “presumes, without providing justification” with “assumes.” Here's the paragraph we'd read to test this answer choice: “Some people argue that vagrancy laws do not decrease criminal activity because vagrancy laws transform many harmless behaviors into crimes, therefore increasing crime. But, that argument assumes that that most innocuous everyday occurrences are harmful to society. So, vagrancy laws might reduce criminal activity.” That paragraph doesn't make any sense. The argument doesn't appear to assume that most innocuous everyday occurrences are harmful to society. In fact, it appears to assume the opposite—that vagrancy laws take harmless behaviors and make them crimes. Secondly, even if the argument assumed that those innocuous everyday occurrences were harmful to society, that would undermine the notion that vagrancy might reduce criminal activity! Before vagrancy laws, everyday activity was harmful and legal. After vagrancy laws, everyday activity became harmful and illegal. That sounds like vagrancy laws increased crime to us! Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (A).

This misdescribes the columnist's argument. The columnist never establishes that vagrancy laws are associated with an increase in many innocuous everyday occurrences. In fact, the columnist never says that there is an increase of many innocuous everyday occurrences. The columnist instead says that vagrancy laws take the innocuous everyday occurrences that were already happening and transform them into crimes. For this reason, we can cross off (B). If you were relying on the backup plan for this question, here's the paragraph we'd read to test this answer choice (note that we re-arranged the answer choice a bit to make it easier to read): “Some people argue that vagrancy laws do not decrease criminal activity because vagrancy laws transform many harmless behaviors into crimes, therefore increasing crime. But, that argument mistakenly concludes that vagrancy laws cause an increase in many innocuous everyday occurrences, from the claim that vagrancy laws are associated with that increase. So, vagrancy laws might reduce criminal activity.” That paragraph doesn't make any sense. First, the argument never says that there is an “increase in many innocuous everyday occurrences” associated with vagrancy laws. So, the part that follows “But” seems inaccurate. Moreover, the “But” part acknowledges that there is an increase in innocuous everyday occurrences. If those occurrences are now classified as crimes under vagrancy laws, then it sounds like vagrancy laws increase crime. That makes the “So” part sound false. Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (B).

This isn't a flaw. The columnist doesn't have to define “innocuous everyday occurrences” to convincingly reach this conclusion. As long as the columnist establishes that vagrancy laws don't reduce any criminal activity and only reclassify non-criminal, innocuous everyday occurrences as crimes, the columnist can reach this conclusion without defining what they mean by “innocuous everyday occurrences.” For this reason, we can cross off (C). If you were relying on the backup plan for this question, here's the paragraph we'd read to test this answer choice: “Some people argue that vagrancy laws do not decrease criminal activity because vagrancy laws transform many harmless behaviors into crimes, therefore increasing crime. But, that argument fails to specify what is meant by 'innocuous everyday occurrences.' So, vagrancy laws might reduce criminal activity.” That paragraph doesn't make any sense. The fact that the argument doesn't specify what “innocuous everyday occurrences” means doesn't prove that vagrancy laws might reduce criminal activity. The “But” and the “So” sentences sound unrelated and disconnected, which is a strong signal that this answer choice does not point out a flaw in the argument's reasoning.

When we see “fails to consider” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the argument if it were true?” In this case, crime increasing in the absence of vagrancy laws would not weaken the conclusion that vagrancy laws do not reduce criminal activity. “Crime” is a broad enough term that there could be multiple, unconnected increases. For instance, vagrancy laws could increase criminal activity by, as this columnist says, reclassifying everyday occurrences into crimes. Separate and apart from this phenomenon, there could be a nationwide increase in shoplifting. Even without the vagrancy laws, there would still be this nationwide increase in shoplifting. Still, we could say that the vagrancy laws increase criminal activity, as they're adding to the number of crimes on top of the nationwide increase in shoplifting. So, the fact that some crimes could increase without vagrancy laws doesn't undermine the notion that vagrancy laws increase criminal activity. This is enough reason to eliminate (C). If you were relying on the backup plan for this question, here's the paragraph we'd read to test this answer choice: “Some people argue that vagrancy laws do not decrease criminal activity because vagrancy laws transform many harmless behaviors into crimes, therefore increasing crime. But, that argument fails to consider the possibility that crime will increase even in the absence of vagrancy laws. So, vagrancy laws might reduce criminal activity.” That paragraph doesn't make much sense. Even if crime would increase without vagrancy laws, vagrancy laws could still add to the total number of crimes. So, the “But” part doesn't provide strong evidence supporting the “So” part. This is a strong signal that this answer choice does not point out a flaw in the argument's reasoning.

This one points out the flaw that eagle-eyed test-takers may have noticed. There's a big difference between the conclusion and the premise and premise/conclusion: the former discusses “criminal activity,” while the latter discusses “crime.” Those aren't necessarily the same thing. Increased criminal activity sounds like more people are out there committing crimes. There's more theft, vandalism, assaults, etc. But an increase in “crime” based on the reclassification of formerly legal, harmless activity? That doesn't sound like it's the same thing as an increase in “criminal activity.” If we reclassify harmless behavior as “crimes,” we won't necessarily see a spike in theft, vandalism, assault, etc. So, it's a problem that the author doesn't “adequately distinguish” these two things. The argument would be much more persuasive if it said, “The amount of criminal activity may stay the same under vagrancy laws, but vagrancy laws will increase the number of crimes committed.” Moreover, even if vagrancy laws increase the amount of crimes committed, it could still decrease the amount of criminal activity. Perhaps knowing they can get cited for violating vagrancy laws will compel “vagrants” from doing other crimes. If loitering is now illegal under vagrancy laws, perhaps people won't loiter or commit the other crimes they typically commit while loitering. That would reduce the amount of criminal activity, even if it increases the number of crimes. If you were relying on the backup plan for this question, here's the paragraph we'd read to test this answer choice: “Some people argue that vagrancy laws do not decrease criminal activity because vagrancy laws transform many harmless behaviors into crimes, therefore increasing crime. But, that argument does not adequately distinguish between an increase in criminal activity and the reclassification of certain occurrences as crimes. So, vagrancy laws might reduce criminal activity.” That paragraph makes sense. Yes, the number of crimes might increase once vagrancy laws reclassify previously legal behaviors as crimes. But that doesn't necessarily mean the amount of criminal activity will go up. Vagrancy laws might compel “vagrants” to engage in less criminal activity (like theft, vandalism, and assault), even if it adds to the number of crimes by reclassifying previously legal behavior as crimes. Whichever method we use, we can select (E) with confidence.

items.stimulusText: Political theorist: The purpose of government is to prevent individuals from injuring others in the pursuit of their own welfare. Hence, if most individuals take a reasoned approach to getting what they want, the power of government should be less.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the political theorist's argument?

options.optionContent: Governments alone are not able to convince individuals to take a reasoned approach to getting what they want.
Government can serve its purpose without diminishing people's ability to promote their own welfare.
People who take a reasoned approach to getting what they want are less likely to injure other people than are those who do not.
People who injure other people in the pursuit of their own welfare will eventually be treated in the same fashion by others.
The more interest people have in promoting their own welfare, the less likely they are to be injured by others.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't even strengthen the argument, so it can't be necessary to the argument either. The conclusion is an “if-then” statement that puts the “people take a reasoned approach to getting what they want” in the “if” part of the premise. When strengthening an argument, we don't have to worry about making the “if” part come true. The conclusion is already assuming that the “if” part is true. In fact, we can treat the “if” part as a premise if that makes more sense to us. Rather than worrying about making the “if” part come true, we should focus on strengthening the “then” part. In this argument, that would involve showing that a reasoned approach to getting what you want involves not injuring other people. So, this answer choice, which only addresses whether governments can make the “if” part happen, does not strengthen the argument. (And, for what it's worth, this answer choice only makes the “if” part less likely to be true.) For that reason, we can cross (A) off. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we're using the negated form of answer choice (A)): “Governments are supposed to prevent people who are trying to get what they want from injuring other people. But, governments alone can convince individuals to take a reasoned approach to getting what they want. So, even if most people take a reasoned approach to getting what they want, the government should not necessarily be less powerful.” This argument doesn't flow naturally. The first premise suggests that governments don't need to be powerful if people aren't injuring each other as they try to get what they want. The “But” part says governments can convince people to take a reasoned approach to getting what they want. That doesn't conflict with the previous sentence, as it seems to align with the government's purpose. So, the “But” makes the second sentence sound a bit awkward. Finally, the conclusion suggests that governments should maintain their power. But if people are reasonable while trying to get what they want, then governments don't need to fulfill their duty of convincing people to be reasonable, and governments probably should be less powerful. So, the conclusion doesn't seem to follow from the “But” statement, either. This means (A) does not pass the backup test. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (A).

This answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument, so it's not necessary to the argument, either. The theorist's conclusion doesn't address whether people actually can “promote their own welfare.” It doesn't say that people actually can get what they want. Instead, the theorist's conclusion only addresses whether the government's power should be reduced if most people take a “reasoned” approach to getting what they want. Whether people eventually get what they want doesn't matter as long as they don't hurt other people along the way. So, this answer choice, which suggests that people can get what they want even when the government keeps them from harming each other, is irrelevant to the argument. For this reason, we can cross off (B). Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we're using the negated form of answer choice (B)): “Governments are supposed to prevent people who are trying to get what they want from injuring other people. But, the government cannot serve its purpose without diminishing people's ability to promote their own welfare. So, even if most people take a reasoned approach to getting what they want, the government should not necessarily be less powerful.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. The “But” part suggests that the government gets in the way of people getting what they want. That sounds like a reason to reduce the government's power if you ask us. Especially if, as the “So” part says, most people are reasonable as they pursue what they want. These facts suggest that the government should have less power—not more, as the conclusion says. Since this conclusion doesn't follow logically, (B) doesn't pass the backup test. No matter our approach, we can confidently cross off (B).

Bingo. This answer choice strengthens the argument. It's also necessary to the argument. This answer choice strengthens the argument by establishing that taking a reasoned approach to getting what you want involves not injuring other people. If people who take a reasoned approach are less likely to injure other people, then the government will have less work to do. After all, the government's purpose is just to stop people from hurting each other as the people pursue their wants. If most people take a reasoned approach, the government will have much less work to do, and its powers should probably be reduced. We also need to know this to draw the conclusion. If people who take a reasoned approach to pursuing their wants hurt others in the process, then the government would have a lot of work to do, even if most people take a reasoned approach. The government would need power to stop people from hurting each other as they pursued their wants. Therefore, if this answer choice weren't true, we couldn't draw this conclusion. That proves that this answer choice is necessary to this argument. Alternatively, we can also evaluate this answer choice using the backup plan. Here's the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we negated and simplified this answer choice to make this easier to read): “Governments are supposed to prevent people who are trying to get what they want from injuring other people. But, people who take a reasoned approach to getting what they want are just as likely to injure other people as those who do not. So, even if most people take a reasoned approach to getting what they want, the government should not necessarily be less powerful.” This makes sense. If people who take a reasoned approach to getting what they want are just as likely to hurt other people, then the government will need to maintain its power to stop these people from hurting others. Since this argument makes sense, (C) passes the backup test. Therefore, no matter which approach we used, we can be confident that (C) is the correct answer.

This doesn't even strengthen the argument, so it can't be necessary to the argument either. This answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument because it makes it more likely that people will injure each other as they pursue their wants. If (D) is true, even if just a few people start injuring others, it'll eventually lead to other people injuring them as others pursue their wants. (D) would create a cascading effect, where more and more people injure each other as they pursue their wants. This would require more government intervention, not less. So, this answer choice weakens the theorist's conclusion by showing how more government power might be needed to prevent people from injuring others. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we're using the negated form of answer choice (D)): “Governments are supposed to prevent people who are trying to get what they want from injuring other people. But, people who injure other people in the pursuit of their own welfare will not be treated in the same fashion by others. So, even if most people take a reasoned approach to getting what they want, the government should not necessarily be less powerful.” This argument doesn't make sense. The “But” part tells us that injuring others won't lead to more harmful behavior. That suggests that the government doesn't need to do much to prevent people from injuring each other as they pursue their wants. But the conclusion says that even if people are being reasonable as they pursue their wants, the government might need more power. That doesn't follow. The “But” part made it seem like the government doesn't need to do much when a person injures others. So, why would the government need more power when people are being reasonable? This conclusion doesn't follow logically, so it doesn't pass the backup test. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (D).

This doesn't strengthen the argument. Therefore, it's not necessary to the argument either. This answer choice doesn't strengthen because it doesn't tell us whether people who are being reasonable as they promote their own interest will injure other people. This answer choice says people who are promoting their own interests won't be injured, but will they injure others? Is there a difference when they're pursuing their interests reasonably? This answer choice doesn't say, so it won't strengthen the theorists' conclusion that the government's power should be reduced if people are pursuing their welfare reasonably. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “Governments are supposed to prevent people who are trying to get what they want from injuring other people. But, it's not true that the more interest people have in promoting their own welfare, the less likely they are to be injured by others. So, even if most people take a reasoned approach to getting what they want, the government should not necessarily be less powerful.” This argument doesn't make sense. The “But” part doesn't tell us whether people pursuing their own wants will injure other people. But it does suggest that these people won't be injured by others. So, the “But” part makes it sound like there won't be many injuries. In that case, why should the government be more powerful, as the “So” part contends? This conclusion doesn't follow logically, so it doesn't pass the backup test. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (E).

items.stimulusText: Food critic: One of the chief competitors of Chris's restaurant claims that Chris's okra supplier cannot reliably supply fresh okra. If this claim were true, Chris's customers could not count on getting good seafood gumbo, Chris's specialty, because the best seafood gumbo requires fresh okra.
items.stemText: The food critic's argument is most subject to criticism because it

options.optionContent: relies upon testimony that is likely to be biased
illicitly presumes that a dish must lack a certain quality if one of its ingredients lacks that quality
confuses a necessary condition for the best seafood gumbo with a sufficient condition for good seafood gumbo
takes for granted that a necessary ingredient of the best seafood gumbo is also a necessary ingredient of good seafood gumbo
fails to consider the possibility that on some days Chris's might be serving seafood gumbo made with fresh okra

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will say something like, “assumes that a requirement for the best okra is also a requirement for good okra.” So, we can cross off (A) without thinking about it too deeply. Besides, the food critic doesn't rely on anyone's testimony in this argument. The food critic responds to one of Chris's competitors, who may be biased against Chris, but the food critic doesn't rely on the competitor's testimony. You only rely on someone's testimony when you use the testimony as one of your premises. The food critic disagrees with the competitor and tries to disprove them in this argument. That's a far cry from using the competitor's testimony as a premise!

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will say something like, “assumes that a requirement for the best okra is also a requirement for good okra.” We can cross off (B) once we notice that it deviates from our anticipation. Besides, the food critic doesn't argue that a dish lacks a quality if one of the ingredients lacks that quality. That would look like this: “Since Chris doesn't use good okra, his seafood gumbo isn't good.” That's not the argument this critic makes. The food critic just concludes that Chris couldn't make good gumbo without fresh okra. “Good” and “fresh” are two different qualities, so this flaw isn't present in the critic's argument.

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will say something like, “assumes that a requirement for the best okra is also a requirement for good okra.” So, we can cross off (C) without spending too much time thinking about it. This argument does not commit the “converse” flaw or “illegal reversal” this answer choice describes. The food critic establishes, as a premise, that fresh okra is necessary for the best seafood gumbo. But the food critic's conclusion doesn't assert that fresh okra is sufficient for the best seafood gumbo. Instead, the food critic argues that fresh okra is necessary for “Good” seafood gumbo.

This answer choice matches our anticipation that the correct answer will say something like, “assumes that a requirement for the best okra is also a requirement for good okra.” The food critic establishes that fresh okra is necessary for the best seafood gumbo. The food critic then concludes that fresh okra is necessary for good seafood gumbo, as Chris couldn't make good seafood gumbo without it. However, just because you'd need to use fresh okra to make the best seafood gumbo doesn't mean you'd have to use fresh okra to make seafood gumbo that is merely good. Because this answer choice closely matches our anticipated flaw, we can select (D) and give the remaining answer choice a quick once-over.

This doesn't match our anticipation that the correct answer will say something like, “assumes that a requirement for the best okra is also a requirement for good okra.” So, we can cross off (E) without hesitating. Besides, the food critic doesn't overlook the possibility that Chris's might occasionally serve seafood gumbo made with fresh okra. In fact, the food critic assumes that Chris always serves seafood gumbo with fresh okra.
