Otherwise, the critic wouldn't say that Chris's customers “couldn't count on getting good seafood gumbo, Chris's specialty,” if Chris couldn't reliably source fresh okra.

items.stimulusText: Ants sometimes live in hollow places in the roots of a certain orchid species. Those orchids of that species that house ants are far healthier than those that do not. Since the ants store organic matter in the orchids' roots, an explanation for the superior health of the orchids that house ants is that the organic matter stored by the ants provides those orchids with additional nutrients.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, is an alternative explanation for the better health of orchids that house the ants?

options.optionContent: Microscopic organisms that are present in the orchids' roots break down the organic matter stored there by the ants.
The nutrients present in the organic matter stored by the ants are the same as those present in the soil in which the orchids are found.
The ants that live in hollow places in the roots of orchids prey on an insect species whose members eat the orchids' roots.
The ants that live in hollow places in the roots of orchids do not play a role in pollinating the flowers of the plant.
Most plant species whose roots, stems, or leaves harbor insects are more prone to disease and rot than are other plants.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't provide another explanation of why orchids that house ants are healthier than orchids that do not. If these microorganisms that break down the organic matter help the orchids' roots obtain nutrients from the matter, then this is entirely consistent with the passage's explanation. If the microorganisms do not help the roots get nutrients from the organic matter, then this may undermine the passage's explanation. However, this still wouldn't explain how the ants help the orchids be healthier. Therefore, this answer choice doesn't address the question proposed by the question stem.

This doesn't provide another explanation of why orchids that house ants are healthier than orchids that do not. Even if the organic matter's nutrients are already present in the soil, the ants could provide the orchids even more nutrients, helping the orchids become healthy. So, this answer choice is entirely consistent with the passage's explanation.

Here we go. This answer choice provides a different explanation of why orchids that house ants are healthier than orchids that do not. According to this answer choice, the ants may not help the orchids by providing them nutrients. Instead, the ants help the orchids by fending off insects that eat the orchids' roots. Orchids that do not house ants would not have this protection, so it makes sense that the ant-less orchids would be less healthy. This answer choice provides an alternative explanation. We can justifiably select it and give the remaining options an, at most, cursory read.

This doesn't provide another explanation of why orchids that house ants are healthier than orchids that do not. If the ants did play a role in pollinating the flowers of the plant, that would be an alternative explanation for how the ants make the orchids healthier. But this answer choice says the ants do not play this role, so this answer choice does not address the question posed by the question stem.

This doesn't provide another explanation of why orchids that house ants are healthier than orchids that do not. Even if most plant species that harbor insects are more prone to disease and rot, some orchids could still benefit from ants. So, this doesn't necessarily weaken the argument. Even if did, it doesn't weaken the argument by providing an alternative explanation of why orchids that house ants are healthier. Therefore, this answer choice does not address the question posed by the question stem.

items.stimulusText: Future overall demand for professors can be predicted with reasonable accuracy from current birth rates. But the accuracy of predictions of future demand for music professors is lower, and that for jazz studies professors lower still.
items.stemText: The situation described above best illustrates which one of the following principles?

options.optionContent: The more detailed and complete the evidence, the more precise predictions based on that evidence are.
The more general the level of a prediction, the more accurate it is.
Predicting future trends becomes more difficult as the events those predictions concern become more temporally remote.
The more detailed and complete the evidence, the more confidence we can have in predictions based on that evidence.
Predictions based only on general trends are unlikely to be accurate.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage doesn't tell us our predictions become more precise or accurate when we use “more detailed and complete” evidence. The evidence doesn't change—it's always based on the current birth rates.

The correct answer should say something like, “Our predictions sometimes become less accurate the more specific they are.” This gives us the other side of that idea—that our predictions become more accurate the more general they are. That's totally supported by the passage since the most accurate prediction was the most general one. This answer choice would certainly be better if it was stated in weaker, easier-to-support language. So, it's a good idea to see if any remaining options match our anticipation but use softer, more justifiable language. If none match our anticipation, we'll put aside our reservations and select this option.

The passage doesn't describe predicting the demand for professors at different, “more temporally remote” points in the future. The passage didn't make predictions for the demand 10 years from now, 20 years from now, 50 years from now, and so on. So, this statement isn't illustrated by the passage.

The passage doesn't tell us we can make more confident predictions when we use “more detailed and complete” evidence. The evidence the passage references doesn't change—it's always based on the current birth rates.
The passage illustrates that some predictions based on general trends can be accurate: we can predict the demand for professors based on current birth rate trends.

items.stimulusText: Anarchist: People can either fight for anarchy or they can tolerate totalitarian government control. But history shows that government control of all facets of human life destroys the spirit, making life miserable. So, people should fight for anarchy, which allows each individual the freedom to pursue a personal course of happiness.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the argument's reasoning?

options.optionContent: Governments provide many social goods, and the argument does not attempt to explain why anarchy is a desirable alternative to government control of all facets of human life.
By asserting that people both should and should not tolerate totalitarian government, the argument contradicts itself.
The argument infers from the assertion that people should fight for anarchy that totalitarianism is objectionable.
The argument offers no indication that there is evidence for its claim that totalitarianism destroys the spirit and makes life miserable.
The argument sets out anarchy and totalitarianism as the only two political alternatives that are available.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: No, this answer choice makes a factually untrue statement. The anarchist does attempt to explain why anarchy is a desirable alternative to totalitarianism. The anarchist says that “government control of all facets of human life destroys the spirit, making life miserable.” That's definitely a reason why anarchy is a better alternative. The problem with the anarchist's argument is that the anarchist doesn't compare the problems with totalitarianism with the problems of anarchy, not that the anarchist didn't offer any reasons why anarchy might be better.

Again, this answer choice makes a factually untrue statement. The anarchist never says that people “should” tolerate totalitarian governments. The anarchist says people can tolerate such governments (or, alternatively, fight for anarchy), but the anarchist never says that people should tolerate totalitarianism.

This answer choice makes another factually untrue statement. The anarchist doesn't infer the claim that totalitarianism is objectionable from the premise that people should fight for anarchy. This gets the direction of support backward. The anarchist establishes that totalitarianism is objectionable as a premise. From that premise, the anarchist infers the claim that people should fight for anarchy.

This is another factually untrue statement. The anarchist offers evidence that totalitarianism destroys the spirit and makes life miserable. The anarchist says that “history shows that” totalitarianism leads to these consequences. That's nebulous evidence, for sure, but evidence nonetheless. Besides, even if the anarchist didn't say, “history shows that,” that would be OK. The anarchist establishes that totalitarianism destroys the spirit and makes life miserable as a premise. On Errors in Reasoning questions, we have to accept premises as true.

Sure, the anarchist does this. And, after having good reason to eliminate the remaining answer choices, we have to reluctantly select this one. But we're just going to say it: if this is the correct answer, this is a poorly written question. The anarchist indeed establishes anarchy and totalitarianism as the only available political alternatives. However, the anarchist does this as a premise. On Errors in Reasoning questions, we're supposed to accept the premises as true. We're supposed to analyze why those premises aren't enough to prove that the conclusion or a premise/conclusion is true. Every other Errors in Reasoning question plays by this rule (save one other poorly written question from an early LSAT), so we're not sure why this question doesn't follow this well-established convention. If the anarchist supported the claim that “People can either fight for anarchy or they can tolerate totalitarian government control” with another premise, (E) would be an unproblematic answer. But since that claim is clearly just a premise, this answer choice doesn't describe a flaw in the argument's reasoning. So, the moral of the story is that the people who make the LSAT are human, and sometimes they make mistakes. This question is one of those mistakes. It doesn't surprise us that this question was released as the “experimental” section of a Prep Test. We don't think this question would show up on a real section that counted toward your final score. More than anything, don't get the wrong idea from this question. Trying to look for answer choices that say “maybe the premise isn't true” will be a waste of time on other Errors in Reasoning questions. If you got this question correct, that's great. That means you understand how to eliminate answer choices that misdescribe the argument on an Errors in Reasoning question. That's a vital skill. But if you got this question wrong because you thought (E) argues with a premise, don't sweat it. That's the right instinct to have on Errors in Reasoning questions.

items.stimulusText: Consumer demand for personal computers continues to increase each year, which might lead one to think that the profits earned selling personal computers at the retail level are very high relative to total retail sales of personal computers. Yet the retail profit margin on personal computer sales is extremely low compared to that of other popular high-technology items.
items.stemText: Each of the following, if true, helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy described above except:

options.optionContent: Rapid innovation in computer technology increases the likelihood of a store's stock becoming obsolete.
Satisfaction with their first personal computer tends to make customers very loyal to that particular brand.
A customer needs more help from store employees when buying a personal computer than when buying other high-technology items.
Many retail stores have low prices on personal computers in order to bring in customers who might buy software and accessories.
An increase in the number of discount retail outlets selling personal computers has intensified the competition for customers.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This explains why retail stores have low profit margins on computers, despite computers' high demand. If retail stores' stock of computers is constantly becoming obsolete, these stores may have trouble selling out their stock. They'd have to consign or sell these obsolete computers at a deep discount, losing money on the transactions. This would cut into the overall retail profit margins on computers.

This doesn't explain why retail stores have low profit margins on computers despite computers' high demand. So, this is the correct answer to this Bizarro Paradox question. Customers may be loyal to a particular computer brand, but they could still return to retail stores to purchase that brand over and over again. This answer choice doesn't suggest why retailers wouldn't earn high profits from customers, so it doesn't explain the surprising fact from this passage.

This explains why retail stores have low profit margins on computers despite computers' high demand. If customers need a lot of help from employees, retail stores must employ many people in the computer department. This makes running this department more costly, cutting into the overall retail profit margins on computers.

This explains why retail stores have low profit margins on computers despite computers' high demand. If retail stores offer deep discounts on computers to lure customers in, they won't make as much money on computers as they will on other tech products. Therefore, we'd expect the stores' overall profit margins on computers to be lower.

This explains why retail stores have low profit margins on computers despite computers' high demand. If many discount retail outlets sell personal computers, there's a high supply of computers, which would offset the increased demand. Moreover, since these are “discount” retail outlets, we'd expect each retailer to have to offer discounts on computers to remain competitive. Both of these factors would lead to retail stores earning lower profits on computers than they will on other tech products.

items.stimulusText: If a film is accepted by the festival committee, then one of the distributors attending the festival buys it. If a distributor buys a film, the film's financial backers are assured of recouping their investment. This film was not accepted by the festival committee, so this film's financial backers will not recoup their investment.
items.stemText: Which one of the following arguments employs a flawed pattern of reasoning most similar to the flawed pattern of reasoning in the argument above?

options.optionContent: If a film has a good story, it will be praised by critics. If a film is praised by critics, it will do well at the box office. This film did not do well at the box office, so it must not have a good story.

If a film features several stars, it will be successful at the box office. A box office success has a long run at theaters. This film features only one star, so it will not have a long run at theaters.

If a film is directed by a talented artist, it will be praised by critics. If a film is praised by critics, it will do well on video. This film did well on video, so it was directed by a talented artist.

If a film is a box office success, then one of its stars is nominated for an award. If a star receives an award, the film is assured of doing well on video. This star was not nominated for an award, so the film will not do well on video.

If a film has a big budget, it will be heavily promoted. A heavily promoted film will be released all over the country at once. This film has a big budget, so it will be released all over the country at once.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice's conclusion resembles the passage's conclusion that “this film's financial backers will not recoup their investment.” Like that conclusion, this answer choice's conclusion is a factual “NOT” claim. So, we can translate these premises to see if the rest of the argument lines up with the passage's: P1: if Good story, then Critics praise P2: if Critics praise, then Good box office P3: NOT good box office. Conclusion: NOT good story. Unlike the argument in the passage, this argument is valid. Because the film does not have a good box office, we can validly conclude that it doesn't have a good story either. Since this argument is valid, we can eliminate it.

This answer choice's conclusion resembles the passage's conclusion that “this film's financial backers will not recoup their investment.” Like that conclusion, this answer choice's conclusion is a factual “NOT” claim. So, we can translate these premises to see if the rest of the argument lines up with the passage's (note the the second premise is a “universal” statement, as we can translate it to “all box office successes ...” without altering the meaning of the statement): P1: if Several stars, then Good box office P2: if Good box office, then Long run P3: NOT several stars. Conclusion: NOT long run. This matches the flaw in the passage's argument. Like the passage, we can connect P1 and P2 to conclude, “if Several stars, then Long run.” This answer choice's conclusion, however, assumes that if the film does not have several stars, it will not have a long run at the box office. Because this answer choice commits the same flaw as the passage, we can select it.

This answer choice's conclusion doesn't resemble the passage's conclusion that “this film's financial backers will not recoup their investment.” Although this answer choice's conclusion is also a factual claim, it isn't a “NOT” claim. That's enough to table this answer choice for now and move on to the next one. If we did translate this answer choice's argument, here's what we'd get: P1: if Talented director, then Critics praise P2: if Critics praise, then Do well on video P3: Do well on video Conclusion: Talented director. This isn't quite the same flaw as the passage. If we connect P1 and P2, we can reach the conclusion “if Talented director, then Do well on video.” This answer choice's conclusion, however, assumes that if the film does well on video, then it must have a talented director. Because this answer choice commits a slightly different flaw than the passage, we can cross it off.

This answer choice's conclusion resembles the passage's conclusion that “this film's financial backers will not recoup their investment.” Like that conclusion, this answer choice's conclusion is a factual “NOT” claim. So, we can translate these premises to see if the rest of the argument lines up with the passage's: P1: if Box office success, then Star nominated P2: if Star receives award, then Do well on video P3: NOT star nominated. Conclusion: NOT do well on video. This doesn't match the flaw in the passage's argument. In the passage, we could connect P1 and P2. In this argument, we cannot. A star being nominated for an award doesn't mean that the star receives the award. Moreover, unlike the passage, the factual premise doesn't deny the P1's “if” condition—it denies P1's “then” condition. Although this argument is flawed, it commits more flaws than the passage.

This answer choice's conclusion doesn't resemble the passage's conclusion that “this film's financial backers will not recoup their investment.” Although this answer choice's conclusion is also a factual claim, it isn't a “NOT” claim. That's enough to table this answer choice for now and review any answer choice we haven't already eliminated. If we did translate this answer choice's argument, here's what we'd get: P1: if Big budget, then Heavily promoted P2: if Heavily promoted, then Released all over P3: Big budget. Conclusion: Released all over. Unlike the argument in the passage, this argument is valid. If we connect P1 and P2, we can reach the conclusion “if Big budget, then Released all over.” Because the film has a big budget, we can validly conclude that it will be released all over the country at once. Since this argument is valid, we can eliminate it.

items.stimulusText: Psychologist: In an experiment, business managers who normally drank coffee on a daily basis were given more than their normal amount. The managers got faster at processing new information, but were less able to integrate it with past information when making decisions. Because successful management depends more on integrating information than on speed, this study demonstrates that drinking more coffee than usual impairs overall management ability.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the psychologist's argument depends?

options.optionContent: The business managers in the experiment were different from each other in both the speed at which they processed information and in their ability to integrate information.
Drinking less coffee than usual would not impede a manager's overall management ability as much as would drinking more coffee than usual.
There is no other factor that is more important to successful business management than either speed of processing information or ability to integrate it.
In the experiment, drinking more coffee than usual did not have beneficial effects on overall management ability that outweighed the reduction in ability to integrate past information.
The amount of coffee one drinks is the most important factor influencing the speed at which one processes new information.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't even strengthen the argument, so it can't be necessary to the argument either. The conclusion asserts that drinking more coffee than usual “impairs” overall management ability. That's a relative claim—drinking excess coffee decreased each manager's ability from where it started. So, it doesn't matter that the managers' abilities weren't all the same. It's perfectly acceptable if some managers' abilities had different starting points or if coffee affected some managers more than others. As long as drinking excess coffee made their abilities worse, the psychologist can still draw the conclusion. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we're using a negated and simplified form of answer choice (A)): “A study gave coffee-drinking managers even more coffee. The managers processed information faster but had trouble incorporating it with past information. Successful management depends more on incorporating new information than speed. But, the managers did not differ in their speed or ability to incorporate new information. So, the study doesn't prove that drinking more coffee than usual decreases overall management ability.” This argument doesn't make much sense. The “But” part doesn't really conflict with the previous claims that the managers processed information faster but had trouble incorporating it with past information. Rather than contrasting with that evidence, the “But” part just adds to the information. The managers got faster but had trouble incorporating new information ... and now their speeds and ability to incorporate information are all the same. The “But” part should form a natural contrast with the previous statements if an answer choice is going to pass the backup test. Moreover, the “But” part doesn't show that drinking more coffee improves overall management ability. If the managers are now all worse at an important part of their job, it seems more reasonable to conclude that drinking more coffee decreases overall management ability. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (A).

This answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument, so it's not necessary to the argument, either. The psychologist's conclusion is only about drinking more coffee than usual. The psychologist doesn't make any claims about drinking less coffee than usual, so this answer choice is irrelevant to the argument. After all, even if drinking less coffee than usual was just as bad as drinking more coffee than usual, it could still be true that drinking more coffee than usual impairs one's managerial abilities. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we're using a negated and simplified form of answer choice (B)): “A study gave coffee-drinking managers even more coffee. The managers processed information faster but had trouble incorporating it with past information. Successful management depends more on incorporating new information than speed. But, drinking less coffee than usual would impede a manager's overall management ability as much as drinking more coffee than usual. So, the study doesn't prove that drinking more coffee than usual decreases overall management ability.” This argument doesn't make much sense. In fact, the “But” concedes that drinking more coffee than usual does, in fact, “impede a manager's overall management ability,” which would “prove that drinking more coffee than usual decreases overall management ability.” No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (B).

This answer choice is very tempting! This definitely strengthens the argument. If there are no factors more important to management than speed and incorporating new information—and incorporating new information is more important than speed—then it seems much more likely that making managers worse at incorporating new information means that drinking excess coffee decreases overall management ability. But the next question is whether this information is necessary to the argument. And this answer choice uses a SCOTUS-y phrase—the superlative “no other factor more important .... than“—that we don't like to see in a Strengthen with Necessary Premise answer choice. And that phrase makes this answer choice a bit too boldly worded to present a necessary piece of information. Even if there are factors more important to business management than speed and incorporating new information, this psychologist could still draw this conclusion. Let's suppose that the most important factor in successful business management is always starting an email with “I hope this email finds you well.” Incorporating new information and speed are the second and third most important factors, respectively. Let's also suppose that drinking too much coffee didn't impair any manager's ability to start emails with “I hope this email finds you well.” In that case, the excess coffee would still make the managers worse at management, even if it didn't affect the most important part of their job. The excess coffee would still make them worse at the second most important factor. After all, the issue isn't whether speed and incorporating new information are the most important skills. The issue is whether decreasing their ability to incorporate new information is enough to guarantee that overall management ability is worse. We don't need to know that incorporating new information is the most important factor. We just need to know that excess coffee didn't improve enough other factors to outweigh its detrimental effect on incorporating new information. And this answer choice doesn't tell us that. Alternatively, we can also evaluate this answer choice using the backup plan. Here's the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we negated and simplified this answer choice to make this easier to read): “A study gave coffee-drinking managers even more coffee. The managers processed information faster but had trouble incorporating it with past information. Successful management depends more on incorporating new information than speed. But, there may be factors more important to management than speed and incorporating new information and speed. So, the study doesn't prove that drinking more coffee than usual decreases overall management ability.” This, admittedly, doesn't sound bad. However, it still runs up against the problem we identified earlier in this answer choice's explanation. Even if there might be more important factors, we don't know how excess coffee affects those factors. If excess coffee might harm those factors, the study may still prove that drinking more coffee than usual decreases management ability. Therefore, no matter which approach we used, we can eliminate (C).

Let's go. This answer choice strengthens the argument. It's also necessary to the argument. This answer choice strengthens the argument by showing that excess coffee's benefits don't outweigh the harm done by decreasing one's ability to integrate old and new information. This definitely strengthens the argument, as it shows that any benefits that excess coffee may bring to the table will still be negated by the reduced ability to integrate new and old information. This will help the psychologist draw the conclusion that excess coffee impairs overall management ability. This is also necessary to the argument. If drinking more coffee than usual had benefits that outweighed the reduced ability to incorporate new information, then the psychologist couldn't conclude that excess coffee impairs overall management ability. In that case, the psychologist would have to conclude that excess coffee improves management ability. So, the psychologist needs this answer choice to be true to draw their conclusion. Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we're using the negated and simplified version of answer choice (D)): “A study gave coffee-drinking managers even more coffee. The managers processed information faster but had trouble incorporating it with past information. Successful management depends more on incorporating new information than speed. But, the study also shows that drinking more coffee than usual produced benefits that outweighed the reduction in managers' ability to incorporate information. So, the study doesn't prove that drinking more coffee than usual decreases overall management ability.” This argument makes sense! The “But” part forms a clear contrast with the information that came before it, and the conclusion follows naturally from the “But” part. Yes, excess coffee harmed the managers' ability to incorporate information. Buuuuuut, excess coffee's benefits outweighed that downside. So, excess coffee may not decrease overall management ability. This argument sounds like a well-written, cogent paragraph. So, (D) passes the backup test. No matter our approach, we can confidently select (D).

This doesn't strengthen the argument. Therefore, it's not necessary to the argument either. This answer choice doesn't strengthen because it doesn't tell us about coffee's effect on incorporating information or any other factor related to management ability. We already know that excess coffee increases speed. But we also know that speed is less important than the ability to incorporate information, which excess coffee harms. So, this answer choice doesn't tell us whether excess coffee produces other benefits that outweigh its harmful effects. Without knowing that excess coffee doesn't produce other benefits, we can't convincingly argue that excess coffee harms overall management ability. Moreover, this answer choice uses a SCOTUS-y “the most” phrase that we don't like to see in a Strengthen with Necessary Premise answer choice. That gives us yet another reason to eliminate (E). Alternatively, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we're using a negated and simplified form of answer choice (E)): “A study gave coffee-drinking managers even more coffee. The managers processed information faster but had trouble incorporating it with past information. Successful management depends more on incorporating new information than speed. But, the amount of coffee one drinks is not the most important factor influencing the speed at which one processes new information. So, the study doesn't prove that drinking more coffee than usual decreases overall management ability.” This argument doesn't make much sense. The “But” part doesn't really conflict with the previous claims that managers had trouble incorporating new information or that successful management depends more on incorporating new information than speed. Rather than contrasting with that evidence, the “But” part starts talking about speed again. The “But” part should form a natural contrast with the previous statements if an answer choice is going to pass the backup test. Moreover, it doesn't suggest that the increases in speed outweigh the downside of excess coffee. So, the “But” part doesn't support the conclusion, either. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (E).

items.stimulusText: Orator: Moral excellence can be achieved only by repeatedly overcoming inclinations to do the wrong thing. Overcoming these inclinations is often difficult to do, even for a morally virtuous person, but the only way to become a morally virtuous person is through the achievement of moral excellence.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is a conclusion that follows logically from the orator's statements?

options.optionContent: A morally virtuous person is incapable of doing the wrong thing.
Most people who achieve moral excellence are morally virtuous.
Someone who has no inclination to do anything that is wrong has achieved moral excellence.
Someone who is not morally virtuous is incapable of achieving moral excellence.
Every morally virtuous person has been inclined to do something that is wrong.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is too bold of a claim. Our conclusion tells us that morally virtuous people must repeatedly overcome the inclination to do the wrong thing. But that doesn't mean they're incapable of doing something wrong. In fact, if they are inclined to do the wrong thing, it would seem as though they're perfectly capable of doing it.

The second premise tells us that all morally virtuous people achieve moral excellence. But we can't just flip those conditions. We can't say that all, or even most, people who achieve moral excellence are morally virtuous. It's possible that achieving moral excellence is just one requirement of becoming morally virtuous. If there are many other requirements—especially ones that are not easily attainable—then it could be the case that very few people who achieve moral excellence ever become truly morally virtuous.

The flipside of the first premise tells us that people who have no inclination to do the wrong thing (and therefore cannot repeatedly overcome that inclination) do not achieve moral excellence. So, the passage contradicts this answer choice, making the answer choice false.

The second premise tells us that people who are morally virtuous must achieve moral excellence. This answer choice just negates both conditions, which we cannot validly do. There could be additional requirements to become morally virtuous. Becoming morally virtuous might require one to achieve moral excellence and, for example, donate half of their salary to charity. Someone could achieve moral excellence but not donate half of their salary. In that case, a person could not be morally virtuous even if they achieve moral excellence.

This statement must be true. If morally virtuous people have repeatedly overcome their inclinations to do the wrong thing, then they must first have those inclinations. Therefore, it's accurate to say that all morally virtuous people have been inclined to do something wrong.

items.stimulusText: Philosopher: Philosophers usually treat emotions as nonrational. But emotion is not nonrational: it only seems that way because language lacks the ability to convey adequate conceptions of emotion. The words we use to refer to emotions name only very general kinds of inner experience—excitement, calm, joy, and so on. Thus, for example, there is no language for describing just how one joy differs from another.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the philosopher's argument by the proposition that there is no language for describing just how one joy differs from another?

options.optionContent: It is an example of the phenomenon that the argument seeks to explain.
It is the main conclusion of the argument.
It is a specific instance illustrating a general claim, thereby indirectly supporting the conclusion.
It is a concession to the view that the argument seeks to refute.
It is the explanation proposed for the phenomenon the argument seeks to explain.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: There's a lot of referential language in this answer choice, so let's work through each referent to see if it matches the argument. The last sentence is definitely an “example,” but whether it's an example of a phenomenon is up for debate. Moreover, if we can indeed call “the words we use for emotions only refer to general feelings like excitement, calm, and joy” a “phenomenon,” we can't say the argument attempts to explain that phenomenon. The argument doesn't explain why we lack words for some emotions. Instead, the argument explains that emotions only seem nonrational because we lack words for some emotions. Therefore, this answer choice subtly but significantly mischaracterizes the philosopher's argument.
Nope. The last sentence is a premise/conclusion that supports the argument's main conclusion. It is not the main conclusion.

There's a lot of referential language in this answer choice, so let's work through each referent to see if it matches the argument. The last sentence is definitely a “specific instance illustrating a general claim.” The last sentence is an “example,” the definition of which is a “specific instance illustrating a general claim.” Moreover, the last sentence definitely illustrates a “general claim”—the claim that the words we use for emotions only refer to general feelings like excitement, calm, and joy. The last sentence shows one instance in which that's true. We only have one word for “joy,” but it doesn't distinguish between long-term joy, short-term joy, ecstatic joy, or any other kind of joy. Finally, the last sentence supports the main conclusion. We anticipated that it's a premise/conclusion that supports the conclusion that emotions only seem nonrational because language can't capture some emotions. And it's accurate to say this support is “indirect” since the conclusion doesn't provide evidence showing that emotions are, in fact, rational. It only explains why emotions may not be as nonrational as some people think. So, this answer choice correctly identifies that the last sentence supports the main conclusion and doesn't mischaracterize any part of the philosopher's argument. It is, therefore, correct.

Nope. The last sentence supports the philosopher's argument. Therefore, it can't support the view held by most philosophers that the argument seeks to refute. After all, the claim that we lack words to distinguish different types of joy doesn't support the claim that emotions are not rational.

First of all, if something is the “explanation” of a phenomenon “the argument seeks to explain,” that “explanation” would appear in the argument's main conclusion. So, this answer choice is just a long-winded way of saying, “It is the argument's main conclusion.” We know the last sentence isn't the main conclusion—it's a premise/conclusion—so that gives us enough reason to cross off (E). If you need more reasons to feel confident eliminating (E), we'll need to work through this answer choice's referential language. The last sentence isn't really an “explanation.” Explanations are typically general claims. The last sentence is explicitly framed as a specific example. Even if we ignore that issue, it's unclear what the word “phenomenon” would refer to in this argument. The claim that “the words we use for emotions only refer to general feelings like excitement, calm, and joy”? In that case, the last sentence doesn't explain why that is the case. It just gives an example of a word that only refers to a generalized feeling. Does phenomenon instead refer to the claim that “emotions only seem nonrational”? In that case, the last sentence still doesn't explain why that's the case. Maybe the third sentence does, but not the last sentence. So, no matter how we slice it, this answer choice mischaracterizes the philosopher's argument.

items.stimulusText: Superstring theory is a controversial new theory in physics that purports, unlike more established physical theories, to explain the nature and existence of gravity. A major problem with superstring theory is that to test it we would have to build a particle accelerator 100 trillion kilometers long. Another problem is that superstring theory has had no success in adequately explaining why the force of gravity is not stronger or weaker than it is.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?

options.optionContent: Superstring theory would be more successful if superstring theorists attempted to explain why the force of gravity is not stronger or weaker than it is.
Physical theories that are better established than superstring theory provide better explanations of physical phenomena than does superstring theory.
Some physical theory more established than superstring theory has had at least some success in explaining why the force of gravity is not stronger or weaker than it is.
A physical theory cannot be true if testing that theory would require us to build a particle accelerator 100 trillion kilometers long.
A theory that purports to explain the nature of a force is deficient if it cannot account for the strength of that force.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is tempting! After all, superstring theory's failure to explain why the force of gravity is not stronger or weaker than it is is a “problem” for this author. So, wouldn't the theory be more successful if superstring theorists attempted to explain why the force isn't stronger or weaker than it is? Well, who's to say they haven't already attempted to explain that? The author just says the theory has had “no success” in explaining why gravity isn't stronger or weaker than it is. It's possible that the superstring theorists have tried and failed to explain this. So, theorists could have attempted to explain this, yet it's still true that superstring theory isn't successful.

Well, it seems plausible that there must be other theories that are more successful than superstring theory. But ... the passage didn't tell us about any of those. The passage never discussed or even alluded to other theories that are more established than superstring theory. So, we don't have any evidence to support the claim that this answer choice makes. Remember our mantra for Connecting Facts questions—when connecting facts, stick to the facts!

This is basically the same answer choice as (B), except it uses the kind of weak language we typically like on Must Be True questions (“some”) and repeated phrases from the passage. However, the passage didn't tell us about any other physical theories, so we don't have any evidence to conclude that another theory has better explained why gravity isn't stronger or weaker than it is. Remember our mantra for Connecting Facts questions—when connecting facts, stick to the facts!

This is a bit too bold! The author says that superstring theory has a few “problems”—not that superstring theory “cannot be true.” While the author would call superstring theory problematic, unconvincing, and deficient, we don't know if the author would say that “cannot be true.” Perhaps the author believes that superstring theory might be true, even if we can't feasibly test it. Remember, unconvincing theories and arguments can still be true!

This matches the inference we anticipated (“a theory purports to explain something like gravity, it should be able to explain why that force is as strong as it is),” so we confidently select it. After all, this passage's author must believe this claim is true. Suppose the author didn't believe this claim. Suppose the author thought that a theory that purports to explain the nature of a force (like gravity) isn't deficient, even if it can't account for the strength of that force. In that case, it wouldn't be a “problem” that superstring theory cannot account for why the force of gravity is not stronger or weaker than it is! So, we can confidently conclude that the author must believe that (E) is true.

items.stimulusText: A smaller number of short documentary films than of full-length science-fiction films are commercially successful, even though there are more short documentary films than there are science-fiction films. Therefore, a higher proportion of full-length science-fiction films than of short documentary films are commercially successful.
items.stemText: Which one of the following arguments is most similar in its pattern of reasoning to the argument above?

options.optionContent: A greater number of small modern apartments than of large Victorian apartments have freestanding bathtubs. Hence, a smaller percentage of large Victorian apartments than of small modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs.

A greater number of large Victorian apartments than of modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs, even though there are more modern apartments than there are Victorian apartments. Thus, a higher proportion of large Victorian apartments than of modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs.

A smaller number of small modern apartments than of large Victorian apartments have freestanding bathtubs. For even though there are more small modern apartments than there are Victorian apartments, a higher proportion of large Victorian apartments than of small modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs.

A greater number of large Victorian apartments than of small modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs, so there are more small modern apartments than there are large Victorian apartments, since a higher percentage of large Victorian apartments than of small modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs.

A smaller number of modern apartments than of Victorian apartments have freestanding bathtubs, even though there are fewer modern apartments than there are large Victorian apartments. This establishes that a higher proportion of Victorian apartments than of modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conclusion resembles the claim that “a higher percentage of Bs than As are C” (it says “smaller percentage,” but that's close enough for this stage of analysis). So, let's take a closer look at this one to see if it matches the full Kirkland version of the passage (“Fewer As than Bs are C. But there are more As than Bs. So, a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.”) Checking out the premises, we can't find any equivalent to “But there are more As than Bs.” That's enough reason to cross off (A). Without that premise, this argument is flawed, unlike the passage. Even if there is a smaller number of large Victorian apartments with freestanding bathtubs, there may still be a larger percentage of large Victorian apartments with freestanding bathtubs—especially if there are far fewer large Victorian apartments than small modern apartments.

This one matches the generic version of our argument! This conclusion resembles the claim that “a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.” So, we'll take a closer look at this one to see if it matches the full Kirkland version of the passage (“Fewer As than Bs are C. But there are more As than Bs. So, a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.”) We'll have to be careful with how we assign our A and B to this answer choice. The first premise says that a “greater number of large Victorian apartments than of modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs.” To line up with “Fewer As than Bs are C,” we'll have to make “small modern apartments” our “A” variable (the smaller variable), “large Victorian apartments” our “B” (the bigger variable), and “freestanding bathtubs” our “C.” So, with some re-arranging, the first premise sounds like “Fewer As than Bs are C.” The second premise establishes that there are more As (modern apartments) than Bs (Victorian apartments), which aligns with “But there are more As than Bs.” The conclusion establishes that a higher percentage of Bs (large Victorian apartments) than As (modern apartments) have Cs (freestanding bathtubs). This matches the Kirkland conclusion that “a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.” Like the passage, this is a valid argument. If there are more large Victorian apartments with freestanding bathtubs despite the fact that there are fewer Victorian apartments overall, there would need to be a greater percentage of Victorian apartments with freestanding bathtubs. By analogy, if you and I were both eating a pie, and I ate more pie than you even though my pie was much smaller than yours, I would have had consumed a greater percentage of my pie. The same reasoning applies to films and apartments for this question.

If you misread the last clause as the main conclusion, this argument is identical to the passage (and to answer choice (B)). However, the last clause is not this passage's main conclusion. The first sentence is the main conclusion. Notice how the first sentence is followed by another sentence that begins with “For”? The structural word “for” almost always comes after a conclusion. Moreover, the word “for” always introduces a premise. And while the claim “even though there are more small modern apartments than there are Victorian apartments” comes immediately after the word “for,” that claim is just a concession. The word “for” really introduces the claim that “a higher proportion of large Victorian apartments than of small modern apartments have freestanding bathtubs.” So, the main conclusion is not that last claim, but the first one: “A smaller number of small modern apartments than of large Victorian apartments have freestanding bathtubs.” Since the main conclusion is about numbers (“smaller number”), it does not resemble our Kirkland conclusion that “a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.” For this reason, we can cross off (C).

This conclusion appears halfway through the argument. The conclusion is introduced by the conclusion word “So” and is the first half of a two-part sentence with “since” in the middle. These structural clues tell us that “there are more small modern apartments than there are large Victorian apartments” is the argument's main conclusion. Since the main conclusion is about numbers (“more”), it does not resemble our Kirkland conclusion that “a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.” For this reason, we can cross off (D).

This conclusion resembles the claim that “a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.” So, let's take a closer look at this one to see if it matches the full Kirkland version of the passage (“Fewer As than Bs are C. But there are more As than Bs. So, a higher percentage of Bs than As are C.”) We'll have to be careful with how we assign our A and B to this answer choice. The first premise says that a “smaller number of modern apartments than of Victorian apartments have freestanding bathtubs.” To line up with “Fewer As than Bs are C,” we'll have to make “modern apartments” our “A” variable (the smaller variable), “Victorian apartments” our “B” (the bigger variable), and “freestanding bathtubs” our “C.” With that framing, the first premise sounds like “Fewer As than Bs are C.” The second premise says “even though there are fewer modern apartments than there are large Victorian apartments.” This means the second premise establishes that there are fewer As than Bs. This doesn't line up with the second premise that “there are more As than Bs.” That's enough to eliminate (E). We can eliminate (E) because, unlike the passage, it is a flawed argument. Even if there are fewer modern apartments with freestanding bathtubs, there could still be a higher percentage of modern apartments with freestanding bathtubs—especially if there are significantly fewer modern apartments than Victorian apartments. (Suppose only 1 modern apartment has a freestanding bathtub, but there are only 2 modern apartments overall. If there are 5 Victorian apartments with freestanding tubs but 100 Victorian apartments overall, 50% of modern apartments would have freestanding tubs, but only 5% OF Victorian apartments would have freestanding tubs.)

items.stimulusText: To test the claim that vitamin C is effective in treating acne, scientists administered it to one group of subjects and a placebo to a control group. The group receiving vitamin C had less severe acne during the study than did the control group. It was subsequently discovered, however, that half of the subjects in each group knew which kind of pill they were given. Among those who could not tell, no difference in the severity of acne was found between the two groups. Therefore, we can tentatively conclude that vitamin C has no real benefit in reducing the severity of acne.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?

options.optionContent: The subjects who were given vitamin C had a history of suffering from more severe acne than did the subjects receiving a placebo.
None of the subjects who were given vitamin C took additional doses of vitamin C on their own.
During the study, the severity of the subjects' acne was lower than the national average.
Some of the subjects who were given placebos consumed foods during the study that are naturally rich in vitamin C.
Some of the subjects who knew their pills were placebos did not actually take the pills they were given.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This definitely makes it more likely that vitamin C reduces acne. This shows “same cause/same effect” by presenting evidence that vitamin C reduces acne. If the vitamin-C subjects had a history of “more severe acne” than the placebo subjects, the vitamin-C subjects probably began the study with worse acne. If the vitamin-C subjects ended the study with the same acne as the placebo group, then we have evidence that vitamin C led to more significant reductions in acne than the placebo. (This answer choice also exploits the “concept switch” or “equivocation” we identified.) This suggests that vitamin C can reduce the severity of acne, weakening this argument. Because this answer choice weakens the argument, we can select it and give the remaining options an, at most, cursory reading.

This doesn't show that vitamin C reduces acne. This might weaken that claim if it said that the subjects who were given the placebo took additional doses of vitamin C. In that case, they could have wound up with the same acne as the vitamin-C group because they were also taking vitamin C. (This would be an example of “same cause/same effect, thus strengthening the claim that vitamin C reduces acne.) But, as written, this answer choice says that the vitamin-C group wasn't taking even more vitamin C. Nonetheless, they were given vitamin C during the study and still wound up with the same acne as the placebo group. This information is consistent with the conclusion that vitamin C doesn't reduce acne.

This is irrelevant to the argument, so it doesn't show that vitamin C reduces acne. Even if the subjects' acne was lower than the national average, we could still use the subjects to track whether vitamin C reduces acne. After all, the study didn't support a conclusion about an absolute amount. The argument didn't conclude that vitamin C guarantees one will have little or no acne. (In that case, using subjects with little or no acne would produce misleading results.) The argument instead concluded that vitamin C probably won't reduce acne. We can measure that, even with people with less acne than most.

This answer choice presents tempting evidence that vitamin C can reduce the severity of acne. After all, if subjects given the placebo consumed foods naturally rich in vitamin C, and if those subjects wound up with the same acne as those who were given vitamin C pills, it seems like the vitamin C may have reduced acne in both groups. Still, this answer choice has a major red flag: the weak, wiggly word “some.” We don't like that language in Weaken questions. Such weak claims rarely provide enough information to meaningfully change the argument. Therefore, these answer choices rarely weaken the argument in question. Even if “some” of the subjects from the placebo group ate foods rich in vitamin C, those few subjects could have been among those who knew which pill they were getting. The author completely ignores those subjects when drawing the conclusion. So, this answer choice may not change the argument at all. Also, this answer choice doesn't tell us about the diets of other subjects. Perhaps all the subjects—irrespective of their group—ate foods rich in vitamin C. In that case, the group given vitamin C pills would still have consumed more vitamin C. That would show the group that consumed more vitamin C still wound up with the same acne as the group that consumed less. Those results would be consistent with the conclusion that vitamin C doesn't reduce acne.

This is irrelevant. The author completely ignores those subjects who knew they were in the placebo group when drawing the conclusion. The author only relies on the subjects who didn't know which group they were in. So, this answer choice does not change the argument at all.

content: John Maynard Smith, The Theory of Evolution, 3rd Edition. ©1975 by Cambridge University Press.

sections.directions: Directions: Each set of questions in this section is based on a single passage or a pair of passages. The questions are to be answered on the basis of what is stated or implied in the passage or pair of passages. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText:
In 1959, Hitsville, USA—the company better known as Motown Records—was founded in Detroit, Michigan by Berry Gordy, Jr. Several factors contributed to Motown's rapidly becoming one of the most successful record companies in the United States. Gordy's entrepreneurial skills and his belief in economic independence played a great role in Motown's success, as did the artistic situation in Detroit in the 1960s. Capitalizing on the rich musical talent of Detroit's African American community, Motown moved quickly into the vanguard of the popular music industry.

Motown's status as an independent company allowed Gordy considerable freedom to oppose recording industry convention. He rejected the practice that was common in the late 1950s and early 1960s of having established recording stars remake songs originally produced within and for limited markets. Gordy insisted that the musical performances recorded by Motown artists would appeal not just to African American audiences, but to a much wider market, and that there would thus be no need to engage high-priced major-label artists to produce alternate versions of Motown's songs. Gordy believed that maintaining the highest possible technical quality in Motown's recordings was an essential part of this appeal, and he devoted the necessary resources to this endeavor.

Another crucial factor in Motown's success was Detroit's well-developed public school music-education program, which provided the company with a deep and talented pool of artists and technicians. The roots of this program reached back to the turn of the century, when a trained soprano and Detroit native named E. Azalia Hackley adopted the musical education of African American youth as her personal mission. From Hackley's tutelage to that of locally renowned public school music teachers, Detroit's African American youth had been educated in a vibrant musical atmosphere. Nearly all of Motown's session musicians, arrangers, and producers were trained in this program. Moreover, many of the performers who would become famous exemplars of the Motown sound received musical training and exposure to diverse musical styles in Detroit schools. Motown's three major early groups—the Supremes, the Temptations, and the Miracles—came together and originally rehearsed at their high schools.

In addition to Gordy's business acumen and the talent produced by the local school system, the invention and growing popularity of electric instruments also played a noteworthy role in Motown's rise to prominence. African American musicians were among the first to use the electric bass, for example, crafting a distinctive sound that inspired other musicians to experiment with this new musical technology. This experimentation ultimately led to a revolution in popular music, helping to broaden both its sound and its audience. In this way, too, Motown Records helped to initiate, and simultaneously benefited from, landmark shifts in popular music culture.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Newly established independent record companies must find innovative approaches in order to compete effectively with established major companies.
The high quality of Motown recordings was made possible by African American musicians trained in the music-education program of Detroit's public schools.
Berry Gordy, Jr.'s faith in local talent and local financing was vindicated by the success of Motown Records.
Berry Gordy, Jr. deserves credit that is long overdue for having brought about a revolution in the culture of popular music in the United States in the 1960s.
Motown Records became a highly successful and culturally influential company through the efforts of an entrepreneurial individual in a favorable artistic environment.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This author only described the conditions that favored Motown's success. The author never said that other independent record companies should emulate Motown's approach. Moreover, the idea of competing with “established major companies” is perhaps alluded to in the second paragraph, but it's certainly not part of the explanation that defines the passage's main point.

Many test-takers may conclude that there's nothing “wrong” with this answer choice — meaning it doesn't misdescribe the passage or change the scope of the discussion — and select it. This passage does, however, completely remove the discussion of Berry Gordy, Jr. and electric instruments from the author's explanation. Because it doesn't fully capture the author's explanation of Motown's success, this answer choice is incorrect.

Like (B), this answer choice is too narrowly focused on Berry Gordy, Jr. to fully capture the author's explanation. This answer choice almost makes it seem like Gordy's faith in local talent and financing was the phenomenon described in this passage. But, Motown's success is the phenomenon described in this passage. Besides, “local financing” wasn't discussed in this passage at all.

Like (C), this answer choice makes it seem like Berry Gordy, Jr. is the topic of this passage. However, Motown's success is the phenomenon, and the author only identifies Gordy as one factor that contributed to Motown's success. That one problem is serious — and would probably lead to quick elimination from an experienced test-taker — but there are other issues as well. There's nothing in this passage to suggest that Gordy's credit is “long overdue,” and the revolution discussed in the final paragraph was caused by musicians' embrace of electric instruments, not Gordy.

Some test-takers may find issue with the general phrasing here. Rather than elaborate on all three parts of the explanation, this answer choice compresses them to “the efforts of an entrepreneurial individual in a favorable artistic environment.” As long as this compression is accurate and doesn't omit anything substantial, however, it's fine. And “the efforts of an entrepreneurial individual” clearly refers to Berry Gordy, Jr., while the “favorable artistic environment” could refer both to the public music-education programs in Detroit and the electric revolution in pop music. So, this answer choice best describes the author’s explanation and is correct.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stimulusText:
In 1959, Hitsville, USA—the company better known as Motown Records—was founded in Detroit, Michigan by Berry Gordy, Jr. Several factors contributed to Motown's rapidly becoming one of the most successful record companies in the United States. Gordy's entrepreneurial skills and his belief in economic independence played a great role in Motown's success, as did the artistic situation in Detroit in the 1960s. Capitalizing on the rich musical talent of Detroit's African American community, Motown moved quickly into the vanguard of the popular music industry.

Motown's status as an independent company allowed Gordy considerable freedom to oppose recording industry convention. He rejected the practice that was common in the late 1950s and early 1960s of having established recording stars remake songs originally produced within and for limited markets. Gordy insisted that the musical performances recorded by Motown artists would appeal not just to African American audiences, but to a much wider market, and that there would thus be no need to engage high-priced major-label artists to produce alternate versions of Motown's songs. Gordy believed that maintaining the highest possible technical quality in Motown's recordings was an essential part of this appeal, and he devoted the necessary resources to this endeavor.

Another crucial factor in Motown's success was Detroit's well-developed public school music-education program, which provided the company with a deep and talented pool of artists and technicians. The roots of this program reached back to the turn of the century, when a trained soprano and Detroit native named E. Azalia Hackley adopted the musical education of African American youth as her personal mission. From Hackley's tutelage to that of locally renowned public school music teachers, Detroit's African American youth had been educated in a vibrant musical atmosphere. Nearly all of Motown's session musicians, arrangers, and producers were trained in this program. Moreover, many of the performers who would become famous exemplars of the Motown sound received musical training and exposure to diverse musical styles in Detroit schools. Motown's three major early groups—the Supremes, the Temptations, and the Miracles—came together and originally rehearsed at their high schools.

In addition to Gordy's business acumen and the talent produced by the local school system, the invention and growing popularity of electric instruments also played a noteworthy role in Motown's rise to prominence. African American musicians were among the first to use the electric bass, for example, crafting a distinctive sound that inspired other musicians to experiment with this new musical technology. This experimentation ultimately led to a revolution in popular music, helping to broaden both its sound and its audience. In this way, too, Motown Records helped to initiate, and simultaneously benefited from, landmark shifts in popular music culture.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes Gordy's attitude concerning the potential for Motown's recordings to have widespread appeal?

options.optionContent: uncertainty in light of past trends in the music industry
willingness to accept anticipated popular indifference
courage in the face of unpromising statistics
confidence rooted in firm personal conviction
optimism based on changing economic conditions

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: An experienced LSATer wouldn't need to read past “uncertainty.” Remember, Gordy “insisted” that Motown's records could appeal to all, so “uncertainty” is the exact opposite of what we're looking for. Moreover, Gordy thought Motown could defy “past trends”; he certainly wouldn’t let past trends deter him, then.

Does a person who “insisted” that his small record label could make massive, universal hits sound this reserved to you? The author never says that Gordy would be willing to accept that audiences would be indifferent to Motown's music. The author never even claimed that anyone anticipated that audiences would be indifferent to Motown's music.

“Courage” would be a slightly strange, but not entirely inaccurate, way to describe Gordy's confidence. Do you recall reading anything about “unpromising statistics,” though? An experienced test-taker would recognize that they don't recall any references to “unpromising statistics” and defer to see if a more familiar description of Gordy's attitude appears in another answer choice. Better yet, such a test-taker would take their lack of familiarity as a sign that “statistics” was not discussed in this passage and eliminate this outright.

“Confidence” is a promising start. This answer choice says this confidence is “rooted in firm personal conviction,” which the passage never explicitly claims. However, note the verbs used to describe Gordy throughout the second paragraph: he “rejected” common practices (P2, S2), and he “insisted” that his music would appeal to the masses (P2, S3). Both of these words are strong action verbs. They are used to show that someone is acting boldly and without reservation. And in the first paragraph, the author claims he had a “belief” in his economic independence (P1, S3). All of these suggest that Gordy had “strong personal conviction” — a steadfast belief in and commitment to his vision. For these reasons, (D) is supported by the passage and is correct.

“Optimism” is a great start and arguably a more apt description of Gordy than “confidence” in (D). But this answer choice suffers from a similar problem as (C). Do you recall reading anything about “changing economic conditions”? An experienced test-taker would recognize that they don't remember any references to “economic conditions” and check the passage to see if any references were made to economic conditions. Better yet, such a test-taker would take their lack of familiarity as a sign that “economic conditions” was not discussed in this passage and eliminate this outright.

items.stemText: The passage provides information sufficient to answer which one of the following questions?

options.optionContent: What musical innovation by African American musicians influenced other musicians?
What musical styles were favored by African American recording companies established before Motown Records?
How long after Hitsville, USA was founded did it come to be known as Motown Records?
Why did Berry Gordy, Jr. insist on following certain standard practices of recording companies in the 1960s?
Why did E. Azalia Hackley dedicate herself to the musical education of African American youth?

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice discusses a musical innovation by African American artists. This could reflect the Motown musicians who embraced electric instruments. If necessary, we can check the final paragraph to see if their use of electric instruments was (1) characterized as an innovation and (2) something that influenced other musicians. The supporting information for (A) shouldn't be difficult to find if you highlighted the electric bass example. During that discussion, the author claims that "African American musicians were among the first to use the electric bass," confirming that this was an innovation by African American musicians. The author then claims this "distinctive sound" would inspire "other musicians to experiment with this new musical technology" (P4, S2). So the passage definitely provides an answer to (A). What musical innovation by African American musicians influenced other musicians? The use of the electric bass.

You could eliminate (B) after reading “before Motown records.” We hear very little about what happened at African American recording companies before Motown. We hear very little about music in general before Motown, other than a few contrasts drawn between Gordy and the major record companies at the time. Since the passage never answers this question, it is incorrect.

You could eliminate this answer choice for asking a very specific question about “Hitsville, USA.” A search could confirm that this passage mentions “Hitsville, USA” at the very beginning and nowhere else. In this brief reference, the author never discusses when or how “Hitsville, USA” became known as “Motown.” So, the passage does not provide an answer to this question.

You could eliminate this one for conflicting with the passage's main point. Berry Gordy, Jr. didn't follow other recording companies' standard practices. One part of the passage's main point was that Gordy's business skills and independence allowed him to defy standard record company practices. The passage never claims that Gordy adopted any standard operations, so this answer choice is incorrect.

You could refer back to the third paragraph to look for an answer to this question. In the second sentence of that paragraph, the author says, “E. Azalia Hackley adopted the musical education of African American youth as her personal mission.” But the author never elaborates on why she made this her mission, so we don't have an answer to this question.

items.stemText: Based on information in the passage, it can be inferred that the author most likely believes which one of the following?

options.optionContent: Gordy's own expertise in the technical aspects of record production ensured that Motown's recordings would be of the highest possible quality.
The great popularity of Motown recordings in the 1960s was largely due to the dearth of innovative popular music being produced by other record companies at that time.
The revolution in popular music brought about by the use of electric instruments would not have occurred if Motown musicians had never used the electric bass.
Gordy's unconventional ideas would have been harder for him to implement if his company had been a subsidiary of a major recording company.
Motown songs would have been equally popular if they had been performed instead by established artists from other record companies.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The main point we anticipated for this passage had little to do with Berry Gordy, Jr.'s technical expertise. Additionally, the claim that Gordy's expertise “ensured that Motown's recordings would be of the highest possible quality” is extremely strong and difficult to support. A time-conscious test-taker would likely defer on this answer choice or eliminate it outright. Indeed, this topic is only brought up at the end of the second paragraph. In that brief discussion, the passage never claims that Gordy personally possessed the technical expertise — only that “he devoted the necessary resources to this endeavor.”

The main point we anticipated did not include a lack of competition as a cause of Motown's success. Additionally, the claim that Motown's success was “largely” due to a lack of other innovative music is strong and difficult to support, especially in a passage that lists out several contributing factors. A time-conscious test-taker would likely defer on this answer choice or eliminate it outright. That would be a wise decision, as this passage did not explicitly discuss what was being produced by other record companies. The only discussion of that sort is in the last paragraph. There, the author claims that there was a “revolution in popular music” during Motown's heyday, suggesting that there was plenty of innovative popular music being produced elsewhere.

We don't have to look too closely before realizing that this describes a hypothetical situation — it discusses what would have happened in some theoretical world in which Motown's musicians didn't use the electric bass. It's nearly impossible to provide the requisite evidence to support a hypothetical like this. The author would have needed to claim that Motown's electric bass-playing musicians were the only possible people who could have initiated the electric instrument revolution. Of course, the author never makes any preposterous claims of that sort, so this answer choice is wrong.

Although it presents a hypothetical, the prediction is much weaker than the one in (C). So, is there reason to believe that the author thinks it would have been harder for Gordy to implement his unconventional ideas if Motown was owned by a big record company? In the second paragraph, the author writes, “Motown's status as an independent company allowed Gordy considerable freedom to oppose recording industry convention” (P2, S1). So, the author thinks Motown's independence led to Gordy's freedom to defy convention. It stands to reason that if Motown lacked that freedom, it would have been harder for Gordy to deviate from standard practices in the record industry. Notably, this answer choice never claimed it would have been impossible for Gordy to do so. That claim would be difficult to support. But this weaker claim is well supported by the second paragraph, and this answer is correct.

Our anticipated main point did not include some hypothetical reality in which “established artists” recorded Motown songs. In fact, the main point was that Gordy's unconventional approach — such as not letting established artists cover Motown songs (P2, S3) — helped contribute to Motown's success. So this answer choice is one the author probably would disagree with.
