items.stemText: The author states which one of the following about Berry Gordy, Jr.?

options.optionContent: He relied on Detroit's public school music teachers to help him recruit talented performers.
He had worked in the music industry prior to founding Motown Records.
He devoted resources to ensuring high-quality recordings at Motown Records.
He was educated in the Detroit public school system.
He founded Motown Records largely to promote the extensive use of electric instruments.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice inserts one part of the passage into another. We know that the second paragraph discusses Berry Gordy, Jr. at length. The third paragraph discusses the talented performers in Detroit at length. Gordy never came up in the third paragraph. And just because public school music teachers were fostering the local talent doesn't mean that Gordy was reaching out to those music teachers.

We really don't get much about Berry Gordy, Jr.'s biography. A time-conscious test-taker would acknowledge that fact and quickly eliminate this answer choice. It's possible that Gordy worked at another record label before founding Motown, but it's never discussed in this passage.

This answer choice is explicitly supported by the passage. At the end of the second paragraph, the author claims that Berry Gordy, Jr. aimed to produce the “highest possible technical quality in Motown's recordings” and “devoted the necessary resources to this endeavor” (P2, S4). So this answer choice is correct.

As was the case for (B), a quick-moving test-taker would recognize that we got very little biographical information about Berry Gordy, Jr. and eliminate this answer choice. The passage never confirms that Gordy also went to the Detroit public schools that produced Motown's seminal artists — we never even learned whether Gordy was from Detroit.

Like (A), this attempts to connect two distinct parts of the passage. The first paragraph tells us Berry Gordy, Jr. founded Motown and the final paragraph tells us Motown musicians were among the first to use electric instruments. But at no point does the passage state or imply that Gordy founded Motown with the goal of promoting the use of electric instruments.

items.stemText: The author most clearly intends to include which one of the following within the scope of the phrase "the artistic situation" (third sentence of the first paragraph)?

options.optionContent: the willingness of Detroit financiers to take risks on artistic ventures
Detroit residents' ready access to musical training in public schools
a Detroit instrument manufacturer's production of electric instruments
Detroit residents' disenchantment with prevailing trends in popular music
Detroit's well-established tradition of supporting independent recording businesses

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This question is eminently anticipatable — we know we're looking for an answer that refers to Detroit's public music education programs or the artists and technicians who came from those programs. This answer choice brings up “financiers” and can be eliminated without much consideration. A review of the passage would reveal that financiers are not a topic of this passage.

This answer choice is precisely what we're looking for: access to Detroit's well-developed, public music education program. This access to music education is the “artistic situation” that is first referenced in the first paragraph and then described in detail in the third paragraph.

This question allows us to be very precise in our anticipation. We are looking for an answer that refers to Detroit's public music education programs or the artists and technicians who came from those programs. This answer choice brings up electric instruments, which is enough to eliminate it. A review of that passage would reveal that this passage never stated that electric instruments were manufactured in Detroit.

We know what we're looking for on this question. Any answer choice that doesn't bring up Detroit's public music education programs or the artists and technicians who came from those programs should be eliminated straight away. This answer choice discusses Detroit r

Yet again, an answer choice that doesn't mention Detroit's public music education programs or the artists and technicians who came from those programs. We can eliminate it without reviewing the passage, but if we did review the passage we'd find that Detroit's history of supporting independent record companies was never discussed.

items.stemText: The author's discussion of E. Azalia Hackley serves primarily to illustrate

options.optionContent: the existence of a long-standing tradition of musical education for African American young people in Detroit
the specific type of musical education that was provided in Detroit's public schools
the extent to which many Motown performers had been directly influenced by Hackley
the way in which music instruction in Detroit's public schools had changed over the years
the author's belief that music instruction in Detroit would have languished without such ardent supporters

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This hits the right note. The purpose of the third paragraph as a whole, and the reference to E. Azalia Hackley in particular, was to show that there were public music education programs in Detroit, which provided Motown with talented African American musicians and technicians.

We never learn what “specific type” of musical education E. Azalia Hackley established in Detroit. So this answer choice is a bit too specific to accurately convey the purpose of including the reference to E. Azalia Hackley.

Like (B), this is a bit too specific to describe the author's purpose in including the reference to E. Azalia Hackley. We learn from the third paragraph that Hackley mentored “locally renowned public school music teachers,” who created the “vibrant musical atmosphere” in Detroit's public music education programs. But we don't know that Hackley directly influenced Motown's musicians and technicians. Perhaps those music teachers developed their own styles and approaches that conflicted somewhat with Hackley's, and those new styles and techniques directly influenced Motown's artists.

Did Detroit's public music education change over the years? Perhaps, but we never get any explicit confirmation of that in the passage. We don't even know whether this is true, so it can't be the purpose behind the reference to E. Azalia Hackley.

Does the author believe that Detroit's music education would have suffered without people like E. Azalia Hackley? Perhaps, but the author never makes this claim in the passage. We don't even know whether this is true, so it can't be the reason the author included the reference to E. Azalia Hackley.

items.stimulusText:
Passage A

Markets, such as stock exchanges, distill the collective wisdom of millions of individuals into a single number, and they do so with amazing efficiency. In contrast to other information-gathering institutions, such as committees and polls, markets require participants to put hard dollars behind their opinions. What's more, markets reward people who are right, not those who lie convincingly or are loudest or most aggressive or who have the most degrees after their name.

Some markets have been engineered for the purpose of providing forecasts. For over a decade, an academic project called the Iowa Electronic Markets has predicted the outcomes of certain elections better than 75 percent of the polls did. Investors put money into a pool. If there are two candidates, each dollar invested purchases two contracts, one paying $1 if candidate A wins, and one paying $1 if candidate B wins. Participants can then buy and sell those contracts at a website. If the going rate for candidate A is 53 cents, then the market as a whole thinks candidate A has a 53 percent chance of winning.

Markets are highly "efficient," in the sense that the market as a whole learns—lightning fast and very accurately—what informed people know. In one experiment, a dozen participants were permitted to trade a fictional stock, having been told that it was worth one of three possible amounts. Two of the participants were then told which amount had been selected, giving them "inside knowledge." Participants couldn't communicate with each other; they could only buy and sell on the market. But everyone watched the movements of the market price, and within seconds, everyone was acting as if they were insiders.

Passage B

Markets are not infallible. To many people, this statement is a form of economic blasphemy. I suggest those people should get over it.

In a recent election, the Iowa Electronic Markets had the eventual winner trading far lower than an opponent up until a few days before the event. For almost a solid year leading up to it, this market's "prediction" was that the opponent would win easily.

Think of markets as racetracks: you get paid lower odds the better the horse looks before a race. When the nag appears ill, old, or tired, the odds are highest, and buyers get the greatest potential payoff. When the steed starts to look healthier, the odds slide lower as a win starts looking more and more likely.

If "prediction markets" do not actually predict the future, then what do they do? I suggest they merely reflect the majority opinion at a given moment. That does not imbue them with any special omniscience. Think of them as polls that avoid random spoofing because the polled must pay an entry fee to participate. That generates more serious responses than other polls—but the answers are just as potentially wrong as any other future guess. Like the majority, sometimes they are right, and sometimes they are wrong.
items.stemText: Both passages are primarily concerned with answering which one of the following questions?

options.optionContent: Is collective wisdom more reliable than individual judgment?
What can be learned from studying the movement of stock markets?
Can markets be used to elicit reliable information?
Are opinions more likely to be true when people will stake money on them?
Are markets that are engineered to predict election results as efficient as actual stock markets?

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Both passages discuss the “collective wisdom” of markets, but neither compares that collective wisdom to “individual judgment.” The latter topic is not mentioned in either passage, so this answer choice can be swiftly eliminated.

A test-taker who anticipated what the correct answer should say — and relied on this anticipation when appraising the answer choices — would likely note that this didn't mention anything about the “reliability” of markets and would move on to the next option without much thought. To less-prepared test-takers, however, this answer choice may be tempting. But beyond lacking “reliability,” there are a few issues here. One, “stock markets” were merely an example of a market in passage A (PA, P1, S1) but were never explicitly mentioned in passage B. In fact, both passages focus on prediction/forecast markets far more than stock markets. Second, we can infer what the authors think we can learn from price movement on stock markets. The author in passage A might say this is evidence that people realize the company's value is changing. In contrast, the author of passage B would probably say the only thing changing is the majority's opinion of the value. But neither passage explicitly addresses this issue, so this can't be the correct answer to a Main Point question.

One way to check whether an answer is correct on this type of question is to see if the authors' main points provide an answer. Both main points answer this question. Passage A concludes that markets are reliable reflections of the collective knowledge of many investors with remarkable efficiency. So passage A would answer this question with a resounding “Yes.” In contrast, passage B concludes that markets are not inherently reliable. So, passage B would answer this question with a defiant “No.”

A test-taker relying on their anticipation would likely note that this answer choice didn't mention anything about the “reliability” of markets and would eliminate this option without much thought. To other test-takers, however, this answer choice may be tempting because it describes a topic both passages address. However, both passages bring up this topic to support the main points; this topic is not the main point.

“Stock markets” were merely an example of a market in passage A, but stock markets were never explicitly mentioned in passage B. Moreover, neither passage compares the efficiency of stock markets to that of prediction markets. Passage B doesn't even bring up the topic of efficiency at all.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stimulusText:
Passage A

Markets, such as stock exchanges, distill the collective wisdom of millions of individuals into a single number, and they do so with amazing efficiency. In contrast to other information-gathering institutions, such as committees and polls, markets require participants to put hard dollars behind their opinions. What's more, markets reward people who are right, not those who lie convincingly or are loudest or most aggressive or who have the most degrees after their name.

Some markets have been engineered for the purpose of providing forecasts. For over a decade, an academic project called the Iowa Electronic Markets has predicted the outcomes of certain elections better than 75 percent of the polls did. Investors put money into a pool. If there are two candidates, each dollar invested purchases two contracts, one paying $1 if candidate A wins, and one paying $1 if candidate B wins. Participants can then buy and sell those contracts at a website. If the going rate for candidate A is 53 cents, then the market as a whole thinks candidate A has a 53 percent chance of winning.

Markets are highly "efficient," in the sense that the market as a whole learns—lightning fast and very accurately—what informed people know. In one experiment, a dozen participants were permitted to trade a fictional stock, having been told that it was worth one of three possible amounts. Two of the participants were then told which amount had been selected, giving them "inside knowledge." Participants couldn't communicate with each other; they could only buy and sell on the market. But everyone watched the movements of the market price, and within seconds, everyone was acting as if they were insiders.

Passage B

Markets are not infallible. To many people, this statement is a form of economic blasphemy. I suggest those people should get over it.

In a recent election, the Iowa Electronic Markets had the eventual winner trading far lower than an opponent up until a few days before the event. For almost a solid year leading up to it, this market's "prediction" was that the opponent would win easily.

Think of markets as racetracks: you get paid lower odds the better the horse looks before a race. When the nag appears ill, old, or tired, the odds are highest, and buyers get the greatest potential payoff. When the steed starts to look healthier, the odds slide lower as a win starts looking more and more likely.

If "prediction markets" do not actually predict the future, then what do they do? I suggest they merely reflect the majority opinion at a given moment. That does not imbue them with any special omniscience. Think of them as polls that avoid random spoofing because the polled must pay an entry fee to participate. That generates more serious responses than other polls—but the answers are just as potentially wrong as any other future guess. Like the majority, sometimes they are right, and sometimes they are wrong.
items.stemText: The purpose of passage A and the purpose of passage B, respectively, are to

options.optionContent: persuade and inform
challenge and defend
present and interpret
entertain and educate
advocate and deflate

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: “Persuade” and “inform” are not contrasting descriptions we'd expect from a passage with an Opposing Viewpoints Meta-Structure. Moreover, “inform” as a purpose suggests the author is taking a passive role in the passage — that the author just wants to convey facts, not opinions. That's a poor description of passage B, which definitely wants to convince us that markets aren't as reliable or predictive as many believe.

“Challenge” and “defend” are antonymic, at least. However, the author of passage A isn't challenging the use of markets in any way. According to passage B's characterization (PB, P1, S2), passage A asserts the conventional view on markets. And passage B's author is definitely not attempting to “defend” markets. So while these two words do reflect the opposing viewpoints, it gets the words backward. Remember, we were looking for an answer choice in which the first word connotes a positive view and the second word connotes a skeptical one.

“Present” and “interpret” are not contrasting descriptions we'd expect from a passage with an Opposing Viewpoints Meta-Structure. Moreover, “present” as a purpose suggests the author is taking a passive role — that the author just wants to convey facts, not opinions. That's a poor description of passage A's author, who definitely wants to convince us that markets are very reliable and efficient.

“Entertain” and “educate” are not exactly the contrasting descriptions we'd expect from a passage with an Opposing Viewpoints Meta-Structure. Moreover, “entertain” as a purpose is a poor description of passage A. There's very little use of humor, analogy, or anecdote that might get used in a passage that wants to entertain. (“Entertain” might be a more apt description of passage B, which uses several offbeat comparisons and word choices — like “get over it,” “nag,” and “random spoofing.” Still, the primary purpose is to convey doubt about the reliability of markets, not to entertain the reader.)

“Advocate” and “deflate” are the contrasting descriptions we'd expect from a passage with an Opposing Viewpoints Meta-Structure. Plus, “advocate” connotes a positive view about markets — passage A's author definitely wants to advocate for the reliability and efficiency of markets — and “deflate” connotes a skeptical view — passage B's author intends to deflate economists' beliefs about the reliability of markets. This matches our prediction, and it is correct.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

Passage A

Passage B

items.stemText: The authors of the two passages would be most likely to agree on which one of the following statements about markets?

options.optionContent: They are a much better predictor of future events than any expert.
They move in completely random and unpredictable ways.
They are easily manipulated for long periods by people with inside knowledge.
They are affected by new information as it becomes publicly available.
They are no better at predicting elections than most polls are.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author of passage A probably agrees with this statement. We can infer that view when that author notes that markets don't benefit the opinions of anyone with “the most degrees after their name” (PA, P1, S3). However, the author of passage B has no express opinion on this issue. The issue of expertise is never brought up or alluded to in that passage. And based on the author of passage B's general view on the reliability of markets, they'd be far more likely to disagree with this statement than to agree with it. Because the latter author has no opinion on this answer choice, it is incorrect.

Both authors probably disagree with this sentiment. The author of passage A claims that markets are very efficient — they quickly and accurately reflect what informed people know (PA, P3, S1). So markets are not erratic; instead, markets move toward the truth that only “insiders” know about. And the author of passage B claims, in the analogy to racetracks, that markets move predictably. As the author implies in that analogy, the markets reflect the general opinion about an asset's “health” or value (PB, P3). When the asset begins to look more valuable, the market will reflect that. Since both authors would disagree with this statement, this answer choice is incorrect.

Although the author of passage A discusses the effect people with “inside knowledge” can have on markets, that author never claims that such people can “easily manipulate” markets “for long periods.” In fact, that author likely believes the opposite; in the third paragraph, they discuss the efficiency with which inside information becomes reflected in market prices. And passage B's author never brings up “inside knowledge.” Either of these issues would be enough to eliminate this answer choice.

We can infer that both authors think markets are affected by new information becoming public. In the study cited in the third paragraph, passage A's author suggests that when certain “insiders” begin trading with new information, that information affects how others buy and sell on markets. As that author puts it, “within seconds, everyone was acting as if they were insiders” (PA, P3, S5). And the author of passage B claims, in the analogy to racetracks, that markets respond to new information. As the author implies in that analogy, the markets change based on the general opinion about an asset's “health” or value (PB, P3). When the asset starts to look more valuable, the market will reflect that. Since both authors agree with this statement, this answer choice is correct.

Both authors would disagree with this statement, making this answer choice incorrect. Both claim that markets are at least somewhat more reliable than polls, as markets require people to back up their opinions with money (PA, P1, S2; PB, P4, S4). So neither author would claim that markets are “no better” at predicting elections than polls.

items.stemText: The relationship between which one of the following pairs of essays, based on what can be inferred from their titles, is most analogous to the relationship between passage A and passage B, respectively?

options.optionContent: "The Future of Computing" and "Futurists' Sorry Track Record"
"Computer Models for Predicting Elections" and "Margins of Error in Prediction of Electoral Results"
"The Pace of Computer Innovation" and "Will Computing Hit a Speed Bump?"
"Computer Simulations of Stock Prices" and "Program Outperforms Fund Managers"
"Computers as Thinking Machines" and "Computers Don't Think: They Execute Programs"

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: A time-saving test-taker would likely eliminate this one solely on the first title. Passage A's main point isn't analogous to “The Future of Computing.” Passage A is all about the present reliability of the markets — it's not about what the markets might look like in the future. So while “Futurists' Sorry Track Record” may match the skepticism in passage B, we can eliminate this answer choice based on the first title alone.

“Computer Models for Predicting Elections” matches the second paragraph of passage A — arguably, it's too close a match since analogous titles rarely match the subject matter this closely. However, this doesn't quite reflect passage A's main point, which was all about the author's trust in the reliability of markets. Nothing in this title suggests the author trusts computer models to predict elections. Moreover, “Margins of Errors in Prediction of Election Results” doesn't match passage B's distrust of or skepticism toward markets. In other words, this doesn't reflect the oppositional relationship of the two passages, and it is incorrect.

This is another answer choice that doesn't quite match the oppositional relationship of passages A and B. “The Pace of Computer Innovation” doesn't exhibit passage A's advocacy for markets' reliability, while “Will Computing Hit a Speed Bump?” doesn't quite evince passage B's skepticism toward markets. With a slight tweak we could make this more analogous to the passages (“The Remarkable Pace of Computer Innovation” and “The Lack of Innovation in Computing”), but it is incorrect as written.

A time-conscious test-taker might quickly eliminate this for at least one of two reasons. First, its subject matter — stock markets — is far too close to the passages'. Analogous titles rarely match the subject matter this closely. Second, and more importantly, “Computer Simulations of Stock Prices” and “Program Outperforms Fund Managers” do not embody the oppositional relationship of the two passages. “Computer Simulations of Stock Prices” suggests a far more descriptive (and less opinionated) passage than the author of passage A wrote. And “Program Outperforms Fund Managers” takes a far more positive stance towards its subject than the author of passage B.

This is the only answer choice in which the titles mirror the oppositional relationship of the two passages. “Computers As Thinking Machines” describes a belief in the reliability of its subject matter, while “Computers Don't Think: They Execute Programs” expresses skepticism toward that same topic. This is what we were looking for and is correct.

items.stemText: Passage B, but not passage A, advances its argument in part by referring to which one of the following?

options.optionContent: market crashes
racetracks
insiders
polls
contracts

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Do you remember reading anything about “market crashes” in either passage? Probably not. A time-conscious test-taker might take that lack of memory as a tell-tale sign that “market crashes” were not mentioned in either passage. If you really wanted to check, reviewing the passage would reveal that the topic of “crashes” was not mentioned at all.

The third paragraph of passage B compares markets to racetracks. This analogy shows how passage B's author thinks markets just reflect the general opinion about an asset's “health” or value (PB, P3). The author of passage A thinks markets are far more predictive than this, so it's unsurprising that passage A never mentions racetracks when making its argument. So, this answer choice presents a detail included in passage B but not A, and it is correct.
“Insiders” is a concept described in passage A (PA, P3) but not in B. This makes (C) incorrect.
We noted that the authors agree on markets' superiority to polls (PA, P1, S2; PB, P4, S4), so we can quickly eliminate this answer choice.

Do you remember reading anything about “contracts” in passage B? Probably not. A time-conscious test-taker might take that lack of memory as a tell-tale sign that “contracts” were not mentioned in passage B. In fact, the topic of “contracts” was only mentioned in passage A, in its description of the Iowa Electronic Markets.

items.stemText: Suppose that, in an attempt to manipulate the Iowa Electronic Markets, several people invest large sums in contracts for long-shot candidate X. The price of contracts for X briefly spikes, but well-informed traders promptly sell their contracts for X at a profit, and the effect of the investments quickly vanishes. This outcome would tend to support

options.optionContent: passage A, since it shows that contracts for an initially unpopular candidate cannot have a sustained increase in value
passage A, since it provides evidence that accurate information is quickly and accurately disseminated throughout the market
neither passage, since the attempt at manipulation was so unsuccessful and short-lived that it proves nothing
passage B, because it shows that a losing candidate can be temporarily ahead of the winning candidate
passage B, because it shows that the market simply reflects majority opinion in the population as a whole

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Passage A never claims that initially unpopular candidates cannot have a sustained increase in value. According to passage A, if the initially unpopular candidate has an increasingly high chance of winning an election, their value should increase in a prediction market. Since this is not a claim passage A asserts, this cannot be the correct answer.

This is just what we predicted, and it is correct. This hypothetical supports passage A because it shows that markets are efficient, meaning they disperse accurate information quickly throughout the market.

This hypothetical supports passage A. An expert test-taker likely wouldn't read past “neither passage.” Moreover, the fact that manipulation was “unsuccessful and short-lived” could support either passage. If the manipulation was short-lived because accurate information was disseminated quickly throughout the market, it would support passage A. If the manipulation was short-lived because people remained convinced that the long-shot candidate couldn't win and acted accordingly, it would support passage B.

This hypothetical supports passage A. An expert test-taker likely wouldn't read past “passage B.” Moreover, this answer choice seems to suggest that the point of passage B was that prediction markets are inherently inaccurate; however, passage B never made such a claim. Passage B instead claimed that such markets are unreliable because they merely reflect the general opinion (which is sometimes accurate and sometimes inaccurate). And, to point out one final issue with this answer choice, this question stem never said the “long-shot” candidate was the “losing” candidate.

This hypothetical supports passage A. An expert test-taker likely wouldn't read past “passage B.” Plus, this hypothetical doesn't suggest that the market merely reflects the majority opinion of the population. The price for the long-shot candidate didn't rise because more people suddenly thought the candidate would win — it was just through market “manipulation.”

items.stemText: The relation between the conception in passage A and the conception in passage B, respectively, of how markets handle the knowledge of their participants, is most analogous to the relation between

options.optionContent: a typewriter and a word processor
a thermostat and a thermometer
a bicycle and a motorcycle
a news broadcast and a magazine
a digital camera and a camera that uses film

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: What are the differences between a typewriter and a word processor? A typewriter is slower, older, and produces more permanent outcomes than a word processor. This doesn't reflect the contrast in how knowledge is described in the two passages, so this is incorrect.

What's the difference between a thermostat and a thermometer? A thermostat produces changes in the temperature, while a thermometer merely records the current temperature. This is very similar to how each passage characterizes knowledge. Passage A argues that knowledge can change the market, while passage B thinks markets are a mere measurement of knowledge. This is the correct answer.

What's the difference between a bicycle and a motorcycle? Bicycles are older, slower, safer, and powered by the user rather than by gasoline or electricity. This doesn't reflect the contrast in how knowledge is described in the two passages, so this is incorrect.

What's the difference between a news broadcast and a magazine? News broadcasts, unlike magazines, are a more recent medium, include an audio and televisual component, and are more responsive. This doesn't reflect the contrast in how knowledge is described in the two passages, so this is incorrect.

What's the difference between a digital camera and film camera? Digital cameras are newer, feature more storage, and provide more immediate and malleable results. This doesn't reflect the contrast in how knowledge is described in the two passages, so this is incorrect.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stimulusText:
Political arguments about biodiversity and the preservation of endangered species generally assume we know what a species is. Yet answering the question of what constitutes a "good" species has long been a confusing and controversial exercise. Within ornithological circles, the debate over the "species question" has often been described as being between "lumpers" and "splitters," between those who group separate but very similar populations of birds into a single species and those who divide such populations into full species. Generally, the lumpers employ what is known as the biological species concept, which until recently was the dominant approach to species classification. Its proponents define a species as a group that is reproductively isolated from other groups, which means that there is no substantial interbreeding in the wild between members of the groups. Splitters, on the other hand, tend to use the increasingly popular phylogenetic species concept, which defines a species as a "diagnosable" population, among which there is a pattern of ancestry and descent. A phylogenetic species is a population in which members share a distinctive, genetically traceable feature that distinguishes it from other populations.

The late Charles G. Sibley, a prominent ornithologist and one of the fomenters of a controversial revolution in avian taxonomy, could be called a splitter. He used a process known as DNA-DNA hybridization—which compares DNA from different species—to determine the relationships of the various families of birds. From his studies he concluded that many earlier classifications of the relationships of bird families were wrong. For instance, he said that vultures found in North and South America were more closely related to storks than to European vultures, and that loons and grebes, which many taxonomists had argued were closely related, were not.

Sibley's work has not been widely accepted. "What the DNA data can give you is an approximation of how different the genes of two isolated populations are," one critic has written, "but how you interpret those differences is basically arbitrary, as arbitrary as any decision made in any species concept." Sibley might not have disagreed, at least not entirely. In 1996 he wrote that "Evolution produces all degrees of genetic differences between populations of organisms, but, for practical reasons, we must limit the number of degrees we choose to 'recognize' by names. We assign names of populations and proposed definitions of taxonomic categories based on various criteria, but the 'species concept' is slippery because there are so many examples in nature of populations that refuse to fit our limited set of definitions and names."

Whatever the merits of each position, the species question undoubtedly has political and economic stakes. For example, increasing the number of species would probably increase the number needing protection as well.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Classifying biological populations into different species has long posed problems for proponents of biodiversity, but many of these problems are closer to resolution thanks to the work of Charles G. Sibley and others.
Although scientists often disagree on the classification of biological populations into species, most agree that all such classification systems contain arbitrary elements.
How biological populations are classified into species is a controversial scientific issue with practical implications in current debates over the preservation of biodiversity.
Traditional methods of classifying biological populations into species continue to have their supporters, but these methods have been called into question by the work of Charles G. Sibley.
Charles G. Sibley developed revolutionary methods of classifying biological populations into species, but these methods have not been widely accepted.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice attempts to assert the primacy of Charles G. Sibley. Sibley wasn't the most important subject in this passage — the debate itself was — nor did Sibley help resolve this debate. (Arguably, Sibley's controversy has only made the debate harder to reconcile.) So this answer choice completely mischaracterizes the subject of the passage and Sibley's role therein, so it is wrong.

There are two scientists who note that classification systems are arbitrary, both mentioned in the third paragraph. There's the scientist who criticized Charles G. Sibley, and there's Sibley. Unless this passage was written in some alternative universe in which there are only three scientists, that's not enough scientists to account for “most” scientists. This answer choice also over-emphasizes the discussion of classification systems' arbitrary nature, which was confined to just the third paragraph.

This answer choice asserts that there is a debate (or, in this answer choice's terms, a “controversial scientific issue”), as is often the case when the passage utilizes a Describe a Debate Meta-Structure. It also includes the author's conclusion from the final paragraph: that resolving this debate has “practical implications.” Some test-takers might take issue with the reference to “the preservation of biodiversity,” but this topic was raised by the author in the first sentence. Because this answer choice includes both the debate and the author's view, it best captures the main point.

Another answer choice that over-emphasizes the role of Charles G. Sibley in this passage. The main focus of this passage was not Sibley's work or his revisions to classification systems. Instead, the focus was the debate. Sibley was merely an example of someone on one side of the debate.

Yet again, this answer choice places too much weight on the role of one Charles G. Sibley. The discussion of Charles G. Sibley was confined to the second and third paragraphs. This answer choice is missing the larger debate described in the first paragraph and the author's views conveyed by the last paragraph.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stemText: According to the passage, which one of the following is true of the phylogenetic species concept?

options.optionContent: It has effectively discredited other methods of species classification.
Its popularity has declined since the death of Charles G. Sibley.
It is more useful in ornithology than in most other biological sciences.
It has more proponents now than it had in the past.
It was pioneered by Charles G. Sibley.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: If the splitters effectively “discredited” other methods of species classification, that would mean the debate was effectively resolved. We know the debate is still ongoing, so we can eliminate this without reviewing the passage.

Do you recall reading anything about Charles G. Sibley's death or a decline in splitters' popularity? Probably not. (If anything, test-takers will recall that the splitters' approach is becoming increasingly popular.) If you don't remember reading about a detail, simply defer and move on to the next answer choice. If you did review the passage, you'd see that their approach is described as “increasingly popular” (P1, S6).

Do you recall reading anything about biological sciences other than ornithology? Probably not. If you don't remember reading about a detail, simply defer and move on to the next answer choice. If you did review the passage, you wouldn't find any references to other biological sciences.

Do you recall reading anything about the number of “splitter” proponents? Perhaps not, but at least two references might allow you to remember this fact. First, when describing the “lumpers,” the author notes that that was the “dominant approach” until recently (P1, S4). That suggests the alternative approach, the splitters', is getting more popular and thus has more proponents. Second, the author notes that the splitters' approach is getting “increasingly popular” (P1, S6). This confirms that the splitters approach now has more proponents. So whether you recalled that this answer choice was supported, or you found that confirmation after deferring on or eliminating the rest of the answer choices, this is the answer choice that must be true based on the passage.

Do you recall reading that Charles G. Sibley pioneered the splitters' approach? Probably not. If you don't remember reading about a detail, simply defer and move on to the next answer choice. If you did review the passage, you would only see that author says Charles G. Sibley “could” be called a splitter, which would suggest that he has a tangential relationship with that group and that he didn't pioneer it.

items.stemText: It can be inferred from the passage that Charles G. Sibley would have been most likely to agree with which one of the following views?

options.optionContent: Splitters are somewhat more likely than lumpers to be motivated by political and economic, rather than purely scientific, concerns.
The total number of animal species in the world today is probably accurately estimated.
A proper goal for ornithologists engaged in taxonomic research is to simplify the classification system so as to reduce the total number of species.
The degree of genetic difference that two populations display with respect to each other should have little bearing on the decision about whether to classify them as belonging to the same species.
Disagreements about species classification are likely to persist even if techniques like DNA-DNA hybridization are further refined.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Do you recall reading that Charles G. Sibley's views on “lumpers,” or of political or economic motivations at all? Probably not. If you don't remember reading about a detail, simply defer and move on to the next answer choice. If you did review the passage, you wouldn't find any commentary on lumpers' motives from Sibley.

Do you recall reading that Charles G. Sibley claimed that the total number of species in the world today is “accurately estimated”? Probably not. In fact, you may believe the opposite is true. If Sibley is making controversial and major revisions to the previously dominant “lumpers” theory, it's unlikely that he thinks the consensus view of species classification is accurate. That's enough to eliminate, rather than defer on, this answer choice.

Do you recall reading that Charles G. Sibley wanted to simplify the classification system or reduce the total number of species? Probably not. In fact, you may recall that the author says that Sibley belongs to the “splitters,” who are increasing, not reducing, the total number of species (P2, S1). That's enough to eliminate, rather than defer on, this answer choice.

Do you recall reading that Charles G. Sibley didn't think genetic similarities between populations should affect how we classify species? Probably not. In fact, you may remember that the author notes that Sibley is a “splitter,” and they are all about using genetic similarities to classify species (P1, S7). And you may also remember that Sibley uses DNA in his classification system (P2, S2), which certainly involves species’ genes. That's enough to eliminate, rather than defer on, this answer choice.

We've seen four unpromising answer choices, so hopefully this one looks good. So do we recall reading anything about Charles G. Sibley's views on disagreements about species classification? Perhaps. In his defense of his DNA-DNA hybridization approach, he notes that “the 'species concept' is slippery because there are so many examples in nature of populations that refuse to fit our limited set of definitions and names” (P3, S5). So he believes that classifying species is “slippery,” and that nature always is more complicated than “our limited set of definitions and names.” So even if his DNA-DNA hybridization approach improved, it would still rely on limited definitions and names, so disagreements could still persist. This answer choice has textual support, and unlike (B) through (D), it doesn't explicitly contradict Sibley's views. Therefore, this answer choice is correct.

items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately illustrates the biological species concept, as described in the passage?

options.optionContent: There is strong evidence that bird populations X and Y share a common ancestor. Therefore, they should be classified as belonging to the same species, even though they do not resemble each other in certain respects.
Bird populations X and Y interbreed in the wild, but they have never been known to do so in captivity. Therefore, they should be classified as belonging to different species.
Bird populations X and Y are visually indistinguishable from each other and live in similar, though mutually isolated, habitats. Therefore, they should be classified as belonging to the same species.
Although bird populations X and Y have differently shaped beaks and head feathers, they nevertheless interbreed. Therefore, they should be classified as belonging to the same species.

Although bird populations X and Y have never been known to interbreed, they resemble each other in appearance, and examination of their DNA indicates a common ancestor. Therefore, they should be classified as belonging to the same species.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We are looking for a situation involving interbreeding bird populations. This doesn't discuss interbreeding at all. A time-savvy test-taker would eliminate this without reservation, especially if they remembered that this illustrates the phylogenetic approach taken by the “splitters,” not the biological species concept used by the “lumpers.”

This answer choice at least mentions interbreeding, so it warrants a closer inspection. However, it says that the populations interbreed in the wild. Based on the biological approach, these populations should be classified as the same species, irrespective of how they interbreed in captivity. For this reason, this answer choice is incorrect.

We are looking for a situation involving interbreeding bird populations. This doesn't discuss interbreeding at all. A time-conscious test-taker would eliminate this without a second thought. Some test-takers who made a less precise anticipation may overthink the answer choice’s reference to being “isolated.” However, the passage referred to isolation as “reproductive isolation,” which was defined as two non-interbreeding species (P1, S5).

We were looking for a situation in which two bird populations interbreed and are classified as the same species, and this answer choice states exactly that. Don't overthink the morphological dissimilarities — we only need to focus on the interbreeding part.

This answer choice at least mentions interbreeding, so it warrants a closer inspection. However, it says that the populations don't interbreed in the wild. Based on the biological approach, these populations should be classified as different species, irrespective of their morphological or genetic similarities. For this reason, this answer choice is incorrect.

items.stemText: If valid, Charles G. Sibley's findings, as described in the last two sentences of the second paragraph, most seriously challenge which one of the following assertions?

options.optionContent: A stork population from Europe is likely to be of the same species as one from North America.
A stork population from South America is likely to be of a different species than one from Europe.
A vulture population from North America is likely to be of the same species as one from Europe.
A vulture population from South America is likely to be of a different species than one from Europe.
A vulture population from North America is likely to be of the same species as one from South America.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The correct answer will either say a North or South American vulture is related to a European vulture or that loons and grebes are related. This is all about the relationship between European and North American storks. A time-conscious test-taker would quickly jettison this choice and move on.

The correct answer will either say a North or South American vulture is related to a European vulture or that loons and grebes are related. This is all about the relationship between European and South American storks. An expedient test-taker would quickly eliminate this choice and move on to the next one.
Just as we predicted: an answer choice that says a North American vulture is related to a European vulture. There is no need to second-guess or double-check — select this and move on.
Assuming they didn't select (C) and move on, an efficient test-taker would quickly note that this is consistent with the first example of Charles G. Sibley's findings, and move on.

Assuming they didn't select (C) and move on, an efficient test-taker would quickly note that Charles G. Sibley's findings aren't inconsistent with this assertion. Sibley didn't note whether North and South American vultures were the same species, only that each was more closely related to storks than to European vultures.

items.stemText: The passage provides information sufficient to answer which one of the following questions?

options.optionContent: When did Charles G. Sibley begin using DNA-DNA hybridization in species classification?
What are two continents on which storks are found?
What common traits led taxonomists to classify loons and grebes as related species?
What is one objection to applying Sibley's work to species classification questions?
What is one non-avian animal population on whose classification lumpers and splitters have disagreed?

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Dates tend to stick out in passages. A quick glance at the second paragraph would confirm no dates mentioned were there. So the passage does not provide the information needed to answer this question. We can eliminate this.

We just answered Question 19, which required us to review the reference to storks in the second paragraph. Although we learned that vultures are found in the Americas and Europe, we never were told which continents storks can be found. So the passage does not provide the information needed to answer this question. We can eliminate this.

We just answered Question 19, which required us to review the reference to the commonly held belief that loons and grebes are related. But in our review, we never learned why loons and grebes are thought to be related. So the passage does not provide the information needed to answer this question. We can eliminate this.

The existence of at least “one objection” to Sibley's work is certainly consistent with the main point of this passage. If there's a debate between “lumpers” and “splitters” like Sibley, then there will be a few objections among the parties. Reviewing our notes, if necessary, we can see the beginning of the third paragraph describes one objection to Sibley's approach — that it's “arbitrary” (P3, S2). So the passage provides enough information to answer this question, making this the correct answer.

Do you recall reading anything about non-avian (non-bird) species? Probably not. Assuming they hadn't already selected (D) and moved on, an expedient test-taker would defer on this choice and look for support for (D) (which is consistent with the main point) in the passage. And any search for references to non-avain species would be in vain, as no such references were made in this passage.

items.stemText: It can be inferred from the passage that a proponent of the biological species concept would be most likely to disagree with which one of the following statements?

options.optionContent: There are considerably more bird species in the world today than are currently recognized.
Members of two bird populations that differ from each other in certain physical characteristics might nevertheless belong to the same species.
Some animal species that are considered extinct in fact have surviving members.
There is less biodiversity in the world today than there was 50 years ago.
Current debates over what constitutes a species are sometimes motivated by political rather than by scientific concerns.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We know that lumpers want to “lump,” or group, similar bird populations together. So, lumpers almost certainly do not think there are “considerably more bird species” than we currently recognize. They either think that there should be fewer bird species than we currently recognize or (since their view is dominant) the right number of bird species. Therefore, this assertion is something the lumpers would disagree with, making this the correct answer.

Assuming they didn't select (A) and simply move on to the last question, a time-savvy test-taker would quickly eliminate this. The lumpers think that bird populations are the same species if they interbreed. They do not base their decisions solely on the birds' physical attributes. So, physically dissimilar bird populations could be part of the same species — as long as those birds interbreed.

Assuming they didn't select (A) and simply move on to the last question, an efficient test-taker would eliminate this without much consideration. “Extinction” was not a topic most would remember reading about; an efficient test-taker would take that as a sign that “extinction” was not in the passage and that this claim was not something we know the lumpers would disagree with.

Assuming they didn't select (A) and simply move on to the last question, a fast-moving test-taker would eliminate this without thinking twice. Such a test-taker would note that “biodiversity” was a topic only the author broached in this passage. For that reason, we can't say that the lumpers would disagree with this claim.

Assuming they didn't select (A) and simply move on to the last question, a speedy test-taker would quickly eliminate this. Such a test-taker would probably not remember reading about “political” motivations and would take that as a sign that this topic was not in the passage at all. So, they'd (correctly) conclude we cannot say whether the lumpers would disagree with this answer choice's claim.

items.stimulusText:
Political arguments about biodiversity and the preservation of endangered species generally assume we know what a species is. Yet answering the question of what constitutes a "good" species has long been a confusing and controversial exercise. Within ornithological circles, the debate over the "species question" has often been described as being between "lumpers" and "splitters," between those who group separate but very similar populations of birds into a single species and those who divide such populations into full species. Generally, the lumpers employ what is known as the biological species concept, which until recently was the dominant approach to species classification. Its proponents define a species as a group that is reproductively isolated from other groups, which means that there is no substantial interbreeding in the wild between members of the groups. Splitters, on the other hand, tend to use the increasingly popular phylogenetic species concept, which defines a species as a "diagnosable" population, among which there is a pattern of ancestry and descent. A phylogenetic species is a population in which members share a distinctive, genetically traceable feature that distinguishes it from other populations.

The late Charles G. Sibley, a prominent ornithologist and one of the fomenters of a controversial revolution in avian taxonomy, could be called a splitter. He used a process known as DNA-DNA hybridization—which compares DNA from different species—to determine the relationships of the various families of birds. From his studies he concluded that many earlier classifications of the relationships of bird families were wrong. For instance, he said that vultures found in North and South America were more closely related to storks than to European vultures, and that loons and grebes, which many taxonomists had argued were closely related, were not.

Sibley's work has not been widely accepted. "What the DNA data can give you is an approximation of how different the genes of two isolated populations are," one critic has written, "but how you interpret those differences is basically arbitrary, as arbitrary as any decision made in any species concept." Sibley might not have disagreed, at least not entirely. In 1996 he wrote that "Evolution produces all degrees of genetic differences between populations of organisms, but, for practical reasons, we must limit the number of degrees we choose to 'recognize' by names. We assign names of populations and proposed definitions of taxonomic categories based on various criteria, but the 'species concept' is slippery because there are so many examples in nature of populations that refuse to fit our limited set of definitions and names."

Whatever the merits of each position, the species question undoubtedly has political and economic stakes. For example, increasing the number of species would probably increase the number needing protection as well.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would provide the strongest support for the author's assertion in the final sentence of the passage about the effects of increasing the number of recognized species?

options.optionContent: It is becoming increasingly difficult to enact international agreements to protect endangered species.
Increasing the number of species through reclassification is more likely to result in new avian species than in new mammalian species.
In disputes over protection of endangered species, economic considerations often outweigh scientific ones.
Advances in scientific techniques like DNA-DNA hybridization will probably favor the efforts of proponents of the phylogenetic species concept.
Proponents of the phylogenetic species concept are less likely to contest an established species classification if none of the biological populations involved is endangered.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author didn't make any claims about actually protecting endangered species, so this is irrelevant to the author's assertion.

Even if it's true that reclassifying species will create more bird populations than mammal populations, it doesn't necessarily follow that more species will need protection following reclassification. And that's because this doesn't address the part vs. whole issue. If the lumper-defined species considered endangered each have only one population regarded as endangered, it wouldn't matter how many new species we made after reclassification. Even if we split the species up as finely as possible, to the point that each population is now considered a new species, we still wouldn't increase the number of endangered species.

This is wrong for the same reason as (A). The author didn't make a claim about how easy it will be to actually protect the species. The author only asserted that the number of species that need protection will increase. So, this answer choice is irrelevant to the author's assertion at the end of the passage.

So what? The author never claimed that the most likely result of species reclassification is more species. The author just said that if there are more species, there will probably need to be more species needing protection. Another irrelevant answer choice.

This answer choice fixes one of the problems we identified. We identified one situation in which increasing the number of species might not result in more species needing protection. As described in the final paragraph of that section, let's assume the lumpers grouped the populations A, B, and C into one species, but none of populations A, B, or C were regarded as endangered. In that case, the lumpers wouldn't think the species as a whole needed protection. Even if the splitters came along and divided that species into three new species, none of the new species would need protection either. This answer choice fixes this issue by saying that the splitters wouldn't both reclassify the lumpers' A/B/C species. So the only times the splitters would reclassify species is when the species has one or more endangered populations. This would make it more likely that increasing the number of species through “splitting” would result in more species needing protection. Therefore, this strengthens the argument, and it is the correct answer.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stimulusText:
This passage was adapted from an article published in 1991.

Because it is relatively easy and inexpensive to produce copycat computer programs, most people believe that some form of legal protection should be extended to creators of computer software. Without a legal deterrent to copycat programming, the resources expended by an individual or a company to develop an innovative software program could be unfairly exploited by rivals who develop a similar product and rush it to market at a lower price. The occurrence of such exploitation would leave software developers with little financial incentive to develop innovative products. While most legal commentators agree that copyright has generally proven to be an effective means of preventing this exploitation, some contend that patent protection is also needed to combat copycatting.

In essence, every piece of software is an encoding of one or more algorithms. An algorithm is simply defined as a series of steps to be followed in carrying out a task; to be usable in computer applications, an algorithm must be expressed in terms that can be processed by a computer. Proponents of software patents assert that in providing a specific way of achieving a desired result, the encoding of algorithms is analogous to the design of a process. Process designs (for example, an innovative way of inducing a series of chemical reactions) do, in fact, fall under the scope of patent protection. However, in order for any design to be patentable, it must be genuinely a product of invention (rather than, say, a law of nature or a logical axiom). For example, while a particular innovative windmill design might be patentable, the principle that wind can be harnessed to produce energy would clearly not be. On similar grounds, software algorithms, because they represent generic principles underlying the specific processes by which tasks are to be carried out by computers, should not be considered patentable.

Issuing patents for computer programs would extend protection to software developers beyond that afforded by copyright when there is really no compelling justification for doing so. Insofar as software programs constitute the expression of ideas in the form of specific texts (i.e., sequences of computer code), they fall more appropriately within the established domain of copyright law. Whereas patents protect the underlying design of an invention, even if it is never actually executed, copyright protects only the particular way in which the underlying ideas are expressed. Because the value of software lies in its form of expression, protection should be given only for particular applications—expressions of algorithms in an encoded form. Such protection could be more effectively afforded with only slight modification to existing copyright laws, and the financial incentive to develop innovative software could thereby be preserved.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Although patent protection is needed for a software program's underlying algorithms, existing copyright laws adequately protect the expression of those algorithms.
Legal protection for software programs beyond that which could be provided through the modification of existing copyright laws is unwarranted.
Without the legal protection afforded by patents, software developers will have little financial incentive to innovate.
Issuing patents for software programs would give software developers more protection against copycat programming than granting copyright does.
Copyright protects only the unique manner in which a software program's underlying algorithms are expressed.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: An efficient test-taker wouldn't need to read past “patent protection is needed.” That's the exact opposite sentiment the author expresses in this passage, so this can be eliminated without further reading. If you did, you would also note it claims “existing copyright laws adequately protect” software programs' algorithms, which conflicts with the author's assertion that algorithms don’t need protection and the claim at the end of the passage that protection of software requires a “slight modification to existing laws.”

This answer choice describes the authors' resolution of the debate accurately — that we only need to modify existing copyright law to protect software programs. Some test takers may take issue with this choice because it doesn't explicitly mention patent law. But that is not an issue here, since the reference to legal protection “beyond that which could be provided through ... copyright laws” would naturally include patent law. So patent law is acknowledged by this answer choice tacitly.
The author argues the opposite of this — that patent law is not needed to protect software developers' financial incentive to develop innovative software.

This is the third answer choice to suggest that the author prefers or sees merit in using patent law to protect software. The author claimed that there's “no compelling justification” for such protection (P3, S1), so we can cast off this choice.

This is true, but it's not the author's main point. The author's main point was that this copyright protection is the only legal protection needed to maintain the financial incentive to create innovative software.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stimulusText:

items.stemText: On the basis of the passage, which one of the following is most likely to be a view held by the author?

options.optionContent: An algorithm is analogous to a law of nature or a logical axiom.
The discovery of an algorithm that can be used in a software program usually requires genuine inventive effort.
Sequences of computer code should not be copyrightable unless they encode a previously unused algorithm.
Proponents of software patents underestimate the severity of the problem of copycat programming.
The encoding of algorithms is not analogous to the composition of a literary work.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't conflict with the author's main point. Remember, the author thinks that patent protection should not cover computers' software or constituent algorithms. And, whether we can recall the following fact on our own or need to consult our notes or the passage, we can recall that patents do not protect laws of nature or logical axioms (P2, S5). So, there's reason to believe that the author thinks that algorithms are similar to laws of nature and logical axioms. An efficient test-taker may note that this answer choice was consistent with the author's main point and is probably correct. Then, they'd look to see if they could eliminate the remaining answer choices without reviewing the passage before returning and selecting this answer choice. If they weren't able to eliminate the remaining choices, they could return to the passage and find the reference to laws of nature and logical axioms in the third paragraph. They'd see that the text supports the inference that the author believes algorithms are similar to laws of nature and logical axioms. They'd notice how the author says, after claiming that patents do not protect laws of nature and logical axioms, that patents shouldn't protect algorithms “[o]n similar grounds” (P2, S7). There, the author draws a line connecting algorithms to laws of nature and logical axioms, making this the correct answer.

This conflicts with the author's main point. Remember, the author does not think that patent protection should cover computers' software or constituent algorithms. We should also recall that patents cover “genuine inventive efforts.” So the author almost certainly disagrees with this sentiment, and it should be eliminated without consulting the passage.

Do you remember reading anything about copyright requiring algorithms to be “previously unused”? Probably not. A risk-averse test-taker might defer on this answer choice. On the other hand, a more risk-accepting test-taker would take that as a sign that this topic was not discussed in the passage, so we cannot say whether the author agrees with it. And if you did eventually review the passage, you wouldn't find any references to “previously unused algorithms.”

This conflicts with the main point. The author didn't think patent proponents underestimated the risk of copycat programming or that patent protection was inadequate to deter copycat programming. The author acknowledges that patent and copyright proponents seek to protect software innovators from copycat programmers (P1, S4). The author's main point was that patent protection is unnecessary to accomplish this goal. So the author almost certainly disagrees with this sentiment, and it should be eliminated without consulting the passage.

Do you recall reading about “literary works”? Probably not. If you don't remember reading about a detail, simply defer and move on to the next answer choice. A risk-averse test-taker might defer on this answer choice. On the other hand, a more risk-accepting test-taker would take that as a sign that this topic was not discussed in the passage, so we cannot say whether the author agrees with it. And if you did eventually review the passage, you wouldn't find any comparisons to literary works.

items.stemText: In the final paragraph, the assertion that software programs constitute the expression of ideas in the form of specific texts functions primarily as

options.optionContent: an example of a counterintuitive claim
a rationale for the author's position
a causal explanation for a particular phenomenon
a layperson's definition of a technical legal term
a point of consensus between opposing viewpoints

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We're looking for an answer choice that says the claim from the question stem is there to advance the author's conclusion. This answer choice does not say that, so it should be quickly crossed off. If you wanted another reason to eliminate this choice, a “counterintuitive claim” means the claim is inconsistent with commonly held beliefs or common-sense expectations. The author did not discuss any such claims in the third paragraph.
“Rationale” just means “reason” in this context. The author included the claim from the question stem to provide a reason for their position. This is correct.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the claim from the question stem is there to advance the author's conclusion. This answer choice does not say that, so we should eliminate it without reservation. If you wanted another reason to get rid of this choice, there are no causal claims or phenomena described in this paragraph.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the claim from the question stem is there to advance the author's conclusion. This answer choice does not say that, so we should cross it off without giving it a second thought. But if you wanted another reason to eliminate this answer choice, a "layperson's definition" simply refers to a definition that could be understood by a non-expert. Such definitions generally use simplified language or analogies to commonly understood concepts. The statement from the question stem uses neither, so we have no reason to believe that this was intended to be a "layperson's definition."

We're looking for an answer choice that says the claim from the question stem is there to advance the author's conclusion. This answer choice does not say that, so we should rule it out. And, of course, the author does the exact opposite of finding a point of consensus between opposing viewpoints in the third paragraph. The author uses the third paragraph to conclude that one side is wrong and the other is right.

items.stimulusText:
This passage was adapted from an article published in 1991.

Because it is relatively easy and inexpensive to produce copycat computer programs, most people believe that some form of legal protection should be extended to creators of computer software. items.stemText: Based on the passage, it can be inferred that proponents of software patents are most likely to hold which one of the following views?

options.optionContent: The sequences of computer code through which a computer programmer expresses algorithms are more genuinely a product of the programmer's inventiveness than the underlying algorithms are.
Software algorithms are generic principles underlying the specific processes by which tasks are to be carried out by computers.
Patent protection should supplant copyright protection as the sole legal means of preventing copycat exploitation of software products.
Both the algorithms and the specific way in which a software program expresses them should receive legal protection against copycat programmers.
As the number of available computer programming languages increases, copycat programming will become less common.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Do you recall reading that the patent proponents thought that coding was more inventive than creating the algorithms? Probably not. If you don't remember reading about a detail, simply defer and move on to the next answer choice. If you did review the passage, you wouldn't find any support for this claim. The pro-patent folks claimed that encoding algorithms was “analogous to the design of a process” and thus fell under patent law, which covers processes that are the products of invention (P2, S3-S5). This suggests they think their inventiveness has as much to do with the algorithms as with the coding.

This answer choice seems to conflict with the patent proponents' views. If software algorithms are "generic principles," the algorithms shouldn't be covered by patents, which only cover genuine products of invention (P2, S5). For this reason, we should eliminate this answer choice. If you reviewed the passage, you would see that the author — not the patent proponents — characterizes algorithms as "generic principles" (P2, S7).

This answer choice makes a very bold assertion (“sole legal means”), which is very difficult to support and unlikely to be correct. A test-taker who was short on time (or simply used their time efficiently) might defer on this choice to see if another answer choice is easier to support. If you did review the passage, you could see that the patent proponents don't want to replace copyright law to protect computer software. Instead, they want to supplement copyright protection with patent protection as well (P1, S4).

This seems consistent with the views held by patent proponents. They want to protect the algorithms underlying the computer program through patent law. They also want this patent protection to supplement copyright protection (P1, S4), which covers the coding (P3, S2). So it seems reasonable to conclude that patent proponents want to protect both, making this the correct answer.

Do you remember reading about the increasing number of computer programming languages? Probably not. If you don't remember reading about a detail, simply defer and move on to the next answer choice. If you did review the passage, you wouldn't find any support for this claim. Moreover, this answer choice seems to conflict with the patent proponents' views. They want to increase the protection available to software, so it seems unlikely that they think the threat of copycat programming will decrease in the future. Two reasons to eliminate this choice.

items.stimulusText:
This passage was adapted from an article published in 1991.

items.stemText: Which one of the following statements is most strongly supported by the passage?

options.optionContent: General scientific principles currently qualify for neither patent nor copyright protection.
The value of patents lies primarily in their protection of the generic principles underlying specific process designs.
Items that qualify for patent protection usually also qualify for copyright protection.
The algorithm underlying a copyrighted software application may not legally be used in a competing software application without permission from the copyright holder.
The majority of commercially available software applications contain at least some sequences of illegally copycatted computer code.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: You may not recall reading about general scientific principles and whether they qualify for patent or copyright protection. It doesn't contradict the main point of the passage, so we shouldn't eliminate it. For this reason, it might make sense to resist the urge to review the passage and instead defer on this choice. If we can eliminate the remaining choices, we can confidently select this one. If we have several answer choices remaining in contention, we can review the passage to see if this is supported. If we eventually need to consult the passage, we can find the support needed to select this one. The author explicitly excludes scientific principles — such as the principle that wind can be harnessed to produce energy — from patent protection (P2, S6). And in the author's description of copyright protection, the author says that copyright protects how an idea underlying an invention gets expressed (P3, S3). Obviously, a scientific principle isn't an expression of an invention, so it couldn't be covered by copyright law either. So, this answer choice is supported by the passage, and it is correct.

This seems to conflict with the author's main point — the author claims in the second paragraph that “generic principles” like algorithms are not eligible for patent protection (P2, S7). Since this conflicts with the main point, we can eliminate it.

This answer choice also seems to conflict with the author's main point, so it can be eliminated. In supporting the main point, the author claims that copyright law protects the way ideas are expressed, while patent law protects the ideas as long as they are a product of the invention (P3, S3). These are two different things, so qualifying for patent protection is not sufficient to also qualify for copyright protection.

This seems to conflict with the author's main point. The author concludes that the algorithms should not receive protection under patent law, so we don't have any reason to think that algorithms are so protected that they can't be used in multiple software programs without permission. This is another one we can eliminate.

Unlike (B) - (D), this answer choice doesn't appear to contradict the author's main point. However, this is a fairly bold assertion and is consequently quite hard to support. Moreover, most test-takers will probably not remember any references to the prevalence of “illegally copycatted computer code.” Indeed, this was not a topic the author addressed, and this answer choice is incorrect.
